description: This is my 2nd visit. 1st visit was fine. This time the place is way understaffed. Thus service super slow. The slow cooked pork was so salty that was hard to eat. Soup was very so so. Pina fresca was dilish though. Staff are nice, but couldnt compensate for the slow service...
author: david c.

description: Food is good, homemade tortillas is a plus! Price was very EXPENSIVE!! Good place to try once but that's about it for me!! Portions are way to small to satisfy a hungry appetite!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Our families stopped here after marching in the 2014 Pride parade. Admittedly, we went to Tacolicious first, but we were told there was a 45min+ wait @ 2pm (btw: this location was very far removed from the Pride festivities). Having two toddlers in the group, we were "forced" to go to Regalito Rosticeria instead, Thank Goodness!!!
All the ingredients were extremely fresh and the food preparation was excellent. Every single dish was presented with care and Pride. Service was exemplary and on point. Our entire group was satisfied with all the dishes served. I cannot stress enough just how Fresh the ingredients were that their Chef utilized. Their wine and beer list was also excellent. Please stop by and try this place. I don't see how anyone can leave disappointed.
author: Sovereign J.

description: Really disappointing. Guac was good, rest of meal went downhill. Avoid the tinga. Really liked the decor though! And waiter was friendly. Sadly, food didn't live up
author: Eric M.

description:
Pollo con mole negro was fabulous. The other steak dish was pretty good too. 

Got some chicharón pig skin as appetizer. Soooo good!

Did not agree with the consistency of the churro/hot chocolate dessert. The chocolate was too thin and soupy.
author: Yuchi C.

description: dont listen to the haters !!! people are never satisfied. regalito is great for birthday events. they have a great variorty of dishes !!! my favorite
author: Nora A.

description:
A girlfriend and I got a Groupon for this place. It was a good deal, though the food wasn't the greatest. They give a ton of guacamole, which was really appreciated since we were starving. Unfortunately, it took us awhile to order, though it wasn't very busy. 

The enchiladas verde is another story. We both ordered it thinking it was the best option on the small menu they had available (which I don't usually mind). It lacked flavor and there was a lot of tortilla and a lot less chicken. The serving was large though.

We ended the meal with the guava, which my friend ate. She said it was good. Overall, an okay experience, but I'm not planning to come back.
author: Hana H.

description:
Truly truly sad.  Sad for two reasons: (1) I should NEVER EVER get charged $19 for four (YES FOUR!) chunks of "chile colorado" and tasteless to top it off!  (2) All the good reviews.  

As a Mexican-American from LA's eastside I know good Mexican! and I'm a MAJOR foodie! This is FAR FROM anything close to "Mexican" 

For those of you who gave this place anything above 3 stars....WOW!  Clueless when it comes to the complexity of Mexican gastronomy.
author: Anthony Xavier S.

description:
The food was bland and grossly overpriced. We were disappointed because the menu looked decent and there was a guy hovering outside urging us to go in because it was so good. My theory is that all the great reviews from this place are coming from a bunch of gringos who find it to be a delightful departure from Taco Bell. (I mean, it's not that hard to make fresh guacamole...)

We ordered the enchiladas verde and the taquitos. They both had chicken in them and a little bit of salsa on top. It tasted like nothing. I had to request a side of salsa fresca. The plates were tiny. I needed a chainsaw to cut through my taquitos. At the end, the waitress asked us how we liked the food, and I told her I thought it was pretty bland. She then avoided me for the remainder of our stay. (I was nice about it, I used to be a waitress.)

The tragic irony is that there's so much amazing Mexican food in the mission at half the price!
author: Angela K.

description:
Super fresh food with ingredients you want to eat! The service was prompt & polite. Came in for lunch... will come back for the dinner menu!
Taquitos - get a mix of chicken & potato/cheese!
Enchiladas verdes- must try!
Guacamole con taquitos- great appetizer!
Churros with Hot Chocolate-- 'nuff said
oh yeah and sangria!
author: Dawn R.

description:
I think the three and a half star rating couldn't be more suiting for Regalito. It wasn't quite a 4 star experience but it also wasn't quite run-of-the-mill. 

Regalito stands out from a sea of Mexican food restaurants in the Mission for it's healthy and fresh ingredients. This is not authentic taco truck grub, peeps. This is a nicer, sit down restaurant that charges a pretty hefty price for an entree. 

Unfortunately, my enchiladas were a tad on the dry and bland side. For $14, I expect nothing but greatness. I don't care if it's healthy and organic and whatever else we label things to feel better about ourselves. Good is good, plain and simple. 

Although a tad disappointed with my dinner, the guacamole and salsa were awesome. The staff was friendly and attentive. It accommodated our party of 6 nicely. 

If my friends invited me to dinner here I'd probably tag along but I wouldn't ever suggest it myself. Too many other great Mexican food joints in the area for a lot cheaper.
author: Julia N.

description:
Called around 5 on a weekday evening to see if I could make a reservation that night to use my soon-to-expire groupon, but the host said they were only taking walk-ins. However, he was happy to allow me to use my groupon if I was okay with potentially sitting at the bar.

When I first walked in, my thoughts were: uh yes! I'm very happy to sit at the bar and watch the flames grilling our meat and the fresh tortillas and guacamole being produced. While I guiltily and anxiously awaited my date (husband was circling the block looking for parking), the host was gracious and made sure to check in on me to let me know he hadn't forgotten that I was waiting for a table. I didn't make a reservation and there are other complete parties here... and you're remembering me?? Thanks!! :)

Based on all the rave reviews about the guacamole, we ordered it as our appetizer.  For $10, it's a very decent amount of guac and deep fried tortilla (GIANT chips!), albeit on the pricey side for guacamole. But WOW, my husband was BLOWN AWAY... he would not stop raving about how delicious the guac was! The portion is better suited to a party of 4, so I over-indulged a bit on guacamole and was a little full by the time our entrees came out.  But after our first few bites, we were both studying the guacamole-making lady and taking mental notes to try to replicate the recipe at home. THAT GOOD!

As for the entrees, the flavor was fresh and ingredient-focused, rather than deep slow-cooked flavors.  Husband got the enchiladas verde (his fave) which came with a side of rice and beans.  Everything was well-seasoned and tasty... not super greasy and not super spicy.  At our server's suggestion, I ordered the carne asada, which came with rice and excellently crisp green beans and a side of red sauce.  Per my request, the carne asada was perfectly medium and served with soft freshly made tortillas.  The green beans were my fave.

We ended our meal with the bread pudding for dessert as it was included in the Groupon.  It had an really interesting smoky flavor from being skillet grilled with an awesome crunch from raw (blanched?) almonds.  Even with the caramel sauce, this was a more savory than sweet dessert.  But nothing special to both of us.

We also had a sangria (for me!) and a Corona with lime (for him!) and appreciated that the Corona was served in a frosty-chilled glass.  A great effort to overcome their lack of beer on tap! Overall, we enjoyed our experience, especially for the price (thank you Groupon for introducing us to this place and saving us $30 on our first meal).  We would like to come back with husband's parents who have dietary restrictions but miss Mexican food (if they could get it without the excessive salt, spice and grease), especially for the guacamole.  However, the price was bit much for my stingy wallet, but understandable for the very fresh ingredients and very attentive service.  Without the Groupon, our appetizer, two entrees, dessert and two drinks would have been $90.  3.5 stars if we had no Groupon, but rounded up because... we did! :)
author: Hannah C.

description:
Reserve the sunny patio for a large group in the back. Originally came with a friend that sweet talked a brunch deal & unlimited mimosas before a large group of us went to a music festival. Good food & delicious mimosas - My 5 star experience

Fast forward 6 months to a half-full restaurant on Sunday for brunch and we get seated out front & forgotten about for a good 30 minutes. When someone comes out to take our drink order, it took another 30 minutes just to get two mimosa carafes that cost us over $60. Definitely not worth it due to the poor service - My 1 star experience

Overall: 2 stars
author: Anna R.

description:
We've been here a few times and I've come to the conclusion that the Pollo Regalito is my favorite dish. On my last visit I ordered the Carne Asada which was really lacking. We also ordered one guacamole. It was a huge portion. There were only two of us, this could have easily fed 4-6 people. I wish they had a smaller option for two people. 

Their Sangria is bliss. I think it's my favorite in the city.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
Lots of Mexican restaurants in the The Mission . . . and no doubt, some really good ones.   So where do I get off writing a review on one where I only had dessert? 

Well, the tres leches cake with fresh strawberries was excellent -- moist and succulent.  

But more important than that . . . Eduardo, my server, treated me with respect even though it was just me and I wasn't ordering and full meal.  He seated me at the counter where I could see the kitchen and introduced my to the chef.  The guy was busy but happy to show off some of his award winning dishes -- chicken mole,  dry rubbed ribs . . . and he whipped up an order on fresh guacamole in less than 2 minutes while his assistant rolled balls of masa to be pressed into homemade tortillas. The aromas were incredible! 

The way customers reacted to the food and the service told me a lot too.   People really seemed to be enjoying themselves. 

While my experience at Regalito was brief, it's definitely a class act -- the ambiance,  the food and especially the people.  I look forward to returning.
author: Jack L.

description:
I wanted to try this place and when a deal popped up on Groupon I snagged it. I left unimpressed with the food.

I thought the line out the door and counter seats only available meant this place would be a gem. The space in small and people waiting for tables meant hovering and staring you down while you ate. 

It's an open kitchen so sitting at the counter you can watch the chefs making homemade tortillas and prepare all the food. 

The enchiladas were drowned in sauce, making them a tough to eat. Overall, it's "Mexican" food and overpriced. If I can get the same thing that tastes better at a spot a block away, I'm going there.

The service was great, I'll give them that. The waitresses were attentive and very friendly!
author: Chanda G.

description: The food was bland. The chicharones were chewy & not crunchy. We went on a Tuesday. The menu was pork fest cooked in different ways. The food was forgettable. Service was good...friendly & fast. Too bad even the guacamole was bland.
author: Rox P.

description:
This place gets 5 stars for service. Our waitress was very friendly, patient and attentive.

However, the food (and especially the value) gets 3 stars. I had a beef shank and while it was pretty good (not great), it was much too small for what it cost ($19). I used a Google Offer which shaved $24 off our bill and I STILL thought it was overpriced.

Also, when I go to a Mexican restaurant, I expect to receive chips and salsa but this wasn't the case here.

Overall, Regalito Rosticeria was okay but we won't be going back.
author: Teiki K.

description:
I live right around the corner from this adorable little restaurant, so I really wanted to love it.  After all, in my fantasy, this was to be my new neighborhood old standby.

Alas, I was underwhelmed.

Let me start by saying the ambiance and decor were lovely, the staff very attentive and polite, and they were very accomodating to our large party.  But all of that can't make up for the fact that I just didn't dig the food.

We ordered three bowls of guacamole to share at the table, and as it arrived, I was salivating, just thinking about how good homemade guacamole was going to taste in my mouth...and then I tried it.....and I was disappointed!  It was bitter, needed salt desperately, and all of us were so unimpressed with it, that it lingered on in front of us, as we were less than interested in consuming it, despite our hunger.

For dinner, I decided to order two appetizers:  an order of Taquitos de Pollo and one order of Taquitos de Papas y Queso.  They arrived with a squiggle of crema and a spoonful of salsa over the middle, the latter portion looking decidedly anemic given how much taquito there was before me.  Both the chicken and potato-cheese taquitos suffered from chronic flavorlessness, and the chicken also gave the double-whammy of being super-dry, sawdusty, even.  I craved a dipping sauce, especially after using up with the first taquito what little salsa was on my plate.  Eventually I flagged down the server and asked for some more crema, which definitely perked up the taquitos...but my stubborn food brain was still annoyed that it took a cup of crema to give my dinner any flavor.

My partner got the Enchiladas Verdes, which were by far the most tasty offering on the menu, everyone at the table agreed.  I enjoyed several forkfuls of this dish, but noted the small portion for $14, knowing full well that I could go to any of a zillion other Mexican restaurants in the neighborhood and get that same dish for almost half the price.  It wasn't, sadly, special.

Another friend got the carnitas.  I found the meat dry, which is pretty rare for carnitas, and again, lacking in any depth of flavor, which made me very sad, since I love carnitas!  Also, we both noted tha the pintos were strangely spicy, almost inedible to us, something one doesn't generally expect from pintos.

I wouldn't go here again unless I'm dragged for a birthday or something like that.  Not because it's a bad restaurant, because it most certainly is not.  But because it just didn't inspire me to want to go back.  I suppose that different taste buds will feel differently about this restaurant, and honestly, I'm happy it exists in my neighborhood, because it's clean and pretty and the orange lettering on the front makes me happy to walk by.
author: Amy L.

description: First time here and it won't be my last!! The food is amazing. My boyfriend and I decided to go all out and get the carne asada, the pork shoulder and the chicken. The good was absolutely delicious!!!! Soo good!! Out of the three the pork shoulder was the best! The waiter was extremely nice and went out of his way to make our first time wonderful!!! Totally recommend this place!!!
author: Megan A.

description: Good fresh food. Nice back patio. Guacamole was delicious. Carnitas burrito is tasty. Chorizo con papas with home made tortillas was good too.
author: Phil D.

description:
We decided to go here for a celebration dinner.  The waiter was good and the food came out on time and was heated properly.  We ordered the roasted chicken with potatoes and the enchiladas plus taquitos. 

My problem was that the food was not worth the price.  The roasted chicken was a whopping $19 and it was nothing special at all.  If I had known this I would have made it myself for less than half the price.  It was not even that tender and was not impressive at all.

The enchiladas were okay, but cost $18 also and were nothing special either.  I hate making mistakes when eating out, ugh!  My recommendation is save your money and make your own roasted chicken at home.  There was absolutely nothing special about this dish.

The taquitos were like the ones you get at a store.  The meat was dry.
author: Jerry H.

description:
Used the Groupon.  

I really wanted to like this place, however, it was not very good.

I had the Cochinita Pibil pork.  It was bland.  Some pieces were fall apart tender, but many were dry and chewy.  Even the delicious sounding habenero pickled onions only had the slightest bit of tang or spice and added nothing to the dish.  The black beans were tasty but could have come from a can for all I know.

The wife had the green chile enchiladas.  Again, very bland.  While it looked tasty, covered with crema and queso fresco, the chicken inside the enchiladas was simply boiled which resulted in a very weak flavor profile.  No spices or deep flavors one imagines when one thinks of Mexican food. $17

I must also say that the portion size was very small for the prices listed.

I have to agree with other reviewers and say that much tastier food can be had at any number of taquerias throughout the city, and for much less scratch.
author: Nico B.

description:
I really wanted to like this place, because my friend took me here for my birthday, and I have been wanting to go to a good Mexican restaurant in the Mission that wasn't a "hole in the wall" divey type place. 
I'll start with the positive: the service was friendly and attentive.
The menu was very limited. I thought it was missing some pages, but no, it was only one page, and that was for everything - appetizers as well as main courses. There were only 4 or 5 of each to choose from, and only two kinds of meat - chicken and pork. Unfortunately, these are my two least favorite meats. No beef, no lamb, no fish, no seafood of any kind. Forced to choose between two evils, I went with the pork ribs. They were actually not bad, but there wasn't a lot of meat on them. Furthermore, the decor was disturbing. A couple dozen pictures on the wall of insects with human faces. I don't know about you, but I don't want to look at a picture of a cockroach with a human face while I'm dining. The main issue, though, is really the complete lack of options.
author: Jason B.

description: Went for drinks and dinner. Tried the papas con chorizo that were super yummy with a really good red sangría. I had the fish tacos and my fiancé had the pastor tacos which had just the right amount of spice and flavorful. Loved it!
author: C G.

description: Fresh, simple, flavorful Mexican food at a reasonable price.
author: Ernie S.

description: A good friend took me to try this Mexican place in Mission after finding parking for over 30 minutes nearby.   Servers are very personable and flexible.  We felt well attended.  Our server made arrangement to let us have  a very spacious table even we did not have a reservation.   Guacamole was very good with their home made tortilla.  Our main dish of pork roast and slow cooked pork were excellent and authentic.  Their flan was rich and very good. Homemade churros and mercian chocolate was pretty good too.  Ambiance is very artistic with different paintings in Mexican bright colors.  Service is very good.  Both servers checked on us from time to time.  The whole experience eating there is very nurturing.    This is a good place to return. it truly reminds me the very good food in Puerta Vallarta.
author: Sunny B.

description:
It was a little too pricey, although they are free range/grass fed. I got Papas con Chorizo which is one of the cheapest things on the menu. If you like grease this is the plate for you. I know, chorizo is usually greasy, but this was like a soup..It tasted good, so it was good grease. 

The tortillas were delicious and the spicy salsa, I could of eaten it with a spoon. Those were the best parts. Service was great. Ambiance was peaceful. But wasn't into the prices and lack of variety
author: Tina T.

description:
Can't say thank you enough to Eduardo, our server. He was very nice, funny and helpful just to start off the evening. 
The carnitas and pollo con mole were great! Chips and dip very good as well! 
We will be back very soon and will be bringing some friends because it is a great place, wonderful service and very nice decor.
Hope you will enjoy Regalito's as well!
author: Ed N.

description: I'm sorry to have to say this is not a Mexican restaurant. The atmosphere is nice but the food is insufficient for the amount they charge. No beans and rice with the meals?! The food was also bland. My sisters couldn't believe they didn't serve tequila. The sangria my sisters had instead was a cheap fruit punch with alcohol. The service mediocre. I will stay away.
author: Roger H.

description:
I have been meaning to go to Regalito for quite some time, but yesterday was finally the day. Service was great and they make everything t order, so I was able to ask for everything without onions (pesky allergy). The guacamole was freshly made, it had a bit of a kick. I ordered the chicken mole and it was DELICIOUS! It is served with rice and tortillas. The tortillas are homemade type... yum yum! I will go back and try other dishes so I can give a better review of the overall menu, but for now... I am a fan!

Make a reservation... it does get busy! And when it is busy, it can get noisy, so keep that in mind.
author: Amelia M.

description: I guess I went on a bad day. They had only white rice!! And the beans had no flavor. They have a small menu so expect what they do have to be good. If you have a groupon its a good deal for mediocre food otherwise you will spend a lot and be disappointed.
author: Rebecca S.

description: Great place!!! Really great menu selection and great prices. Wine and alcohol also available. Very clean and staff is friendly and knowledgable. Definitely would go back again.
author: Charlotte C.

description:
Where to begin on the magic that is Regalito?  First off, my credentials to critique Mexican food.  My parents are from Jalisco and Michoacan (Mexico for those of you unfamiliar with Mexican states) so I'm always excited to find a place that doesn't bastardize the food of my parent's homeland or list "taco salad" or a burrito that weighs 20 lbs. as a main entree.  

Now onto this lovely spot!  I've been here a handful of times and it's always because of the food.  Here are my favorites in no particular order.  **Disclaimer: These are only my favorites because this is all I've tried to date.  They have all been awesome and excited to try more.

So the entrees:

1. Tinga de Pollo - as good as my mom's recipe!
2. Carne con Chile Colorado - this takes me back to visiting my family in Mexico City!
3. Carnitas - you can never go wrong with pork on a fork.
4. Pollo con mole negro - this isn't the "come out of a jar" garbage they serve at most places.  You can taste the Oaxacan love in this dish.

Other pros?  The service is awesome and very attentive.  Did I mention the handmade tortillas - this may seem like a small detail but I've been eating tortillas since before I could walk and nothing makes a mexican meal more amazing than that.

Overall, I'd recommend this place for those of you interested in experiencing a little taste of Mexico.  If you're lucky enough to have a mariachi band walk in, here are a few songs for you to request.  You can hear them on YouTube:

1. El Rey
2. Serenata Huasteca
3. La Parranda
4. El Sinaloense
5. Mariachi Loco (for fun!)

Provecho a todos!
author: Janet L.

description: Service was great!. Food was just Ok. wine not so good. A bit over prices for latin food.
author: Bill B.

description: Mediocre food, really slow service, bland guacamole, overcooked pork, and generally overpriced. Avoid.
author: Daniel F.

description: The Pozole was delicious & fall apart in your mouth good on a rainy Saturday.  That being said, $14 dollars for that alone is very steep, especially with the other great options in the area.  Had we looked up the prices before, may not have come for lunch because that was a little excessive.
author: Raina D.

description: I would eat here weekly if I could control myself. My last review was short so I'm going to make up for it a bit. I brought two work colleagues who live in areas of the U.S. with limited Mexican food options. We started with a carafe of their amazing sangria and the guacamole and tostadas. Both were a hit. I had to order the pollo mole because Regalito has some of the best mole in the city. It was hard for me to not get the enchiladas again since I had them last time and they were so good. One of my colleagues got the tamale special and loved it. The other got the mole too and found it to be a bit too spicy but she still liked it. My friend got the pollo tinga which was really flavorful and tender. We also ordered a side of the calabaza which was very very tasty. If you ever want to treat yourself to upscale Mexican food in SF, you simply must try Regalito. Also, the location is wonderful for taking a Mission area walk after your meal.
author: Nicole O.

description:
The food is pretty solid, but being in the Mission I kinda expected more.  Still, it wasn't bad by any stretch of the imagination, and the habanero salsa was actually really tasty.  If I had a better spicy food tolerance, I would have slathered that on a whole lot more, for sure.

The issue is that the food is really overpriced.  For about $15-20 for an entree, I expect to be full.  I was really disappointed by the portion of the admittedly tasty dish, but yeah, I just kinda wish there were more.  I wasn't really full at the end.  Even something like offering chips and salsa would have done a lot to make it more satisfying.  

Still, if that doesn't bother you, the food is solid.  Recommended to go to at least once if you're in the mood for Mexican.
author: Norman S.

description: It's a great deal with a groupon. about half the menu changes with the season. Inside decor is modern Mexican, nice. only complaint, the tostada for the guacamole is hit and miss. Sometimes it's stale. But everything else on the menu is good. Roasted chicken, carnitas, etc.
author: Dustin T.

description: This place rocks. Been here twice, and the food was absolutely delicious. Attentive service, cozy ambiance and housemade tortillas (if you sit at the bar, you can see them making them). The chicken mole is FANTASATIC! Their guac is above average (and I am a guac snob...) Definitely worth a visit.
author: Sherry K.

description: All I remember is that it was good but pricey for the portion. I think the guacamole was $11 and it was about the size of a softball. We all liked the sangria and our server was great but we came on a Friday when the Giants were playing so it was pretty empty and we got a lot of the attention.
author: Xteethx B.

description:
I have loved Regalito's for many years. My experience has always been a winning combo of delicious and unusual takes on classic Mexican cuisine, warm and attentive service and a comfortable setting with a lovely outdoor space. I've never had a bad meal here, but the standouts for me have been the taquito app (I love them so much I often get as a main with a side of their DEELISH brussel sprouts); chicken enchiladas - healthy portion, yummy tomatillo sauce, perfectly cooked chicken; and carnitas. 

Last night, however, I tried their ribs in mole special. I'm not generally a mole fan - it's so easy to be heavy-handed with it. This was undoubtedly the best, most complex and flavorful mole I've ever had! The ribs were fork tender and the pork was complemented by the flavors in the mole, rather than being overpowered as so often is the case. They came with homemade tortillas (mmm), rice and beans. As always - service was perfect, vibe relaxed and inviting and the Cab I ordered - delicious. But, really, this dish is the stuff of fantasy - can't stop thinking about it!
author: Ruby G.

description:
Huevos con sunshine.

Another November weekend. Temperatures warm enough to eat outside yet again. Are we on vacation? Or is home just that awesome.

Definitely the latter which helped make up for a just OK brunch.

Service and seating were great, ten bucks seemed steep for a not very large portion of eggs and tomatoes. Appreciated the egg whites. Receive a few tortillas too.

Just expected a bit more. Perhaps it was part of the deal for the nice weather. Well OK then.
author: Jason B.

description: Tender moist fall off the bone (because there were no bones) chicken, smothered in thick flavorful mole. Served with whole beans, spanish rice and corn tortillas perfectly delicious. We were starved at 2 pm on a hot (yes HOT Saturday in the Mission) scorched my shoulders hot. Sat outside in the shade in the nice breeze, washed it all down with some cerveza's. Our server was very friendly and prompt. Everywhere else had a ridiculous wait and here we walked right up sat right down and got served, and as far as I was concerned the food and service was great and no wait. Alittle pricy but a good size portion (my husband helped me with mine). Really nice meal, want more of that mole.....must go back....soon!
author: Susan D.

description:
This place has a lot going for it:
It's beautifully decorated 
They have a decent amount of space with a heated back patio area, an indoor dining room and bar seating, and also a few tables out front
They were able to seat us around 8pm on a Friday night
The produce is high quality and the meat is free range

We had a couple of glasses of wine, the taquitos, and the cochinita pibil.  Everything was perfect and delicious.  I don't think you can compare this to most of the Mexican joints in the Mission.  It's in a different category of dining experience.  The portions were not enormous, but my boyfriend and I split the appetizer and the entree and we were both too full for desert.  It was a shame because the people next to us had the bread pudding with ice cream and caramel and it looked amazing.  The pitchers of sangria were tantalizing as well- maybe something for next time.
The service was outstanding.  We take a long time to choose what to eat and they got the timing perfect.  Everyone we came in contact with was polite and friendly and not in a fake way.  They are simply friendly people.
Another great spot in the Mission!
author: Erika W.

description:
Can't believe it took me so long to get here! We came with a Groupon (as many other Yelpers have mentioned) and the entire experience was great. We were adequately warned about having to sit at the counter -- and it was a very fun spot - we got to preview all the food coming out of the kitchen before deciding what we wanted to eat!

We had a guac appetizer (the only food we ate that I didn't think was outstanding -- it needed salt). After that, I had a chile relleno and my dinner date had enchiladas. Both were great choices! We loved our food and then tried the bread pudding for dessert -- super interesting and tasty. 

Overall, we ate way too much. But the food was great and the restaurant is very cute. If you're looking for an alternative to the everyday mission burrito, but still want amazing Mexican in the neighborhood, check out Regalito. 

(p.s. This was not a cheap meal without the groupon, but I'd go back at full price!)
author: Gretchen S.

description: We used a Groupon to eat here last night. Even for a Tuesday, the restaurant seemed to be pretty empty for the entire time we were there. We really liked the back patio, it has a serene feeling that really took us away from the hustle and bustle of the city. The food was good, but not amazing. The selection of dishes were quite unique: homemade chicherons, pork belly, mole sauce, and Mexican hot chocolate are not super common, even in the bay area. And we liked the fact that all the meat was sourced from hormone/antibiotic-free animals. But we also felt that the prices were somewhat high, even for gourmet Mexican food. Two glasses of sangria, an appetizer, two dinners, and a desert, none of which were very large, came to just over $80, plus tax and tip. Had we been asked the value of the meal after we finished, we would have put it closer to $60. So, while this place is fairly solid, I would have to recommend one of the other nearby Mexican places instead of it.
author: Brian S.

description:
We had our latest Thursday Night Dinner Club at Regalito and we were not disappointed.  None of us had ever been here before but everything from the margaritas to the entrees were very flavorful.

For appetizers we started with the guacamole, salsa and chips and taquitos.  We also added the habanero sauce which had a nice kick to it.  For our main meal we had a variety of dishes and I had the carnitas which were prepared perfectly and were very tasty.  We were too full for dessert but we loved our meal.

The place is pretty small inside and when we sat around 7:30 it was not very busy but by the time we left it was pretty crowded which was a good sign.  The meal was relatively cheap as well.
author: Blake B.

description:
It was great not to have any wait on a Friday night but that is a warning sign with that location in the Mission. 

The food was fine (guac, enchiladas, etc.) but definitely not stellar. Overall, nothing is great about this place except the lack of a line.
author: Ojus P.

description:
Great service - very attentive waitress.  Food was good, not fabulous, but good.  We had the rotisserie chicken and pork shoulders.  Great that they have half orders of the guacamole which is all we needed - didn't want to fill ourselves before dinner.  Delicious margaritas which oddly were not on the drinks menu so ask for them!  The ambiance was perfect for us - nice music in the background, tasteful decor.  We sat tat the bar which was very comfortable.  It's not a big restaurant so if you get there by 6-630p on a Friday night, you'll likely get a seat w/o reservations.  Of course, parking in the Mission can be challenging.  

We'd definitely come back again!
author: FoodJunkie S.

description:
I SO wanted to like this place, but it was just sub-par. If I'm going to eat $20 mexican food in the mission, I'm expecting great things. Regalito just didn't deliver. Here's the break down:

The good:
- the rotisserie chicken was fresh, juicy, and a big portion 
- margaritas: not overly sugary with a definite kick of tequila (the way I like them)

The bad:
- the place was pretty busy, and our waiter was inattentive and made some mistakes. Drinks took a long time to come out, he brought out the soup with dinner (shoulda been an appetizer), entrees came out at different times..overall, just messy service
- despite this being a semi-nice restaurant, they let the mariachi men in, which totally changes the vibe. We were sitting in the front, so we could barely talk over the music. 
- the potatoes that came with the chicken- SO salty. More salt than potatoes. 

Overall: decent food, but overpriced for what it is. We kept waiting to taste the flavor, spices, heat...anything!
author: L B.

description:
Regalito is a small Mexican restaurant specializing on such things as free range chicken, pork and other dishes. They make homemade tortillas. They have several yummy desserts. We loved their chirros and hot chocolate (this is very good chirros and was very yummy).

The service is friendly; you can see the food prep in the kitchen; lively environment but still able to easily have a conversation with your party. Recommend making reservations on the weekend as it is a small but good restaurant.
author: Samantha K.

description:
Ugh...I have to take away a star due to the UBER SLOOOOOOOOOOOOW service last Sunday. 

I mean, I was in no rush, but I was UBER hungry. 10 mins for drinks...20 mins for guacamole (did they leave to go pick them fresh from the garden 20 miles away??), and then the entrees slowly rolled out. 

A 90 minute lunch date is a bit much.

However, I was able to make a reservation easily online (www.opentable.com), and the host honored my request for a table vs. bar, seating the two of us at a 6 person table.

The enchiladas were good, the guac was super fresh, and my friend liked her chillaquiles (breakfast nachos).
author: Misha F.

description:
After trying to stop at another restaurant found on Yelp that appeared to not be open, we backtracked to Regalito and I believe made the better choice.  The goal was Mexican food with waiter service and this delivered. 

Ordering the shredded chicken in green chile sauce and pork shoulder, we had two very distinctive and different flavors. We started with the guacamole which was excellent and flavorful. The port shoulder was tasty, spiced well and relatively tender, but maybe could have been slightly more tender. The shredded chicken had a nice kick and flavor, but seemed to be a bit light on salt and spice and maybe a bit dry. 

Overall however the food was excellent, the service top notch and the eye candy in the kitchen (strawberry blond haired chef) was great.

Highly recommended, great place for couples or groups.
author: Jim H.

description:
It's not cheap and given the many good mexican spots in the mission it's hard rationalize why go to one that costs more? But for the good service, stylish atmosphere and mostly the fresh tasting food that didn't make me feel gross or sleepy afterward [normally, without fail, Mexican food always makes me feel that way] , it was worth the price.

Walked in off the street on a whim with my brother on the early side of the dinner hour. All tables full but the place still didn't feel crowded. We were politely asked if we had reservations. We didn't but were cheerfully offered the counter which as fun to sit and watch them make the food from scratch including the tortillas!

Service was quick, friendly and attentive. We both had the enchiladas verdes with rice and beans = yummy! 

Given that service, atmosphere and food hardly ever meet the standard that should be expected at a higher price, I give any restaurant that can meet 3 out of 3 criteria a 4-5. They didn't hit it out of the park but it's definitely on my list of places to go.
author: Anne O.

description: I am a big fan of Regalito, for both the food and the wonderful service. The staff is always super nice, whether you're a single diner ordering a sangria and chips at the counter bar, or a party of four doing it up. The brunch is a bit of a secret, but if you're a fan of huevos rancheros, you have to experience it. Tip: they don't charge the Healthy SF fee.
author: Marie F.

description:
Regalito = Small Gift, BIG BILL!!!

Usually when my family and I wander around SF, we screw up dinner. I don't mean that we pick the wrong place.  I mean we wait until it's too late (and by late I don't mean 10PM, I mean 6 or so - hey, with 2 kids we need to eat a bit early) to make any plans and then we struggle to find a place that a) looks appealing, b) doesn't cost a ton (this is SF after all), and c) isn't already packed.

So on this day we were wandering around the Mission, checking out the cool shops and letting time pass us by.  It was around 6 when we decided that we must eat.  We passed a few places by - too full of hipsters, too expensive...etc, when we stumbled upon Regalito.  The menu looked good, albeit a bit steep for uppity Mexican food, but we weren't going to let that deter us.  After all, we've learned that we should eat at the first place that seems decent or we could pay the consequences of our poor decision-making.

Regallito is a nice looking restaurant, with fairly modern, clean decor and only a handful of tables.  As I said before, the menu seemed to have some traditional Mexican dishes, but with a healthier, California twist.

We started with the Tortilla soup, which was honestly the best tortilla soup ever!
For the main, I chose the veggie Enchiladas stuffed with nopal (cactus).  Meh.  It took a while before I noticed the nopales, and even then there wasn't much flavor.  Price $18.  Ouch.

My wife ordered the Pollo Regalito which was tasty - well spiced with good sides.  Note that everything was jammed onto a smallish plate.  A bigger plate would have been a lot easier to eat from.  Price $17.  Ouch.

My son chose the Carne Asada.  Not a ton of carne for the price, but it was good quality and well-seasoned.  He liked it.  Price $22.  Holy crap!

There is a theme here.  Yes, we knew it was a bit pricey before we sat down.  But we also expected something extraordinary, not just a medium step up from the typical Mexican places found in the Mission.  Yes, the food was good, but not $70 for dinner good. I guess we paid for the good service, nice decor, and superior ingredients.

Next time we'll save some money and go to the nondescipt Mexican restaurants that serve similar dishes for half the price.  We can live without the service and decor.
author: Larry Z.

description:
I love really good Mexican food, so I enjoyed my meal at Regalito.  I easily got here by taking Muni and walking a few blocks to meet a friend for dinner.  Perfect SF restaurant - intimate atmosphere, friendly service, good food.  

Both my friend and I had the Enchiladas and they were wiling to mix it up a bit for us so we could each have a sampling of the Verdes and Rojas.  The Guacamole Con Tostadas appetizer was yummy.  There are so many great Mexican options in the Mission; I typically enjoy the more casual taquerias and would say this is a bit of a pricier upscale option, but still more than affordable.  Thomas made our night enjoyable by making us feel at home and preparing us some delicious food.  I would return.  I would agree with this statement from Regalito's website:  "REGALITO is the best place in San Francisco to eat authentic, hand made Mexican food for people who enjoy humanly and sustainably sourced food."
author: D B.

description:
One word:  mole!

I am a total newbie when it comes to mole, so my first dining experience I christened here, at Regalito Rosticeria, which serves gourmet Mexican cuisine.

We started with a round of appetizers:  guacamole, sopa de tortilla and ensalada nopalitos (sauteed cactus), served with crispy and soft corn tortillas.  Our stomachs were in for a treat of sweet, heat, textures and so much more.

Then we each had a dish but shared:  me:  pollo con mole negro (mole chicken with Spanish rice & pinto beans) and him:  savory pork shoulder.  The mole was savory and slightly sweet/spicy and I could taste hints of probably Mexican chocolate and the dozen of other ingredients and time it takes to make the sauce.

With so much food, we had some leftovers which we definitely took home.  Our kind and pretty knowledgeable waiter made some good wine recommendations; he was generous and added more rice and beans for our to go menus.  That's great service.

Although I'm interested in making mole, think it'd just be easier to come back and dine here again.
author: Jen L.

description: Blend. Tasteless. The "chef" is like... 17 yo. This place is a hoax.
author: Hilla B.

description: Regalito has the best Mexican food outside of Mexico! The food is fresh and delicious! The people at friendly! My husband, mother and I loved the tacos and guacamole! It was amazing! They serve homemade fresh tortillas made to order and the meat is cooked to perfection! I am definitely coming back soon for some more!!
author: Ninii M.

description: Just attended a going-away party here for a dear friend, and the staff here took great care of us and dulled the pain of the day. There's a covered outdoor area, with a large table that seats about 16 or 20. There are also overhead heaters. We ate, we drank sangria...repeat repeat repeat. I'm really into sangria, and I loved this one. The guacamole here is also excellent.
author: Karen Z.

description:
OK, but by no means great.

Ambiance: 3 stars. Making the best of a drab space, but far from beautiful. The cover over the patio tints all the food red, which I found unappetizing.

Food: 3 stars, but very uneven. The tortillas are some of the best I've ever had, no exaggeration. The salsas were also quite good (and spicy!). But the entrees were bland and had some problems with texture: the beans were too hard, while the roasted chicken was too dry and lacked crunch.

Value: 2 stars. You can get far better roasted chicken for cheaper from Roli Roti. And as for better Mexican food, just look around you.

Service: 4 stars. Friendly and attentive. The place was pretty empty, though, so it wasn't the best test.
author: Mike B.

description:
Looove! My favorite part is how whimsical it is inside. It's small, comfortable, and above your average mexican establishment.

My friend and I enjoyed a carafe of sangria (don't judge), which tasted like purple stuff. We shared enchiladas, carnitas, and a humongous heaping of guacamole.

A very successful night indeed.
author: Annie L.

description:
On a Groupon I made a reservation for Tuesday night. This restaurant has a pre-fixed menu option per person  (or to share) for $28. You get to order one appetizer, one entree, and one dessert. You can mix and match options on the menu. We ordered Margarita wine with dinner. For the most part, the restaurant lived up to my expectations. The food was good with a new artistic twist. Portions are big enough to share. You get your money's worth, but not for families. This is nice for a girl night out or a dinner date.  

Since the restaurant is small I recommend making reservations online to avoid a long wait or get turned away. No phone reservations accepted. Parking is hard in the area. Max number of groups 4 ( to be comfortable).
author: Ana S.

description: Regalito offers a slightly more upscale version of a sit-down Mexican dinner -- with California touches, like the Tuesday all-pork "Pigalito" menu. Their food isn't super fancy, but it's good comfort food with freshly made tortillas, generous portions, and their house-made spicy habanero sauce if you want to liven up your meal. Their pozole is especially excellent, and I'm fond of their soju bloody marys. (I know, but it really works.) Their Mexican hot chocolate for dessert is also a nice touch at the end of a meal.
author: Beth W.

description: My girlfriend and i got a groupon to go here. $30 for app. 2 entrees and dessert. The seating has great potential but for now is really weird. They have this in door/out door area that would be great if they provided individual seating, however they have this one large table they sit everyone. We wanted a nice night out together and this made it a little awkward. I really wanted to like this place because it's really cute and stuff inside, but in all honesty the food was just meh. If we payed full price here, our bill would have been $80, an amount not worth it. Maybe come in for a drink or two and an app, but that's about it.
author: Tyler L.

description: Great restaurant for authentic Mexican food!  The chicharrones are amazona!  The tortillas are The best in San Francisco.  The prices are in par with other restaurants.  It's  not cheap because it's a restaurant in San Francisco.  If you want cheap Mexican food then go to the taqueria down the street where you will find food under heat lamps and you have to sit in a dinner type of environment.
author: Jaime O.

description:
I'd been dying to try this place after rave recommendations from friends, so it pains me a little that I actually really didn't like it.

Full disclosure: I was here the night before an apparent groupon for this place was expiring, so I'm sure my experience was tainted a bit. Especially since I didn't have one of these said groupons.

The wait was ridiculous - about an hour on a Wednesday night. I'm down with waiting that long for restaurants that actually deserve to have an hour plus wait on a Wednesday, but this place certainly doesn't.

Once seated, it was another 20 minutes for the menus. Then another 20 minutes to order. And then about 40 until the meals came out.

I would have forgiven (most) everything up until then, except the food was super mediocre at best. 

Cochinita pibil ($17) - I've definitely made tastier versions at home, and I'm no expert in this dish. Theirs was a sad, bland pile of fairly unseasoned little piggy meat.

Chicken enchiladas verde ($17) - Eek. There was absolutely no spice goin' on in this plate. Really the only flavor I could taste was the ocean of cream my poor enchiladas were trying to stay afloat in. I seriously ate 1/2 a jar of their salsa with about 3/4 of an enchilada in order to spice it up a bit. Took the rest home, and they went moldy cause I felt no compelling urge to eat them.

Their guacamole ($7.50) was decent. But shouldn't every Mexican restaurant be able to make decent guac?

You've saddened me, Regalito. I will not be returning.
author: Monica C.

description:
My friend and I go to brunch almost every Sunday, and this was our first time eating here.  The staff was very friendly and they suggested we try Tamarindo juice with our Mimosa instead of Orange juice.  He let us try it before we ordered it and it was so delicious.  My friend is from Mexico, and he  says the food is authentic , and I have to say the food was really good.  
The atmosphere is clean, comfortable, with really warm colors.   The service great, food is great, and hey what else can you ask for brunch?
author: Fefe F.

description:
After a wildly hectic day of moving and walking up and down Valencia looking for dinner, I was starving. We stumbled upon this place by accident and oncewe were seated it only took two minutes to realize this was exactly what we wanted. 
We ordered the guac to start and it was outstanding. Tortilla were fresh and warm. I ordered the pork and was blown away with the textures and the mole. My partner ordered the mole chicken dish and it was out of this world. The drinks were reasonably priced and the decor added a nice touch. Overall,it was delightfully different than the not so hot Latin food in Massachusetts.
author: Annie Zean D.

description: I wasted all my time here last night. My family came over to visit and we decided to go give it a try. We were a party of 5. They sat us outside even though it was chilly, it could have been because we didn't have a reservation. So they promptly take our order, and when my mother asks the waitress how long the food will take she says 15 mins. 15 mins go by. 25 mins go by. 45 mins go by and nothing. The waitress did not walk near us for 45 mins even to apologize for the delay or bring our drinks. So finally she walks over with some food and says she will be right back with the rest. 25 mins go by and half the table don't have their food. Since we are outside our food is getting real cold so we dig in even though my parents are starving. Half way through the meal we notice that the chicken is raw in the middle! When she finally comes over, my parents tell her that they no longer want the food and she takes the chicken back as well. Bringing the check and charging me becomes a delay. This place is overpriced for tiny uncooked portions. I don't recommend. Waste of our time.
author: Cindy P.

description:
I won't give this place 1 star out of respect, but we walked in last night for dinner and walked out without eating a thing.

My dessert/drink menu had some nasty old food spilled on it...just throw it away please.  It's just a piece of paper.  

The main chef (I think) kept staring at us and totally creeped me out.  Kind of like he wanted us to order so he could get the hell out of there.  Plus, he picked up a bowl of guac (or something similar) and start eating it right out of the mixing bowl with chips.  Ummm...it's an open kitchen, if you are going to eat, please hide it from the customers.  I pretty much lost my appetite after that and didn't want him anywhere near my food.  

We had already ordered drinks, so finished them quickly, paid the check, and sadly won't be coming back.  

Menu did look good and I was totally going to order the pork shoulder, but...you need a new chef.
author: Ayrn H.

description:
I REALLY liked Regalito. My dear friend took me out in the Mission for a early birthday dinner and we decided to wing it.  We went to the 4 spots that were on our mental list and were told the wait was 1.5 hours at all of them.  We proceeded to hit up other places we could think of, and encountered the same issue.  Usually, as a deuce, you can sneak in reasonably quick, but not this Saturday night. We literally tried to get into 7-8 places before noticing Regalito. Admittedly a bit desperate, we decided to give it a whirl. We were able to get seated right away, which could be a red flag, but I took note of their awards on the door before going in, and was comforted by their presence.  Regalito lived up to the awards and then some.  

It's a nice little "up-scale" Mexico spot, but reasonably priced.  The guac was to die for and our server was excellent and extremely pleasant. We ordered the Tempranillo, which was lovely - beautiful color, and soft in its tannins. 

We ordered the following as a starter: 
* Elote - Grilled corn on the cob, cotija cheese, house-made mayonnaise, lime, and chile powder.

It was amazing. Flat out amazing and so simple!  As I understand, it's a typical Mexican dish. Corn any other way will always be lacking after this.  Cheese and corn is brilliant!

My entree:  Tinga De Pollo - Shredded free-range chicken in chipotle sauce, served with rice and avocado salsa.

A little heavy on the onions, but still quite tasty.

My friend's entree:  Carne con Chile Colorado - Beef stewed in a spicy sauce of chile de arbol, roasted tomatoes, garlic, and caramelized onions. Served with rice and refritos. 

She loved it!  

We ended with some birthday churros.  YUM!

I will definitely be back and I am spreading the word.
author: Steph P.

description: The service is terrific here and the staff and owners very pleasant. I've been back on and off over the past 3 years and noticed this last time that they've undergone a nice renovation, opening up a new lovely back room. Overall decor is bright and cheerful, and the restaurant is very clean, refreshing counterpoint to the dingy "naked bulb lit" burrito joints that line the streets of the MIssion... Organic/fresh/sustainable ingredients in very tasty food. Portions are not huge, but plenty filling. The giant round tortilla chips that came with the excellent guacamole seemed handmade to us, unlike the claim of another review -- regardless they were just the right foil to a tangy guac and I enjoyed them (and I'm a foodie). Mole is excellent, as is the steak, and pork. Have not tried any of the veggie options...A wee bit pricey.
author: Kate A.

description:
Since posting my review for this restaurant, I've gone back for more! I fall more and more in love with this place every single time.

Everything on the menu is amazing, but the cochinita pibil still holds the top spot! I love the sangria. As for desserts, they're all delicious, but you'll have the bread pudding if you know what's good for you! ;)
author: MJ T.

description:
Pros
+ taquitos and the guacamole 
+ friendly service
+ clean and modern interior

Cons
- enchilada w red sauce was super boring. Nothing inside, literally just tortilla w sauce and a little cheese sprinkled on top
- no refill on lemonade

I give it 3.5 stars and will return to try some other plates
author: Captain B.

description: Overpriced for such non-creative dishes. Pretty much standard Mexican fare for $20/plate. Service was mediocre. Nice garden thing was the primary redeeming factor. Won't be back.
author: Scott S.

description: Great food, great value great service. The long community table and heated outdoor patio set a really nice backdrop for our outdoor dinner on a Beautiful night. Seems it would be ideal for a big group party or birthday. Definitely coming back! The guac and rotisserie chicken were both stand outs.
author: Jeremie H.

description:
We came here on a Tuesday night which is a special menu days called "Pigalito"  and am I glad we happened in that day.

Got one of those groupon/lving social deal things to eat a 3 course meal here with wine for 2. I always wonder about the places that have to offer these deals and assume that they are little better than average, so I went into it with no significant expectations.  We came on a Tuesday night and could only get 5:30 reservations.  It's cute inside but small.  Think neighborhood taqueria given a decent makeover.  They serve wine and beer, but no hard stuff.  

The Good:  Every bit of food and salsa served to us.  I'm serious.  I thought for sure I wasn't going to be impressed, but they really surprised me. The taquitos and empanadas on the appy menu were off the hook.  Fried perfectly, meat flavorful and moist, perfect garnishing of queso fresco and crema along with a very good pico de gallo.  Then you have the habanero salsa they provide to the table.  A great balance of heat and flavor that doesn't overpower the food if accompanies.  Emapanandas were flaky and the filling meaty and moist.  Also a home run.  
Main courses were the Enchiladas rojas and the Chile verde.  The enchilada sauce they used had a great smoky chile flavor and they tried to do justice to the mushroom and swiss chard filling.  I would have liked a little more flavor in the filling, but the enchilada sauce helped.  The chile verde - oh. my. god. - perfectly cooked nopales (cactus for all who don't habla) add a great citrusy note and slightly crunchy textural counterbalance to the most succulent hunks of pork in a great sauce.  The rice was given the stamp of approval from my dining companion who measures all Mexican restaurants by the quality of their rice. The servers were very nice, helpful, and attentive without being intrusive. 
Desert was the Arroz con leche (mexican rice pudding) that my companion said had the subtle cinnamon and bay flavors her Mom managed to get into her cooking.  I had the homemade churros with mexican chocolate.  Churros were incredible.  Crispy on the outside and still just slightly doughy on the inside. Prior to that cup of chocolate, I have always had a negative opinion of mexican hot chocolate as grainy and watery - the cinnamon notes are nice, but i've never been that impressed.  This changed my mind.  Rich, smooth, some spice notes and great chocolate flavor.  Damn.  The wine list here may not be expansive and may not win a Wine Spectator, but they did a nice job of picking mostly South Ameican wines with good flavor at reasonable price points.  

The Bad: I dunno... parking?  

The Mediocre:  The enchiladas themselves were just OK for me, but the dish was helped greatly by the enchilada sauce.  After tasting the chile verde I don;t see myself ordering the enchiladas again.  Hey, at least they offer a vegetarian option.

Overall:  Two enthusiastic thumbs up. The next time I come here I am eating my way through the appetizer menu and then going straight to dessert. YUM!
author: John G.

description: this place has a nice romantic atmosphere and delicious food.  They are known for their pork dishes.  The taquitos were my favorite thing we ordered.  I could have eaten 20 of them!   The churro dessert was not impressive at all.  I wish we got the flan.
author: Julie B.

description:
Love it! 

Usually when I review a Mexican restaurant, I end up going off on some rant about how much better the food is in SD. I should clarify that this goes for taco shop Mexican fare only. Aside from Mariscos, I have been unimpressed with SD's selection of sit-down and regional Mexican cuisine. Although I recently lived in Mar Vista, LA where every Mexican restaurant happens to be Oaxacan and specialize in mole, Regalito does a much better job. 

I probably don't need to credentialize myself by noting that I have been to Oaxaca or recounting my numerous encounters with different types of moles. I will say though that this place does it right. I came in with the wifey and a couple of friends last night for dinner and had to have the mole. They had some pork mole enchiladas, but I had envisioned a half of a chicken smothered in the rich, delicious sauce. The waiter said that he could have the chef do the mole with chicken enchiladas, shredded chicken, or the roasted chicken. Score! Although they initially gave me just the breast, they added in the thigh, competing the half chicken promptly upon request and without questions. I love how flexible and accommodating they were about this. It really shows that they care about their customers. 

As for the mole itself, amazing! I tore it up. A friend ordered the chicken enchiladas with mole for her first mole experience and had to save the last one to bring home for her husband to try. She was really impressed about how flavorful the sauce was while not sweet or excessively spicy. We also got the guac, which is a bit pricey at $10, but it is huge. The four of us did not finish it. It is also made very fresh and is delicious. 

The wifey got the cochinita pibil, which she thought was a miss. I think I have had better versions, but enjoyed the flavors. The pork may have been a bit dry. Our other friend devoured her enchiladas verdes and reported that they were excellent. 

We had a Bloomspot coupon for this one, which helped with the price. Regardless though, this is a nice place to come and have a satisfying meal. I don't mind paying more money if the food is going to be this good. I have been here once before and tried the tortilla soup, which was amazing. Unfortunately, they did not have it this time. I have to make it in some time for the pozole and really want to make it to this Pigalito thing too. Check this place out, it is the bomb!
author: Miguel V.

description: This was one of the worst restaurants I have even been to. "Tacos" are crazy small, they can't even serve you a side of guacamole because "We don't serve it like that", a side of beans and rice are split on a infant size bowl (literally). Waste of money.  I can understand that they wanted a new take on Mexican food, but at least do it well.  I will NEVER come back!!! If people like this, they clearly have bad taste in "Latin food".
author: Randy G.

description: Outstanding decor, service and, best of all, food. Visiting from New Jersey, a friend introduced us. When he said Mexican, I winced, but went trusting his taste. What a pleasant surprise. No cliche's. Sleek modern decor, great menu, and attentive helpful waitstaff.  We sat at the communal table, and as the sun went down, the tropical foliage lit up. I had the enchiladas with salsa verde, my wife had the roast chicken, and our friend had the roast pork with pickled onions. All wonderful. The leftover chicken went all the way home to NJ and was lunch the next day. Yum.
author: Donald P.

description:
I think I may have waited too long to come back. I didn't write a review the first time around, so I think the stars have gone down.

I had a Groupon worth $35. In retrospect that's a good deal because the bill came out to $48ish, leaving us only $13 + tip to pay. Not bad.

That being said, eating here the second time was not worth buy a  Groupon for. I had been looking forward to their tortilla soup. The menu had changed completely and focused mainly on pork (Pigalito). Other than that, the waiter explained 2 specials to us for the night: chicken enchiladas and a vegetarian alternative. No soup.

The chicken enchiladas were great, nice portion, 3 enchiladas covered in cheese, sauce, and stuffed with flavorful juicy chicken. The guacamole serving as an appetizer was great, a nice change to the regular chips and salsa.

Pair that with a nice glass of Malbec (because their delicious margarita was NOT on the menu either).
author: Alyssa G.

description:
Badges? They don't wear no steenking badges here, senor!

But if you've ever been to Oaxaca, you know there is a whole other side of Mexico that has nothing to do with sombreros, mariachi bands and those plastic dogs that have the heads that go up and down on your dashboard when you go low riding in the barrios. In fact, Regalito is exactly the type of clean, modern-looking place you'd find along a side street in Mexico's culinary capital.

Make no mistake that in a neighborhood full of great south-of-the-border eateries, this one stands out for the fresh ingredients they use in some interesting variations on basic Mexican dishes. Standing out in its own building on 18th Street between Valencia and Lexington, the small, tidy place inside has a warm vibe with a bright chartreuse hue on the walls and stainless steel and beech wood on the lengthy counter.

I ordered the $12.50 Pollo Con Mole Negro, which is a quarter-chicken, free-range of course, covered in a thick Oaxacan mole full of chiles, nuts, and spices. It came with stewed pinto beans and rice. Tasty and the breast-dominated chicken was cooked to the right tenderness. My friend had the simpler $9.50 Pollo Regalito, which is the leg and thigh of a chicken marinaded in garlic, lime and chiles. It also came with the beans and rice.

Barely three months old, they also offer pork, steak and veggie dishes which I look forward to trying some other time. There are also a bevy of appetizers and side dishes of which we just ordered the $3 Salsa Fresca y Tostadas, a bowl of incredibly fresh tomato, onion and chile salsa with deep-dried tortilla rounds you need to break apart to scoop up the salsa.  Yummy and just enough of a teaser for the entree.

They even offer a $9.95 "Mexican worker's lunch" consisting of agua fresca, a chosen entree (today it was a pork dish), dessert or coffee. Sounds like a pretty good deal to me. The staff is friendly and incredibly quiet though not in a dysfunctional way since I am making the grand presumption that it is a family-run place.

Keep in mind that it is small (just three tables and the counter), so I imagine weekend waits are a given. Even though you can have dessert here, just walk up 18th two blocks to get your scoop of salted caramel at the Bi-Rite Creamery.

FOOD - 4 stars...fresh tasting...you feel you've made the healthier choice in the Mission
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...clean, contemporary and no sombreros, serapes or velvet paintings of orphans on burros
SERVICE - 4 stars...very accommodating but no worries, they don't hover
TOTAL - 4 stars...has potential to earn another star if they get more daring on the dishes but fine and dandy for what it is
author: Ed U.

description:
I like this place!  I tried this restaurant on a Monday evening and my 3 friends and I dined al fresco on the patio in back.  Since there were four of us we were able to sample a good portion of their menu. 

We started out with the soup of the day .. a creamy sweet corn soup.   It was tasty.  The soup tasted as if it were made with real cream and it was a white creamy soup.   It was rather rich  and perhaps a tad too sweet for my taste but not sugary.  It tasted vaguely like cream of corn (only better) without all the lumpiness. 

For appetizers we order the taquitos de papas y queso and there were 4 taquitos so we each had one.   The taquitos were large  over an inch in diameter. They were served on a bed of cabbage salad and were topped with cream and salsa and a bit of the queso fresco. This dish was a hit for everyone and not a spec of food remained when the waiter cleared the dish.

For the main dish I had the Chile Relleno with a side of Elote.  This dish was wonderful the vegetables meant it was a "mild" dish but they had salsa and hot sauce on the table for me to spice it up. (I tend to like a bit of spice or a lot of spice).  The vegetables were cooked perfectly and was a nice change from the cheese filled rellenos you get at other places.  The Elote was charred perfectly and tasted delicious.  I could have used a bit more spice on this one, but I'm not complaining.

One friend had the Enchiladas Rojas and it was served with 3 tortillas loosely rolled and filled with veggies.   It was another delicious dish but a bit more filling than the Chile Relleno.    Someone else had a side of brussel sprouts.  The brussel sprouts were cut in half and sauteed or baked.  They looked delicious. 

Warm corn tortillas were served with dinner, I am not quite sure if they were made on the premises or purchased from a tortilla vendor, but they were fresh and tasty. 

We also had a few of the juices  (non-alcoholic) and a Soju bloody Mary and a bottled beer (no beers on tap).   The Soju Bloody Mary was a bit watery and seemed rather weak (perhaps because it was soju).  I don't know if it was just our bartender, but it really looked more like a strawberry aqua fresca that was watered down.    I'm not a fan of Soju so I didn't try it. 

I would definitely try this place again.  Tha patio on a sunny day is an excellent spot to enjoy a meal.
author: Cat C.

description:
Regalito is a pretty little restaurant, and a great mid-week late lunch spot if you're in the neighborhood. It's tiny, so avoid "rush hour".

The staff is charming and graciously allowed me to order something that wasn't exactly on the menu. The wi-fi was free, though I'm not so sure that was on purpose. Shhhh. 

My lunch (taquitos) was really tasty and beautifully presented and I only felt mildly guilty for not going to a taqueria and stuffing a cheap taco down my pie hole. 

They play good music here too...I was treated to lots of Nina Simone. RIP Nina,  and thanks for a lovely lunch.
author: Gwynnie P.

description: Every time I come here after teaching it is a treat! The best service, every dish (and I've tried to have a different one each time) is so beautifully done! Wonderful food and environment to visit.
author: Zara H.

description: Best Mole I've ever had! I serious have been having dreams about it since. yumm! Everything we ordered was delicious and the service was fantastic. Great lighting and ambiance. Perfect date night spot. Casual and intimate. I highly recommend checking it out on a weeknight to avoid a wait and a more leisure experience.
author: Vanessa G.

description: Mexican Fusion, because beans and rice instead kale and brussel sprouts. I wish they had a plate just of kale because it was great. The chicken the first time around was under cooked, I asked for it to be cooked more. They made me a fresh batch and got it right the second time minus one star.  The chicken was good how ever not very exotic. I thought it would be because it is called regalito chicken.  Our waiter was very attentive. They should have a regalito carnitas dish instead. The meat was very good quality. They serve the carnitas with brussels sprouts very tasty. This place is good date that you want it to last because they do take a while. The food is nice and hot. Good tortillas and churros. Not super cheap, not ultra expensive. A good twist on Mexican food.
author: Carolyne R.

description:
Tasty Mexican food with handmade tortillas.  We had the slow-roasted pork and enchiladas verdes, and both were delicious.  

The place is quite small and very busy, and of course, being in the Mission, full of annoying foodies whining about their reservations; so don't come in expecting great ambiance or service.  Also, on a weird note, the wine tasted like brandy and water, so maybe stick with beer.

But overall, a good experience and worth checking out.  

If you don't have a reservation, you can always try your luck at scoring a counter seat with a view of the kitchen.  It's fun to watch them make the tortillas.
author: Nina L.

description: Everything there is cooked absolutely to perfection. Beautiful presentation, super high quality ingredients (and you can taste it), never eaten a dish there that wasn't incredibly good. The roasted chicken, of course, is impeccable. Oh, the veggies, though not listed on the menu are insanely delicious - ask for a side. And desserts ... dude! I'm a flan-lover, so... I've gone there with a date and I've gone their with my child - suitable for both without diminishing the experience for either. The waitstaff are super pleasant and the environment is really comfortable and lovely (the garden outside is like a mini-enchanted forest) and yet somehow casual - like if you could take everything you like about San Francisco, get rid of the rest and whip it into a restaurant - then you've got this place.
author: Heather I.

description:
I ended up visiting this place twice because I accidentally bought 2 groupons, long story.  Both times I was not "wow'd" nor "satisfied" for that matter.  The first time was with a large group and we started with a pitcher of Sangria.  It tasted good but lacked alcohol, a very important requirement for my sangria.  Tasted like more fruit juice than anything which would have been fine but they are super expensive.  We had some appetizers to share and I had half roasted chicken.  Apps were good but the chicken was boring.  Just tasted like a simple baked chicken.

The second visit was more of a date night.  Glass of wine and some sausage type apps to start.  To tell you the truth I didn't even know what I had for dinner it was that forgettable.  The food is clean and simple, but that doesn't mean it has to be bland.  2-stars is "Meh. I've experienced better."  and that is exactly how I feel.  Not much flavor and defiantly over priced.
author: Louis C.

description:
Incredible Mexican Food!

My husband is Mexican and ever since we moved here from So Cal we have been searching for great spots to get some truly great Mexican food. This place is the real deal. The sauces are slow cooked, the meats are braised over long hours, the tortilla is fresh made. It is amazing. 

Ps: if you like Mole, they won a award for best Mole in the city. Must try!
author: Mia N.

description:
The good: delicious handmade tortillas, guacamole, carnitas, beans, and rice. Also, great service!

The bad: not enough seating. Place is very small with NO place to wait inside

The ugly: please don't tell me the wait time is 20 minutes and then seat me 60 minutes later. I would have given this place 5 stars if they would have just been honest about the wait time.
author: Elise R.

description:
Food was OK (thus the one star)
Coffee tasted like boiled socks.
The "regalito"? A baby cockroach crawling from under a plate on our table.
Never again!
author: Rebeca R.

description:
Food still remains to be their strong focal point, but this time around my service was somewhat short of the norm. With only 3 other active tables in the restaurant, my book club showed up with 6 girls since Limon was closed for remodeling. 

They asked us if we had a reservation, which obviously last minute change was a no, so they began trying to squish an impossible dinner seating together on the bar side of the room. 10 minutes later, the guy gets on the phone and we're still not seated...turns out their reservation cancelled, so we were able to have the table by the front entrance we originally were wondering why they hadn't put us in. Table rocked, so we shoved a napkin under. Another 10 minutes goes by and sure enough, we finally get water. 

Everything went pretty slow from there. Granted, roasted Elote does take some time, but it shouldn't take more than 5 minutes to get our beverages to us when the restaurant is dead. I also think our waitress didn't like our jokes about how we wanted our drinks "right away then" since when we requested the corn be delivered as an appetizer and they couldn't do it (since it takes so long to cook, she said they'd probably end up being with the entrees). We were just trying to be light hearted! 

Oh well, needless to say, she did make sure our orders came out exactly as we requested and we had no issues with the food. I went with the Roja sauce instead of Verdes for my enchiladas, which is always touch and go for me....still good, I added chicken, but I know now I prefer the Verdes there. 

I guess I just still feel that with a huge table and an empty restaurant, there should have been more umph going on! That being said, I'll still come back.
author: Alita M.

description:
Well, glad we used a "Groupon."

I have walked by this place millions of times and always wanted to go in and try their food, but everywhere else always seemed better. The prices seemed steep and I was suspicious about the authenticity of a place that is Mexican, yet has no trace of it from the outside.

Anyway, the hand-made tortillas and the guacamole, which were delicious simply do not attribute to the service.

It was lunch hour. No one bothered to seat us until a few minutes later. The menu was given and the host disappeared. She was the only one actually, physically, emotionally working. Everyone else, the cooks, and everyone were in a bubble. Doing their jobs and exclusively their jobs. She then comes and takes the other but it took forever to get the coffee, took forever to get our nopales salad (which was good, but not authentic). Another thing, we ordered a Coca Cola, and they brought me a can of Coke. I even said "Coca." Not what was on the menu.

My pozole would have been perfect and almost worth the wait, if I had had the chance of swapping pork with chicken. What is it with these "cuisines" that replace all kinds of ingredients. I guess I should cook things my way and until then shut up, but seriously.

And well, let me tell you that while we ate, people were coming in, staring at our food, and they didn't get seated either, until we finished our salad. That's a long wait. Fairly busy place, but the pace is super slow and well, I'm not coming back. Wasn't super impressed and waiting for nothing special is not my thing.
author: Alexia R.

description:
I can't say I hate it or love it. Another trip might be in order so that I can make a more concrete verdict, but until then I'm sticking with the 3 stars.

Even though I made reservations, it appeared rather easy to be seated during prime dinner hours mid-week as there were scattered empty tables. Not sure how the weekends play out. The staff was very friendly and always approached our table with a smile. Pork was the main feature of the rather meager menu options, however, the waiter was quick to point out the other non-pork items that didn't make the cut on the menu that evening.

The highlights of the meal were the guacamole and the carnitas. A lot of restaurants like to skimp on the guacamole--not Regalito. The surplus of guacamole helped accompany several of my meals the next day. As for the carnitas, the generous portion had a good blend of both succulent, juicy shredded pork and fattier chunks that will make your cholesterol jump a notch or two. Served with delicious rice & beans and a fresh salsa medley, the savory blend was quite enjoyable.

On the flip side, the chicken enchiladas were rather disappointing. They were somewhat bitter and the overall flavor failed to land an impressionable punch. 

A small, but noteworthy point, I took notice to how they packed up the leftovers. Most places put all remaining items in a box where it eventually ends up tossing and turning into a giant mess. With each item having its own small box the different items maintained their proper flavor. This notion of "separate but equal" for leftovers is the only way to go (sorry Dr. King!).
