I really appreciated that they packed my leftovers so I could have a great lunch the next day. They gave us extra tortillas and made sure we were taken care of the entire time. Very nice place in an easy location.
author: Nicole S.

description:
Regalito Rosticeria is a very clean and chic little Mexican restaurant, maybe TOO clean and chic for me. Everything was fresh and simple but it was not at all flavorful or satisfying. Where was the cheese? Free salsa and chips? Even Chevy's gives that out! AND $7 for guacamole is just ridiculous!!!

A Pollo Regalito - 1/2 Roast free-range chicken, choice of lime or chile garlic marinade served with sautéed greens. Mmm. I honestly didn't even think this was Mexican. It was good enough but in the end, it was juct chicken! 

Cochinita Pibil - Slow roasted, banana leaf wrapped, Citrus & achiote marinated pork with onions, cilantro and black beans. First it wasn't banana leaf wrapped. The leaves were just at the bottom. What was their purpose? It just looked like decoration. And this dish was basically a pile of shredded pork. The black beans were very good and I'm glad it came with tortillas. But still, sometimes less is NOT more. 

Random thought: After I've seen it at several places. I'm now sure that cucumber (in water) is the new lemon! I'm totally feeling this trend. Sometimes lemon water reminds me of dish soap. But I still drink it.
author: Julia T.

description:
First impression: Really bright and upbeat decor... loved the small, open kitchen. We sat at the bar where we could see everything happening in the kitchen and I was mesmerized by the efficiency of the inner workings of this kitchen. 

We ordered this delicious appetizer of a spinach tortilla topped with fresh cheese, cabbage, and salsa. Entrees were enchiladas verdes and seasoned pork ribs. Both were good but boy does this place love cheese and crema on everything. I asked for both on the side for my enchiladas and they were happy to do so, which was nice. Dessert was Mexican vanilla gelato... saw them scoop it from a container (no not made in house) and it was alright. 

Overall, the service was really great and the food was delicious!
author: Aurora S.

description:
My BFF wanted to try Regalito for the 10th anniversary of his 29th Bday.  Being a good friend (enough to recall that it was probably the 13th anniversay but kind enough to not call him on it), I was more than happy to oblige.  

We started out with the Chorizo con pappas.  With all the hoopla on Yelp, I expected crisp potatoes and spicy chorizo but that wasn't the case.  The potatos were mushy and the chorizo needed a heavy dose of habanero salsa.  Frankly, I could have made this at  home and topped it with some eggs for breakfast. 

Next up were the Nopales.  Now, BFF loves nopales and they were great bundled in the fresh homemade tortillas.  I wanted to try the chilindrinas - blue masa fried up and topped with a mound of queso fresco and I was not disappointed.  I loved the richness of the masa and the lightness of the queso together. 

We shared the chicken mole and rice.  I enjoyed the sauce but found a the chicken a bit dry as compared to Tropisueno (which also includes a side of beans).
author: Monica L.

description:
There are a lot of great places to get Mexican food in the city. Burrito joints, taco trucks, cantinas and carts. Especially in the Mission, so it's hard to stand out. Regalito's does a good job of doing just that. It's traditional Mexican food done up all fancy like. Definitely a different experience than what you normally get from the Mission. 

The meat is perfectly cooked and all the spices are well balanced, flavorful, with a little kick. The vegetables are fresh, the chips are crispy and the sangria is sweet. 

The downfall is the price. It's worth it for the quantity and quality, but for much less you can get equally as good a meal from one of the other fine Mexican food establishments in the city. This makes it a special occasion destination. A place you visit once in a while. Which is fine, it's good to have a restaurant you keep in your back pocket for times when you have a little extra money.
author: Spencer C.

description:
My wife and I are vegetarian and although there aren't many options, the food itself is very good. Our friends, who eat meat, also loved their food. In addition, the service was excellent. Even though we used a Groupon, our waiter was very attentive and accommodating. He offered to check on a second vegetarian option, which we got, and gave us fresh-made tortillas, which were excellent. 

As appetizers, we had the corn and potato taquitos, both of which were very good. As entrees we had the vegetarian enchiladas and chile relleno and our friends had the chicken and pork. For dessert, we both had the churros with hot chocolate and the hot chocolate was delectable. 

All in all, it was a very good night. We'll definitely go back.
author: S S.

description:
Hi, I live in the Mission.  The Mission, aside from being known for the pretentious hipsters who make the neighborhood their home (something I mock yet secretly wish to become), is also known for good Mexican food.  Sure, it's a bit pricy, but at the very least, it's good.  Unfortunately, Regalito Rosticeria... is still pricy but not so good.  

We came in on a Tuesday night at around 8pm, and fortunately, got seating with no problem.  The decor is nice modern European style, and we enjoyed sitting at the counter and watching the staff bustle to prepare the food.  Unfortunately, for the food we ordered there wasn't much preparing.  I got the Pollo Con Mole Negro.  This was prepared by taking a piece of chicken out of a container that was keeping chicken warm and putting sauce on it from a vat.  Ian H ordered the cochinita pibil.  The preparation of his dish involved taking the pork out of a container, putting it on top of some black beans, sprinkling a bit of greens on top of that, and handing it all over to us.  

So yeah, fast, but at the expense of everything being already premade.  Now, for my dish, the chicken was pretty dry and quite bland by itself (especially compared to say the nearby Limon).  But the sauce was quite tasty.  Ian's dish was pork and beans.  Seriously, that was it.  The pork was kind of tastless and the beans were beans.  It's like that Weezer song, only, the Weezer song sounded better than the dish tasted.  Oh, did I mention this ended up costing us 20+/p for just those small dishes?  Conclusion - 2.5 stars (mostly for the nice decor) - Not worth it!  Go to Limon instead.
author: Leon K.

description: Amazing mole negro that won best mole in SF last 3 years
author: Eric K.

description: We used a Groupon for a 3 course meal. We had the taquitos with potatoes and cheese for shared appetizer, pollo regalito with sautéed greens and carne asada for entrees, and churros and hot chocolate for the big finale. Had a carafe of margaritas to go with the meal. Everything was delicious and service was great. Ambience is nice too. The hubby and I had a nice date night. They have a cool back room with garden view perfect for a private party, like my next bday!
author: Amalia C.

description:
Perfect pork! Perfect. 
Salsa packs a punch, then kisses you after wards.
Awesome service.
Yums and Wows
author: Juan Carlos R.

description:
Wow!!

What a treat!! Went here on a Wednesday night... the restaurant was about 75% full and the ambiance was great. 

The place looks amazing! What a great job they've done. 

The food.. finger-licking good. From the homemade tortilla, to the amazing starters, to the main course. OMG. YUM!

Only bad thing? Sangria tasted like Kool-Aid. Too bad they don't serve cocktails. 

Started with potatoes which were so freaking good.. what a great starter. Then had the green chile enchilada.. delish. After the poor sangria, I had a glass of Malbec which was fantastic.

I'll be back.. and back again. :)
author: Art A.

description: Tried it for the first time and loved it. Will definitely go back. We tried the carnitas, enchilada, and chili Coronado. All of the dishes were delicious. And the service was wonderful.
author: Cynthia L.

description: Yum! Bought a google offer for 2 entrees and 1 app. The food was really great and our waitress was a darling. The only reason why I can think this mission restaurant with a primo location is a bit dead (as it was on a Thursday night) is the cost. It's a bit pricey for what you get, and there's just so many other options in the area. I will definitely try to come back, but because of the menu prices this may be a "special occasion" type visit vs. regular haunt.
author: Violet C.

description:
From the bland dry chicken to the inattentive service to the guacamole we ordered but never received, Regalito was a disappointment.  

The verde sauce on my enchiladas has some nice spiciness to it and I enjoyed the papas with chorizo (thus the two stars). And my friend enjoyed her soup.  But it simply wasn't enough to make up for the dreadful service and the other mediocre dishes.  

Save your money (the meal for four of us was $80 before tip) and get a delicious burrito at dozens of other places in the Mission.
author: Todd X.

description:
I'm not sure what to say, so I'll just sumarize our experience. 

We were sat next to a party of six, two adults, and four screaming children. So, you'll know just what kind of experience it's going to be... Awful!

For starters, we shared the guaculmole dip and tostitos. They were deliciuos. Next, I had the carnitas which were over cook and hard. I should of complain but Im not like that at all. So hungry, who cares if it was a bit hard. My two friends has the sea bass, which she said was a bit bland and the pollo was just perfect from what I could tell. The sangria and agaveargaritas were good, very light and refreshing. 

I don't know if I reccomend this place to my friends or come back. I wasn't too thrilled about the service especially when our server know the specials too well or gave us the bill in between our apps and our entrees. My friend and I both made the assumption that he was drunk or hung over from the nigh before. The bussers were nice and attentive, I give those guys my tip anyday. I don't expect this review to be rotd, so don't.... Unless....   

Sorry for the bad granmer and spelling, writing a review on itouch is rather hard.

=)
author: Stanley K.

description:
Problem was it was a hot day and the bugs were out.  Dead fly in her water.  They brought back the same glass less the fly (lipstick still on glass). Shesh we could have picked it out.  Killed a couple bugs running on the table.  

Food was okay. Big eaters beware, portions are a little small.  Ceviche was good quality.   Carnitas properly seasoned and moist.  The guacamole and chips is excellent.  Chicken mole is tasty.   

I would go back on a cooler day for the food.  Without the bugs, I'll add a star.
author: David L.

description:
Best Sangria ever! So lite, fruity and refreshing. Love, love, love their Sangria.

The Mango de Azucar dessert was delicious and the guacamole was awesome. 

Thus far I've only been to Regalito Rosticeria once, but I enjoyed the food and drink and plan to be back.
author: Ginger L.

description: Cute little place with very good attentive service and tasty handmade food.  Also really enjoyed the sangria.  Maybe a little more spiciness to the food would kick it up a notch?
author: Newyorkwalk D.

description:
First, the food.  You see anyone dissing the food at this place, then question their whole review.  Because it is really delicious.  Hands down, no complaints.  Solid, fresh, consistent.

I just wish they could nail down their service a bit.  We had OpenTable reservations for a Tuesday night, and after we were seated, it took us a full 45 minutes to get our drinks.  You know, I am not hard to please.  I am fine sitting in a restaurant with my friends chatting for almost indefinite amounts of time.... ASSUMING I have a drink to nurse.  In a Mexican place, add in some chips and I am pretty much good to go.  

Anyway, I am in here a lot for brunch and it is nice and mellow and the service is always great.  But for dinner the service is a bit weak.  I think they need one more waitperson.
author: Troy S.

description: Very good!  Bought a groupon but normally would not go out of my way to spend that much money on Mexican food (don't get me wrong Mexican food is my absolute fav and a staple in my diet but...)  when there are so many other affordable amazing places in the Mission.  Everything was deelish!  Had chicken taquitos, enchiladas, flank steak, agave wine margaritas, and churros y hot chocolate.  I seriously never order taquitos or enchiladas but they were soooooo good!  Churros were a little slice of heaven!  Very small place I would reccommend making reservations and if its nice out they have a great outdoor dining area!
author: Jacqueline M.

description: I love this place. Try the carnitas and the the cocolate Popsicles. High end comfy Mexican delisious place for lunch or diner
author: Moy V.

description: I work in the Mission and have seen this place at lunch time but they are never open for lunch.  Tonight we decided to give it a try and I was very disappointed.  We had guacamole as an appetizer and it was very bland (the tortillas were good though). As a Latino myself one of the ways I measure really bland food at a Latino place is if I need to pick up the salt to add to my meal, and this was the case here.  Looking at the menu I saw the chicken rotisserie totally overpriced ($19 for 1/2 chicken!! when at Limon for $20 you get a full chicken plus two sides, and the chicken at Limon is very tasty), so chicken was a no-no.  I had the cochinita pibil and it was good, but it came in a plate full of black beans (bland too) and that was it on the plate.  My spouse had the green enchiladas and said they were bland too, we started joking that we could have had a more tasty one for less than half of the price at one of the delicious taquerias in the Mission.  We decided not to get dessert there.  The place has a modern cool feel inside, the service was pretty good and as others have said, no waiting line (which is actually not a great sign on a Friday evening).  I don't think we'll be coming back, which is unfortunate because I really wanted it to be good, I really did.
author: Jose R.

description:
A lot of reviews compare this place to a Tacqueria.  Regalito is to your standard Tacqueria as Show Dogs (http://www.yelp.com/biz/showdogs-san-francisco) is to your standard Bacon Dog Cart.  Yeah, the basic premise is the same, but the execution and presentation is entirely different...hence the added cost.

Regalito presents itself as a nice eatery with a simple decor that wouldn't look out of place at Ikea.  The kitchen is open and there is little mystery as to what is going on - chicken is cooked rotisserie style with an open flame and everything is made with high quality ingredients.

Service was very good, with an attentive and cheery waitress.  We ordered chicken mole and pork stew (I don't remember the Spanish name...).  

The chicken was very good - tender, juicy, and flavorful - and served on a bed of price.  It was listed as 'half a chicken' but in reality was two legs with attached breast, which made splitting very easy. The pork stew as also quite tasty, full of flavor with a delicious, sauce broth.  The black beans and tortillas that came with meal were a nice buffer between the two dishes.

Overall, it was a nice meal that, with wine, came to about $30 including tax and tip.
author: Eric M.

description:
The food here was really great -- I've walked by this place many times and never stopped in, but I'm glad I did. I had the tinga, and it was really flavorful. My boyfriend had the poblano, and I'll be getting that next time!

The only downside was that I booked a reservation for 9pm, and we weren't seated on time. It was a busy night, but the only option was to wait outside (since the place is so tiny) and it was pretty cold out! That part wasn't their fault, but it didn't help ;)
author: Veronica B.

description: Food delicious, but portions  small.  Main problem is service, which was execrable.  Impossibly understaffed for the number of diners.  It took us two hours from start to finish - on a Wednesday night.   If you have plenty of time on your hands and like pork (oh, I forgot - their menu has seven dishes but two were ... sold out.  Again, Wednesday, at 6:30?) and are not ravenous, then this might be the place for you.  Otherwise, not.
author: Owen B.

description:
I feel like I need to go back and give them another chance.  All I had were the enchiladas verdes, and it seems kind of sketchy to evaluate a place based on one dish.  So I'll probably update at some point.  But, for what it's worth...

The enchiladas verdes were okay.  Good portions, and the chicken was exceptionally moist and tender, so bonus for that.  The sauce, however, just wasn't that good.  It needed more tanginess and flavor.  The fact that it was the sauce that bothered me is what makes me think that I really just need to go back and try something else there, and maybe I just don't like their green sauce.  The servers, however, were quite friendly, so kudos for that.
author: Angela B.

description: Each time I come back, I like it more.  The service is super friendly.  The food is really tasty and fills a niche unlike any other in SF for Mexican food.  It's higher end Mexican in a relaxed setting, complex flavors, less spicy than you might be used to/expect.  Everything tastes very fresh.  It's relatively meaty, so as a warning, it is somewhat less good for vegetarians than many other Mexican places.  Definitely get the guacamole, make sure to get something that comes with the nice tortillas, enjoy something nice off the wine list, and relax!
author: Leo C.

description: Had their Cochinita Pibil and it was delicious with their homemade corn tortillas. Their guacamole appetizer was tasty, but we were also starved after walking around for a while looking for a restaurant that could seat us without a reservation. Overall a great dining experience for me.
author: Eric C.

description:
We were cruising the Mission when hubby said "let's go to that place you used to have a coupon for." I said "you mean the coupon that expired like 2 years ago?" Yeah, that one. So we headed to Regalito, popped in at 5:30, immediately liked the cool dark ambience with tracks spotlighting the art - which I'd describe as Upscale Day of the Dead.

Reservations? No. So hostess said we could either sit at the bar, or we could have a table if we were out in one hour for the reserved folks to come in. I said ok to the latter cuz I really like to have my feet on the ground.

The chips were fresh, the guacamole perfect and very ample. My husband's cochinita pibil was okay but showed no trace of the banana leaves it's supposed to be wrapped in, and didn't hold a candle to the one we had at Taqueria Las Palmas on Santa Rosa Ave. in Santa Rosa. If you're ever up there, definitely give it a try. 

I can't remember what I had at Regalito - its unmemorability I suppose speaks for itself, though in fairness, I asked for the least picante entree - but I recall a tasty crema fresca which I had to order more of, it came in a thimble; and a yummy verde sauce which gave the dish a little zip without burning my entire g.i. tract.

 The agave wine margarita was outstanding. First time I've ever had that.

Scarfing madly, we finished in time to yield to the vaunted reservations, which didn't materialize. The waitress asked if we'd like to see the dessert menu, but by then, having rushed, I was full.
author: Leigh G.

description: I'll start with a summation to my long review below: Nice venue, very expensive, low quality meat cuts, nice sauces, non-melting cheese, non-impressive service, and not enough beans = disappointing.  My group of 8 was looking for a nice restaurant in the Mission and stumbled upon Regalito.  The photos of the establishment do it justice, it is a nice-looking establishment.  Our party of 8 was seated in an outside patio area which was heated (nice and cozy).  The food, unfortunately, was very disappointing.  Members of our group are connoisseurs of Mexican food, having eaten it from all over the U.S. and in various regions of Mexico, so we were familiar with different styles, but we were incredibly disappointed with the results here.  We started with taquitos, ordering one vegetarian (potato) and one chicken option.  When the server brought over the taquitos, I was handed the first dish which was dentified it as the "chicken" dish.  Much to our dismay this was incorrect and our vegetarian ended up having her first bite of chicken in 3 years.  I later took the server aside and told her that though we were "fine" with it, in the future it is very important to identify correctly vegetarian from meat dishes (especially in SF).  We then ordered 3 orders of enchiladas (2 green and 1 roja).  There was virtually no cheese in the dish (certainly not melted) and the sauce was not really identifiable - or tasty for that matter.  I ordered the chicken mole, which true to the photo on Yelp, was one leg attached to the thigh.  I enjoyed the mole sauce, but I was not impressed with the dish overall.  Too much bone and skin, not enough sauce - and on top of that, everyone was disappointed in the amount of rice and beans for sides.  One person in our group asked for a few more beans, which arrived in a 1/2 cup-sized bowl, amounting to an added charge to the bill.  Even after the appetizer issue.  Seriously, at a Mexican restaurant, you charge for a side of beans?  We also ordered the carnitas (pork) which was not very flavorful and included no sauce of any kind.  I will give them credit for their tortillas, which are made from corn and thicker than typical, and very flavorful.  But, as mentioned before, with only a smidgen of sauce and beans/rice, it was difficult to wrap up the meat in the tortillas and be satisfied.  We had a child in the group who ordered quesadillas...he didn't like the tortilla or the cheese (no taste).  I think that these folks could improve the experience if they increased their sauces, rice, beans serving sizes, and maybe even offered a bit of lettuce/veg on the table, in case someone wants to add to their dishes.
author: Mona N.

description: My husband and I stopped here randomly, as it was a busy night in the Mission and everywhere we thought of going looked crazy busy.  This place was busy enough without being overcrowded, so we went with it.  The food was amazing!!  I had a chicken dish & fell immediately in love with the avocado sauce it came with!  I asked for more, which they happily gave to me and I it ate by the spoonful!!  My husband had the carne asada (which I kept stealing off his plate!).  It was tender and rich with flavor.  I washed it all down with Sangria and was a full and happy camper when I left!!
author: Nadia B.

description:
Came back, and it was definitely better than what I wrote about before. I had the chicken mole, which was pretty excellent. It was about twice as expensive as my quarter chicken last time ($17), but it was also probably twice as much food.

We also had the bread pudding. Not the best bread pudding I've had, but not bad. They had these neat jellos with really ornate flower designs in them. I was curious, but not enough to overcome my fear of Jello.

The service was right on the border between good and inattentive. They were entirely full, and it was a Saturday night, so I'll give them some slack.
author: Dana L.

description: Have been twice.  First time was impressive.  Seemed like a creative menu, and the service was friendly.  The ambiance is nice, and the artwork on display is amusing.  However next visit a year later, it was all about the same.  Not really meant to be a complaint, but maybe a suggestion to freshen up the menu.
author: Ken B.

description:
Today was the first time I've eaten at Regalito, and it was for lunch. I was surprised to find the place relatively busy on a weekday, and I chose to sit at the bar. 

The lunch menu is a bit abbreviated from the regular dinner options, and the portions are smaller (but also less expensive). On my waiter's recommendation, I went with the Pollo con Mole Negro, which arrived less than 10 minutes letter, piping hot.

I've had my share of mole sauce, but unless if my memory is going, Regalito's was some of the richest I've tasted. A little more chocolate-y than I expected, but it proved perfectly spiced in the end. I cut up my chicken, mixed the mole into the pieces and the accompanying rice and beans and went to town, making sure to sop up any extra sauce with the tortillas that were provided.

Washed it all down with a Negro Modelo, I'm sold.
author: Nish N.

description:
All four of us liked our dishes.  I had some kind of enchilada and gobbled it up, well-placed sauces and all.  Nice atmosphere.  Seemed like a high quality joint.

The place was dead, though.  It felt like we were the only people there.  3 lawyers and a lobbyist is more than enough, don't get me wrong.  Too much for everyone else there, no doubt.  Sorry everyone, but lepers like company too.
author: Brian D.

description:
RIP favorite umbrella, but your loss was totally worth it.

Out in the cold and rain, I didn't need help translating 'Rosticeria.' That means warm, homey, fall-off-the-bone goodness in every language.

That's "Rosticeria," not "Taqueria."

The decor is warm, clean, modern, with nicely framed mixed media pieces on the walls. The menu is clear, easy to read and frequently mentions two of my favorite words: chile and lime. Everything is made fresh that day and utterly delicious.

We shared 1/4 chicken, slow roasted with a nice chile-lime marinade. The chickie was super tender, clinging to the bone only enough that you could eat it like a happy kid at a picnic, if so desired. It came with beans, rice and tortillas. 

We ordered two sides. The Caesar cole slaw was surprisingly good with the bitterness of the cabbage contrasting the creamy dressing nicely. The sauteed green beans were tossed to 'snappy' perfection with fresh, sweet onion and lime. Sooo good.

We also could not resist the "made-from-scratch limeade", which was super fresh and tart. Faint of citrus heart may want to let your ice dilute the intense flavor. 

The topper was an Arbol [sic] Salsa made that morning that brought incredibly fresh and complex heat and citrus tang to everything it touched. I know, because I touched it on everything with delectable results.

We opted out of the desserts, citing recent holiday indulgences. I am very eager to try their take on bread pudding with apples. In all, the healthiest Mexican meal we ever had was less than $20 for both of us. That's super cheap for the quality and flavors.

The warmth of food and service had us slogging home like Gene Kelly, sans 'brella.
author: Andy R.

description:
Go eat here *now*. 

Mexican food sometimes gets short shrift in this city.  Sure, there are a pile of wonderful taquerias, and while most of them have great food they're usually a bit lacking in the atmosphere department.

Not Regalito -- The food here is wonderful, and the atmosphere is as well.  The restaurant is neat and tidy, and the shades of green and yellow adorning the walls are stylish and subtle.  

We ate almost everything on the menu - we shared 3 appetizers -- guacamole, quesadilla, green beans.  (by the way: The guacamole itself is worth the trip.)   We devoured the chicken in mole sauce, the herbed pork, and the chicken enchiladas.  

Unfortunately, they were out of flan - so we were forced to order the bread pudding.  I'm not really a bread pudding person - but my friends enjoyed it greatly.

Did I mention, you should go here ... now?
author: Stephan W.

description:
decided to give regalito another chance - this time for brunch - but still stand by my original opinion: it's okay.

service was good, but the brunch menu was relatively pricey - especially considering all of the more affordable (more tasty) options in the area. the dishes averaged about $10 and weren't generous size servings. i had the chilaquiles and there were so-so. it would've been nice if they had the option to add meat to them. we also tried the guacamole and it too was so-so. not very flavorful.
author: Kristen A.

description:
I hate to slam other reviews in my review, but when someone is just missing the point... well, you get a tongue-lashing.  Another reviewer wrote "bland, Americanized Mexican food" - and I guess if your only food experience in Mexico was in Cabo San Lucas, then maybe that's true.  and Regalito is not trying to compete with Taqueria's for christs sake. 

I think the idea here is actually an upscale twist on more traditional central Mexico dishes.  My dining companion, who spent time in Oaxaca, confirmed that.  the emphasis is more on pork and chicken, less on seafood, and includes central Mexican specialties like cactus.

The carnitas were indeed to die for, I will be going back for them.  I got the roast chicken with chili and garlic, but I must say the spices are very subtle, almost too much. It is organic chicken, so maybe the idea is just to let the birdie goodness come through.  the only other complaint would be that the cactus salad was so cold it seemed like it came right out of the fridge.  I think that dish is supposed to be closer to room temperature... what the hey it was a slow night and maybe it has to be kept in the fridge.

Table seating is rather limited but it's got the ever-too-popular counter option if you're flying solo, and you can watch the chickens turn in the roaster!  The service was very friendly.  Considering that organic and free-range meats and veggies are used, the prices are a bargain too.
author: christoph s.

description: Yay for Niman Ranch. This  place is super modern, cute space, and a great menu. I was able to eat yummy pork. It all worked out. A little pricey, but high quality and tasty.
author: Andrew K.

description: Loved it! What's not to love. The vibe/feel was cool, urban. Nice decore. Service was top notch. The food was tremendous. I had a seat at the counter and saw everything that was being served and it ALL looked splendid. I had the fried pork belly appetizer and the carnitas. Outrageous. It's 14 hours later and my burps taste like pig. What more could you aks for?
author: Tom M.

description:
The service was very good, the food was well..strange. I've been on a Michelada kick ever since I discovered them in Mexico, and was super excited to find them here, but the Michelada  turned out to be a strange concoction with bloody Mary MIx in it.  The chicken was so dry I almost asked for salsa to slather it with --if you want chicken, go to Limon. And be prepared to use some serious muscle if you want to eat the rice pudding, it is very very thick.

The guac and the flan were excellent though, but at $40 a head, I'd expected better food.
author: Asha V.

description:
When you've got a place with the word rotisserie in their name you'd expect the free range chicken to be the stand out item, but sadly it's dry and bland. If I'm going to pay $9 for 1/4 chicken with rice and beans, I'd expect the chicken to be juicy. I'm not hard to please really I'm just asking for more flavor. The guacamole was fresh, surprising for this time of year, and the corn chips were crispy and addicting. But here's the thing, I can't help but wonder if regalitos is trying to cater more towards the american palette because the flavors lack that little heat I'm used to. While the guacamole was fresh and good, it lacked that extra flavor. I prefer my guacomole with a bit more lemony tartness and a lot more heat, both of which were sadly missing in action. Perhaps I am just being nitpicky but still I can't help feeling somewhat  disappointed by the blandness of the dishes.

The desserts however are worth trying. My prefered dessert is the gelato made from Ibarra chocolate. It's both dense and rich, and shockingly it was the first gelato dessert I could not finish. Yes I left half of it untouched, what a waste. I've also heard good things about the tamarindo gelato. I'm giving Regalitos the benefit of the doubt because they are still new, and probably have to work out their menu issues. The service is well meaning, the food is hit or miss. And all I can say is stay tuned for an update.
author: X marks the spot ..

description:
This place has a overall Mexi-muted theme about it. 

The color of the place is more pastel and matted.  Not the bold and sometimes darker colors seen in Mexi-eateries. 

The food is also muted.  All the flavors are there but they were very much toned down and subtle.  I don't know about you but since when is Mexican food subtle in taste?!?!?

As always...I have issues paying $13 for a dish I can make at home for half that amount.
author: Jay H.

description:
Okay, I'm officially hooked on yelp, like it were a 9-5 job.  So, I was disappointed that I wasn't the first to review Regalito's, damn you!!

My  yelp friend and I decided to check this new place out.  So, we started off with the guacamole with tostadas (warm and fresh), appetizers of course.  Our waitress, Honora (?), had a good eye and was attentive with refilling the water during the entire time. 

Fellow yelpers, the carne asada con hongos (steak with mushrooms,) which also comes with red beans, is a meal to satisfy.  The steak (ordered medium) was juicy and filling.  The beans could of had more flavor though. 

And to finish off the meal with something sweet, we had more than enough of ice cream, made by the owner/chef.  Keep in mind an order can serve two, at least to me since I wasn't able to finish it and ate the most I could because it's a shame to see sweets go down the drain.  Mexican vanilla, tamarindo and mango are other flavors available.   

No alcohol (beer and wine) is served yet, but they will once they have their alcohol license.  Also, some desserts aren't served just yet, just ice cream for now, creamy ice cream.

Oh and visit the bathrooms, guys there are urinals.
author: Glu C.

description:
I have been wanting to try this spot and hoped that it would be DELISH! My girlfriend is Mexican and was highly skeptical of fancified Mexican food, but we had a groupon so we gave it a shot. 

We were sorely disappointed! The food was pretty bland and not substantial enough - her expensive enchiladas rojos were basically tortilla dipped in red sauce with some queso fresco crumbled on top. that's it! and, the $7 salad was so miniscule it was insulting. The waitstaff were really sweet but the food is just not good enough to warrant those prices - we could have had a more flavorful and authentic meal at Pancho Villa for a mere pittance.
author: Créme d.

description: I was very excited to try this place.  What a disappointment.  Selections were limited and unimaginative.  The meats in our entrees were flavorless - even my friend from Mexico City was puzzled.  And the portions weren't exactly generous considering the prices.  Oddly, I don't know why it's called a rotisserie, because only one or perhaps two entrees on its limited menu were prepared that way.  Sadly, we won't be back.
author: P L.

description:
ME: Welcome amiguitos y amiguitas yelpers! For this review let's play a game of  fact vs. fiction with Mexican Professor Esmar T. Pantalones, shall we?

Bienvenido, profesor Pantalones! Ready for question one? According to the website, Regalito's menu got inspired by the type of food you eat at an honest to goodness Mexican Mercado! Fact or fiction, Profesor Pantalones? 

Profesor Pantalones: 
"FALSE! FALSE! Mexico is an enormous country. Traditionally Eurocentric maps favor Europe and the US (Mumbling) horrible colonists countries...by appearing bigger!! Yet Mexico is even bigger than Alaska or Scandinavia at .7 mill square miles. (shaking his finger) Regalito!!! Be specific and show your work! Mexican Markets WHERE? El Centro? El Sureste? El Norte? El Bajio? La peninsula de Yucatan? They are all strikingly different cuisines!!

ME: You mentioned Yucatan...what did you think of the Cochinita? It is an authentic staple from the Yucatan peninsula! 

PP: As we all know Cochinita is more of a sit down dinner you'll find at a home or a restaurant. Generally it comes wrapped in banana leaves adhering to Maya styles of cooking, and delicately spiced with achiote and bitter orange. It is NOT stall food!!! Regalito's was a little bit greasy. Regalito!! You didn't do your homework!!! Tache!!

ME: What about the "comida corrida"? Isn't that something you would find in Mexico?? What about the papitas con rajas ($5)? La sopita de fideo ($8)? Y las calabacitas a la Mexicana ($5)?? They are VERY authentic!! I seemed to liked them all just fine. 

PP: Yes...but they are something you would eat maybe at a "FONDA", not a market. And who would pay those prices for "FONDA" food??? Or market food? The only thing you would maybe find at a market in Mexico City would be the Pepitas con chile y limon ($3), along with esquites, alegrias, pepitorias and palanquetas.... all of them mere cents. MEXICAN MARKET FOOD SHOULD BE CHEAP!!

ME: OK.....we have to clarify that they use organic produce as much as possible, so I think THE PRICES ARE UNDERSTANDABLE. Besides we are in the US and things are more expensive here. And don't you want our fellow Mexicans working there to get paid reasonably? But let's backtrack for the sake of our non-Mexican amiguitos and amiguitas out there...can you briefly explain what a "FONDA" is, professor?

PP: A diner basically. A small neighborhood restaurant. Again, not market food nor gourmet cuisine. At a Mexico City market you would eat stuff like Tlacoyos!! Empanadas de Huitlachoche! Pambazos! Charales! Cuimiles! Sopes! Huaraches!! Jugos y licuados...and..!!

ME: Professor, we are getting off topic! Besides, if anyone wants to try *some* of the food you mentioned they could always go to places like "El Huarache Azteca" in Oakland...or better yet, go to MEXICO! When it comes to Mexican food, there are always options for everyone. You have to remember that most of our Amiguitos and Amiguitas here are accustomed to "Tex Mex" and "Taqueria" food...they always want a side of chips with their food. Please understand them...they may not know *anyting* about the diversity of Mexican food....

PP: QUE PENDEJOS!!!

ME: Professor, this is a family review! 

PP: My madre alway said about chips "Esas cosas te empanzonan y te llenan, pero no te nutren!" They are not even Mexican foodl En el Sureste they call them "totopos"...and they are round, not triangular...

ME: (rolling my eyes) Anyway.... is there something you *did* like at Regalito?

PP: The Fresas con crema. They are apparently a seasonal dessert, not usually on the menu. They are beautiful strawberries with creamy, slightly salty Mexican Crema. If they had a side of "galletas maria" I would be transported back to my childhood in Irapuato. And the Ensalada de nopalitos ($8.50) is a good choice for its nutritional value. Nopalitos aid naturally in processing blood sugar, they are good for diabetics. However the ones at Regalito didn't get rinsed enough.  They have to rinse out the gooey roping, specially if they are going to make SALAD! Put them in a colander and rinse them well...then drain them, Regalito!! Minus one point!!

ME: (throwing away my note cards) Professor, I had 10 more "fact vs. fiction" questions but this is taking way too long...we can't get pass the first question! Besides, I'm the one giving the review!

I'll give this restaurant four stars, because everything was fresh, it was  nicely decorated, and just because they are trying to cook something different....

PP: Pero ni tanto!!

ME: The staff was very nice....

PP: You just kept giving the big bear of a waiter "ojos de borrego a medio morir"! I saw you!

ME: OK, this review is over! Please join us some other time for another game of facts vs. fiction with Professor Esmar T. Pantalones....

Maybe.
author: Raul A.

description:
Ahhh, I love living in the Mission. It's a food lover's paradise, and a recent blossom in this culinary Garden of Eden is Regalito.

We were on the fence about ordering an appetizer, but our server enticed us into trying the guacamole. (OK, "entice" is a rather strong word. I was sold before she got to "...amole.") As promised, it was very good, and the fact that it was served not with chips but with crispy corn tortillas hot from the fryer was a really nice touch. The combination of sizzling crispness and tangy-spicy richness was delicious. 

For entrees, we split the Chile Verde and the Pollo De Plaza -- roasted free-range chicken served with enchiladas rojas, potatos and carrots. I'm a big fan of chile verde, and Regalito's rendition is excellent. I'm not sure if green beans are a traditional ingredient in chile verde, but they worked. Also, I don't like too much tang in my chile verde, and this dish had just the right balance. The chicken was pure comfort food: juicy, tender and simply prepared. The carrots, potatoes and enchiladas rojas -- again, very simply prepared -- were satisfying and rounded out the experience.

it also bears mentioning that the sangria was very good.

The dining room is much smaller than I expected, and we had to sit at the counter to avoid a 25-minute wait. I normally don't like the restaurant counter experience, but I didn't mind it at Regalito. Maybe that's because the service was so attentive and friendly.

I'd like to give Regalito 3.5 stars, but since that's not possible here on Yelp, I'll give them the benefit of the doubt and bump it up to 4 stars. (It definitely deserves more than 3 stars.)

I can't wait to try the carnitas next time.
author: The Other Jeff A.

description: Just went tonight for Pigalito Tuesday and had an absolutely fabulous time.  We all ordered off of the Pigalito (all pork) menu.  We shared the Flautas and Brussel Sprouts, both delicious.  I had the Empanadas, which was amazing (I think the best of all that we ordered).  My dinner mates also had the Carnitas and the Cochinitas Pebil.  For dessert we had the Churros with Hot Chocolate and the Bread Pudding.... but were wonderful.  Everything was beautifully presented and delicious and the service was exceptional.  Our server was so sweet and accommodating.  He brought us several tastes of wine in order to help us pick our bottles.  We also were a day late for the BlackBoard Eats deal, but he gave it to us anyways!  Overall a fabulous night, I highly recommend it.
author: Susan M.

description:
The outside is deceiving - the big painted wall visible from Valencia makes it seem large, but Regalito is a tiny restaurant that seems to shrink when you walk inside the door.  I think they must have about 7 tables, tops?  But what they lack in tables they make up in a good amount of counter space, which I don't mind at all if you are a party of 1 or 2.

I don't know if I would have chosen the Mission for the location of this place, as it is bound to get a lot of flack from the tacqueria-eating die-hards.  I found the modern setting refreshing, and the simple food satisfying, and not coma-inducing like so many other places.

We started with a carafe of sangria - very tasty with lots of fruit on the bottom.  The guacamole is a huge portion and is served with round crispy tostadas instead of tortilla chips.  We also had the chicken tacquitos which were very good with strips of fresh chicken inside.  

For my main, I had the Carnitas which were very good.  The portion was ample, not gargantuan, which was nice, and the meat was very tender and had just enough fat for flavor, but not too much. It served with beans, salsa and fresh avocado.  I also ordered a side of Elote which was so so so so good!  Give me some corn on the cob, cover it in cheese and mayonnaise, add spices and you have something bordering on lethal.  

The rotisserie chickens were mezmerizing me as they rotated on the spit, and I'd definitely stop by to get one for take-out on a week night.

For dessert, we shared the bread pudding which was pretty good - I would have preferred it a little more crisp, but it was tasty, with chunks of fruit and a scoop of ice cream as a topping.

Regalito is a good choice if you are craving Mexican food, but don't want to feel all bloated and unhealthy afterwards.  The food is simple, the portions reasonable, and you'll have room in your stomach for plenty of beer later.
author: Liz S.

description: We dined here for a group event we were invited to. The staff were all very friendly and the food was good. Very kids friendly.
author: Akiko I.

description:
I stumbled by this place a few weeks ago and knew just by peeking in the dark window it would be good.  Having already overly high expectations, I was still impressed on my first visit for dinner.  

This is not a taqueria, it is not cheap food, it is not the place to go if you want quick and dirty tacos from a truck.  I love taco trucks as much as the next guy but sometimes it's nice to sit down to a clean table and have something a bit different than my favorite street taco style fare.  

The guacamole here is freshly made one serving at a time.  It's simple, not overdone, like you'd make at home but yet Regalito and Colibri seem to be the only restaurants in SF who make it just right. The papas (potatoes) with pasilla chile strips are the other simply elegantly flavored thing here which just don't taste as good anywhere else.  The slow roasted 1/4 chicken I ate was tender, juicy and flavorful.  The seasonings here at Regalito are clearly not designed to explode in your mouth or compete with a taqueria style mexican meal that many people know and love.  The flavors are melded together in complimentary ways to massage the pallet with a slow seduction of savory sensations.

The agave wine based margarita here was very tasty, a bit sweet for my preferences but to be expected since wine has more fructose than tequila. Agave nectar has such a wonderfully smooth sweetness about it though, so much silkier than regular sugars.

Update:
Regalito is on my list of potential favorites, but I really think they seem to need more than 1 server when it's busy even though it's a small place.  On a few occasions I haven't been satisfied with the flavors of the food, things are bland sometimes.  When they're good they're good though, hope they can get these issues worked out.
author: P H I L H.

description:
Almost everything about this place is unremarkable--the service, the flavors, the ambiance.  Plus one star for using fresh ingredients, but minus two for the utter lack of anything compelling.  My companion and I had the rotisserie chicken and pozole.  Both were filling but far from special.  

And don't bother asking for anything spicy.  When I implored our waiter to bring me some hot sauce, all I got was a ramekin of watered down tomato paste, no heat whatsoever.
author: vicarious c.

description:
I don't understand the expectations people have of this place - of COURSE it's not going to be cheaper than a burrito place, or even a restaurant that serves Americanized Mexican food because Regalito serves food made in a traditional manner and from very high-quality ingredients.

I love this place for it's clean, flavorful food during both dinners and especially on weekend brunch.

True story - we have a friend who is a restauranteur in Tokyo and all she wants to eat when she comes to visit is Regalito.
author: Horns D.

description:
When I first discovered Regalito over a year ago, It became a craving every time we were in the Mission. The owner Tomás was always present. COOKING. He was quiet but focussed on his kitchen. There was dedication and I then though, love for his business.

Our experience at Regalito yesterday left us not wanting to ever set foot in it again. Tomás, no longer in charge of his kitchen, or even present. Left it to amateurs who cooked up the most insipid (and overly expensive) collection of disappointments. What's worse. We left with such pain in our stomachs, I couldn't sleep last night. Today, my stomach still on fire. Regalito not only got crossed from our favorites in a matter of seconds, the food was so plain and digestively unsettling that Regalito deserves no stars for actually giving us pain on top of it all.

If Tomás cares for his business he surely must act now. Sadly, we won't be treating ourselves to a Regalito ever again.
author: Marielle L.

description:
Lunch with the boss as always is an adventure. Those in the know can predict that with baby in tow, while trying to hold meetings, run errands or pay some bill, we're always out looking for a way to multi-task. Those who really know my boss knows she works in her sleep. Multi-task is the ONLY way we do.

With summer approaching however we're both reaching the more loopy, why isn't it warm out, part of our personas and know that any tension, frustration, or weather/hunger induced mood swings can only be corrected by one thing, a burrito. Or good Mexican. Well, I'm a good Mexican but you get the point...

Breakfast burritos on her brain, we ended up at Regalito. Actually we were going to go to El Buen Sabor, but a former roommate of mine who I would rather not talk to and made one of the potentially best semesters of my life a living hell, happened to walk in right as we drove around the corner to look for parking. 

Comfort food was REALLY in need because I've managed to not speak to her in a few years, so I was cool off Buen Sabor. Then she, being on top of all that's design, noticed Regalitos paint job and logos. Hoping in and grabbing a menu to pick out what we were getting. We salivated. 
Chilaquiles for me (sans chicken is how they serve it here, but that's aight i looooove green chiles) and Chorrizo con Huevos for her. 

As soon as we got back to the house, we devoured it all. Some damn good meatless chilaquiles, and I'm a protein fiend. And some really tasty, not as spicy as I generally go for, chorizzo for her. Made my day. Have to  check out their chicken since they are a rosticeria, that might be next time.
author: Niki M.

description:
Plain and Simple- The best little mexican restaurant in SF!  

Everytime I travel to SF from LA this is my place for REAL food.  

Try the Churros and hot Chocolate!
author: Anthony C.

description: 3.5 stars. A step up from casual taquerias but not fancy. Great for takeout. I enjoy the cactus salad, but always ask for no onion because there's too much for my taste. Also, I like that they have arctic char fish tacos, unlike the run of the mill fish that taquerias use, but the fish is a tad dry. The rotisserie chicken with lime is good and my friend enjoyed the pork pibil.
author: Marina N.

description:
I just wanted to say that Regalito Rosticieria is now my favorite "everyday" SF restaurant, not just my favorite Mexican restaurant. The food is outstanding and the service is very friendly and efficient.

I have eaten at Regalito at least 10 times and I do not understand the negative comments other Yelpers have given, this place deserves a solid five stars. Well they say, "to each his own", but you naysayers are stupid and unsophisticated. I have never had a bad dish or a bad service experience. 

This is not your typical Mexican restaurant, SF doesn't need more of those anyway. If you want typical Mission-district-Mexican-food, go to Chava's and shut up (no offense to Chava's, I like them too). 

So what if Regalito doesn't serve red Mexican rice or give you chips and salsa, this place is above the expected norm. It's much much better and I'm honored to be a customer. I "get" them and I have been looking for this type of Mexican food for years - really. It satisfies me on a soul level. Regalito is my soul mate.

I eat here a few times a month and have tried almost everything on the menu. They are open for lunch (smaller menu) and serve a great breakfast too (they open at 11 am). 

I recently had the Cochinita Pibil: Slow roasted, banana leaf wrapped, Citrus & achiote marinated pork Served with black beans $15.00, it was wonderful. 

I love sitting at the bar and watching the cooks prepare the food: they make Mexican food the right way, all from scratch using high quality ingredients, made with love and care. If you appreciate someone like Chef Rick Bayless (PBS's Mexico: One Plate at a Time), you will like this place a lot.

Regalito I love you, I really do. You are my sweet satisfying restaurant soul mate. 

Yelpers, you cannot go wrong with anything on the menu, it's all GREAT.
author: Yvette K.

description:
Looking for a place to have a belated b-day dinner a friend and I came to this place on a random weeknight. It's a very small place and luckily a few tables cleared as soon as we walked in. I was super hungry and super excited, especially because I saw them making handmade tortillas...WHA? OMG!! 

The service definitely needs some serious help. The place is so small that we had to prance around the counter just to let customers exit. The waiter half smiled at us when we walked in. I was so confused. Do we sign our name somewhere? Is there a hostess? Do we seat ourselves? We patiently stood by the counter waiting to be acknowledged. After a few minutes the waiter finally came up to us and asked us how many in our party...um just two. He then just walked away. Awkward? No not as awkward as the man playing his guitar 18 inches away. Very nice music but it felt like we were invading his space or like we were interrupting someone's serenade. 

Finally we get seated. I was so hungry and excited for the tortillas that I let that ridiculousness slide. The service did get better after that. The guac was very good as were the freshly made tostadas. The enchiladas verdes were SO good! Just the write blend of spicyness. I highly recommend getting this dish!! The mole was also good. The chicken just melted onto your fork and the mole sauce was quite tasty. I just wish that they could marinate the chicken in the mole sauce instead of just pouring it on top. I think it would enhance the flavor of the chicken. With a small resto comes small tables. We eventually got all of our plates to fit but any sudden movement and we could kiss our guac and tostadas goodbye. Too bad I was driving or else I would have enjoyed me a few more glasses of their sangria--SO good!! We didn't try dessert although we were very tempted but so full! 

Not sure if I would come back. Maybe for takeout. The service needs to improve a tad.
author: Adriana G.

description: $20 for a plate of tasteless rotisserie chicken which was not tender enough. Tortillas were tough. Taquitos were tough. Food didn't taste fresh and worst Mexican food I've had given the higher prices. Better to go to other good-value taquerias. Went on a Tuesday - not sure if that's part of the reason. Server seemed to be new; was receiving oral instructions from the cook about our prepared dishes, so they were talking OVER our food (no I don't like someone's spit on my food).  Used to be good years ago.
author: Chris D.

description:
Yummy!!!!

Tiny place that does not look like your typical Mexican restaurant but has the food (and on the night I was there the live entertainment) to back up its roots.

Very friendly and accommodating service, and oh so tasty and yummy food. If you love super-spicy, you may be slightly disappointed - here it's more about the balance and variety of flavor instead of pure burn.

Pollo con Mole Negro: tender, succulent, delicious. Loved the Mole.
Cochinita Pibil: Sigh. so moist, so flavorful, such great textures with all the ingredients.

I will so definitely be back.
author: Tatjana G.

description:
Great food. When the waiter brought our orders out and set them on the table, I said, "Wow, that looks like something that would come out of my mom's kitchen!"

(My mom is a brilliant home chef who learned all her considerable Mexican culinary wizardry from her mother and older sisters back home on the ranch in central Mexico. Her food is astoundingly good and authentic, so I hope that contextualizes the exclamation quoted above properly.)

Then I tasted the food.

It was delicious. The flavors were fresh and clear, not overwhelming and unbalanced. It tasted like what Mexican food--prepared by and served for Mexicans--is supposed to taste like.

All these folks who are complaining of "bland" and "Americanized" and  "who wants subtle" are idiots. That's right:  idiots.

Or, to be fair (if I must), they are suffering from a lack of context. If all the American food you've had has been at Denny's, you're probably not going to know what to think when you're eating at Maverick. Likewise, if all the 'Mexican' food you've had is at taquerias, you aren't going to know what hit you when you have real Mexican food. Catch a clue, people:  taquerias are fast food, they aren't in the same category as a sit-down restaurant. So, if you wouldn't compare Jack in the Box and the Slow Club (even if they do both serve French fries), don't compare a taqueria and Regalito. Me entiendes, buey?

Regalito is definitely one of my go-to restaurants for good, authentic Mexican food. It's delicious and certainly someplace I take friends to enjoy the kind of high caliber Mexican food I grew up with. Hell, I wouldn't be embarrassed to take my mom there, the food's so good.

Seriously, if you want actual Mexican food, go to Regalito. If all you want is Mexican fast food, hit up a taqueria--and stop your bitching about how they don't serve it at Regalito.
author: Alberto Y.

description:
TOO HIGH A PRICE drops just ok food into "meh" status.

C'mon.  It's just expensive, gussied-up Mexican food.  In the Mission, of all places.

Look, I would pay -- dearly -- for REAL Mexican food.  By which I mean, what you get in Mexico when you get way past the border.  Now, they're trying here at Regalito, but not hard enough.  What we had was average, and the prices were high.

The Tortilla Soup?  Good, I'll give that to them.  Tamales?  Commonplace.  Their special lambshank in the random creamy tomato sauce?  Whatever.  Gamey, and not good enough.

I know it's pretty comfortable for white people to eat here, but I'm not one of them.  I guess I just have to keep dreaming of what it was like down in Mexico City...   

(I never stop looking for the ideal Taco al Pastor... my search is here:
http://www.yelp.com/list/taco-quest-2009-oakland)
author: Daniel S.

description:
Authentic Mexican food with a great (but small and cozy) atmosphere.

I like bringing friends here as I plan to work through the entire menu.  The selection of fresh aguas frescas are vast.  My favorites are Tamarindo, Mango, and Melon.  As for food favorites, the green chicken enchiladas use moist white meat chicken breast in more of a broth than I'm used to, but still super tasty.

The chicken mole is fantastic, sweet, but not too sweet, and savory with all the spices, mmmmm!  Elotes, well can you go wrong with that?  The papas y queso tacos are really good too.  I've also had the Chocolate Mexicano and yes, it was so worth it.  Same as the Churros, freshly made there, and perfectly cooked in the center, still a bit oozing of fresh dough, so good!

The service is great and I like the interior decor, it's fresh and has that lofty feel.  If it's not too busy, you'll catch the chef checking out your reactions to the food, he wants to see if you like it and it keeps him on his toes.  He knows that he has a good product.
author: Miss C.

description:
I stopped by this restaurant for lunch an afternoon that I was off from work.  I was the only customer at the time (around noon on a Friday).  I'm usually weary about those types of situations because more often than not, the servers take that opportunity to ignore you.  Granted, they're doing "restaurant stuff," but it's just not how you treat a patron.  Sorry, tangent.  Anyway, Regalito Rosticeria did NOT do this.  The server was quite attentive and very kind.

I ordered the enchilada with chicken ($12.50).  Sadly the dish was fairly small for the price.  However, I was only able to eat half of it at the time and was able to box the rest (FYI, not too shabby as leftovers).

All in all, I liked this place.  Great atmosphere and kind people.  All the meat is Niman Ranch or equivalent and is quite tender.  I will come back for dinner in the near future.
author: Chris M.

description:
This place will make you think twice about Mexican food...

You realize that you get what you pay for with $5 burrito you buy at the other local taqueria when you eat at Regalito.  There are those rare restaurants that put amazing precision and care with abosolutely everything.  Not just the balance of flavors but the presentation of the food, the atmosphere, the way they write their menu, the colors on the walls...everything!!  

It makes you question the way you've been eating before.  Are enchiladas not rolled into little cyclinders (some are evidently floated on your plate like little handkerchiefs of corn dipped in home-made sauce)?  Are there actually desserts that harken Mexico besides churros?  Are rice and beans not automatically included in your meal?
author: Tom K.

description:
Eh. I wanted to like this place more than I did, but I can't lie -- it was fine, not great, not horrible. Will I go back? I probably won't go out of my way to, but I won't avoid it, either, if others want to partake.

The best parts: Attractive interior design, sparkling clean surfaces, friendly service. This place strikes me as a Mission joint that's been made over for non-Latinos, particularly those who are hesitant to go into any of the less shiny, less frou-frou, and yes, less pricey places in the neighborhood. I'm not always as adventurous as I could be when it comes to trying said places, so you could argue I'm part of Regalito's target clientele -- but it fell short for me.

Okay, we only tried two dishes, the chicken prepared with garlic, chile, and lime and the chips and salsa, so I can't claim to have tried a wide variety of their offerings. I'm wondering if, paradoxically, some of the non-rotisserie chicken dishes are the way to go, particularly after reading others' reviews here. Enchiladas, maybe? Sopa? Worth consideration. In any case, the chicken and its accompanying rice and beans were fine, but this dish's portion was too small. We enjoyed the fried tortillas that we had to break apart ourselves to make chips, but the salsa, of a pico de gallo style, had too many (serrano?) chiles in it for us, and we like spicy food.
author: Tara M.

description:
Highly recommend getting together with a friend or group of 2-4 & heading here. Or go by yourself, sit at the bar & watch the action. When I was there, there was 1 hostess/dessert maker (learned I could freeze churros from her), 1 tortilla lady, 1 server, 1 grill/sautee/cook & 1 dishwasher. That's about all the people that can fit in their prep space though, & they did a great job of coordination (although only 2 tables & me to wait on)  

I went on a Tuesday night, slightly raining, around 5:15pm, & sat at the bar. Not realizing it was "pig night" - when the menu centers around all things pig - I was happily informed they had 2 dishes for non-pig eaters. 1 vegetarian dish & (what I went for) Regalito Pollo. 

OMG!! What a fantastic dish! I rarely compare other's chicken to my Dad's (he makes a darn good grilled chicken) but this cook had it down. The chicken was super moist, the skin crunchy in some places & chewy in others, golden brown & a good portion. The swiss chard had garlic chunks & onions laced thru it (LOVE that!) & was sauteed to the point of perfection. The tomato salsa had a nice balance of chuncky tomatoes, onions & a sprinkle of fresh herbs. The tortillas (5! for 1 person!) were fantastic - grilled to doneness without being dry. You could even taste the corn! When asked, I was told to cut up the chicken then make tortillas/wraps out of them. With the squeeze of lime to give it the final touch, these tortillas were heaven. The corn tortillas held up to the sauce from the vegs/lime. I ate 2 that way then ate the rest of the chicken & sides as is....a heavenly plate of texture, spice/flavoring, and well-prepared food. Hard to ask for anything more. 

I'll happily go back and tell others to keep this place in business for many more years.
author: Marissa H.

description:
Dear Yelpers,

The main reason that you should trust me is that I try really, really hard to visit places twice before I review them.  Sometimes, I can't help myself, like Hard Knox Cafe, and I have to go home and talk about how miserable it was.

That wasn't the case with Regalito.  We walked away with a distinct feeling of "meh", disappointing in light of how close it is to the boyfriend's house.  The interior is adorable.  Man Candy's enchilada was too hot, the green beans and chicken I ordered was nothing that I couldn't have pulled together in my own kitchen, if I wasn't so lazy.  The pumpkin seeds were a bright spot, but again...I wasn't raised to be this lazy, I'm eschewing my genetic code.

But I AM that lazy.  That would be too lazy to walk to Dosa on a cold night (an additional four blocks away) and the Chron had just run a review that talked about how the experience got better each of the three times that they visited, and that they dialed the flavors up.  My whining won out, and we ordered a boatload of food-chile rillenos for the MC, green beans, and some chicken, potatoes, carrots and enchilada thing for me.  And taquitos, the potato kind.  We were going for broke.  Starch central!  

It was quite good. Really, all of it was.  During the intial visit, plates were both spicy and unflavorful.  Now, they're just using fresh ingredients and letting the food speak for itself.  Just in case we were too hungry to judge, I heated up the leftovers tonight-and they were still good!  Even the rice and beans (which came with the chile rilleno and I dumped some TJ's salsa on before I put it in the microwave.

I can't speak for the service, but I can assure you it's being added to the take out rotation.  Give Regalito another try-or a first one-and let me know what you think.
author: Beth V.

description: This is a great Mexican kitchen. The food is fresh, with the highest quality ingredients.  The guacamole is rich, creamy, with just enough spice.  The mole is out of this world.  And the staff is really nice and eager to please.
author: Jason Y.

description:
After one visit, it seems like a great place.  Pretty authentic mexican food (as far as I can tell) served in a hybrid modern atmosphere (imagine a tiny Limon with brighter lighting).  But still a little too tight for a date - as others have noted, a mix between taqueria and restaurant.

The food, as viewed from our nice perch at the counter, is both beautiful and delicious.  Try the quarter chicken, and the enchiladas verdes (as recommended by the quality staff).  Lots of fresh guac goes into the guacamole.  The toasted pumpkin seeds were also nice.  We saved dessert until next time.

As long as you don't mind watching the cook pike chickens for the roaster, go!
author: Elliott W.

description:
My boyfriend and I had a "date night" so we decided to try a new place we hadn't eaten at in the Mission- which is so easy to do considering all the great places to choose from!

We had gone to Luna Park a while back, and noticed Regalito Rosticeria across the street- we decided, why not?  

When we got there, one couple was in front of us so we put down our name and decided to wait- figuring 15 min?  Turns out everyone had who had been seated before us, must have gotten there all at the same time!  We waited about 30-40min (which in SF is unheard of...) 

BUT- the couple in front guaranteed it was well worth the wait, and since we had no were to go- and the line was building up behind us... we stuck around.
The cooks actually gave us a small side plate of their homemade potato chips which were amazing while we waited.  

Once seated at the bar, we ordered the Chicken Tamales and one of their Pork Dishes, and the grilled cactus appetizer... WOW.
Talk about authentic REAL Mexican food!!!  Heck, I'm not even sure if it's Mexican or something more Central American- but it was damn good! 
We both ordered Dessert as well- the flan and something else with Mexican Vanilla Ice Cream.... we were too full to order the Bread Pudding, but I'll tell you this- that Bread Pudding looked so Freak'n good- it's worth a trip back, just for that!

Service was slow ish- but not bad!  Go in planning on dining, not eating quickly and leaving... You need to eat slowly and enjoy each and every bite!  

If you are looking to impress friend from out of town- are take someone on a date... THIS is the place!!

Five Stars for me!
author: Leslie D.

description:
If you know Mexican food, this ISN'T the place for you

The taquitos were served without guacamole, the machaca was served without tortillas and we didn't get chips and salsa when we sat down

The plates are so small, the rice and beans come in a separate bowl

I did however enjoy the caramelized mango and vanilla ice cream
author: Xica D.

description:
Customer service is obviously not a priority in this over-priced and under-achieving restaurant. One of the waiters had the audacity to ask us to move seats literally while we were in the middle of eating our meal to give up one of our seats to other customers! Are you kidding me? I could see if it was before we had been served our orders or well after we were done and our plates were cleared, but damn, while we're eating?! Wow. 

Additionally, the food was alright but certainly not worth the ridiculous prices. If you're gonna have high prices, your food better have the clout to back it up and this place certainly does not cut it. 

Before my friend was even done eating the very same waiter reached for her plate and asked her if she was done with it AFTER he already picked it up! WTF? Really?! He didn't even ask if she wanted it wrapped up or anything and she had plenty of food left on the dish. Yeah, that didn't make us feel rushed or anything. *rolls eyes*

Flan is $8 and it's not even good. The sauce is too sharp and thus throws off the flavor balance of creamy/sweet that flan is supposed to have. Weak. And by the way, if you are vegetarian, dont eat the rice because it has chicken stock in it. 

The only good thing they had going on was the interior design. It has a nice atmosphere, but that one waiter should be fired and they need to step up their game if they are going to charge as much as they do.
author: j v.

description: We had a great experience at Regalito. We were out for a friend's birthday and had a group of 9. We didn't plan ahead, so finding a place to accomodate 9 people at 7 pm on a Saturday was not easy (our fault for not making reservations anywhere). Regalito was full, but they were by far the friendliest and made the greatest effort to get us in (which they did after about 20 minutes). Once inside, the service was great. The guacamole was phenomenal, and the sangria was quite solid as well. I would consider the entrees very good. Nothing spectacular, but quite tasty. Overall, I would definitely go back. Very good food & drink, paired with great service.
author: Michael H.

description:
We snuck away from the Red Bull soap box races in order to escape the obnoxious stumbling drunk at noon crowd and satisfy our hunger. 

Just up the street we found Regalito which looked promising. 

To help nurse my cold, I opted for the chicken tortilla soup. I was looking forward to a piping hot bowl of soup to make me feel warm and comfortable. Instead, I was served a bowl of luke warm soup that definitely didn't make me feel warm.

Our food took FOREVER. The restaurant was almost empty when we arrived, so there really didn't appear to be a good reason for our food to take so long. 

I hate sending food back, but when it really was cold and I was sick, so I asked for my tepid soup to be reheated. 

Once reheated, the soup was ok, but I've had much better. 

Definitely a disappointing experience.
author: Lee H.

description:
Apparently I've been walking by it (well, kitty corner to it) for 3 months and failed to notice this little spot.  Once I finally stopped starring at my shoes and took notice I had to try it.  Went with a lady friend and we split three appetizers and a dessert.

The place is small and has a modern and clean vibe but it's not pretentious.  The wait staff were all pleseant and our server in particular was a pleasure.  We ordered Sangria and the Guacamole, Taquitos de Pollo and Quesadillas Fritas.  

The sangria was good.  Perfectly acceptable.  The Taquitos (5) were perfect and were served beautifully.  The chicken was tender, they were at just the right temperature and the texture was spot on.  

The Quesadillas Fritas (3) were served with a chile sauce that was soooo good.  The taquitos were crossed dipped multiple times in it.  They were also the perfect texture and temperature and were delicious.

The guacamole was the sole minor let down.  It was fresh and chunky but it lacked flavor.  This may be my own snobbery as I like to think I have the best guac recipe on the planet at my disposal and have a particular taste for it.  Basically I felt the salsa components were lacking but the crisp tortillas served with it were the perfect texture (I sound like a broken record) and delicious.  

We ended up splitting an order of flan for desert and it was exceptional.  I'm not really a big fan of flan but this was great stuff.  

Overall I loved the atmosphere.  The wait staff and the food was fantastic barring the blandish guac.  I think they are on to something good with this place and I plan to go back.
author: Ross A.

description: Groupon got us in, the food made us a fan. If you've ever wanted to experience gourmet mexican food, this is the place you want to check out. We had their homemade guacamole and it was devine. You can tell they used good quality avacados and they took time to prepare it. Also they have fresh homemade tortillas which are the best I've ever had. We had the pork entrees which were fantastic. No unwanted fatty pieces to chew and the preparation was A+. I just wish their prices were lower so I would be more motivated to go again, soon.
author: Kato D.

description:
I had brunch here with some friends a few weeks ago and really enjoyed myself.  Very friendly service, good food and very good sangria.  I can't quite tell you why it's missing that 5th star other than to say I really liked it, but I didn't love it.  I'll say this though: I'd happily go there again or recommend the place to a friend.

Oh, and if you do go make sure you try the guacamole!
author: Jonathan B.

description:
Very beautifully done space, serving delicious food in perfectly-sized portions.

Carne Asada con Ongos (melt-in-your-mouth)---5 stars.
Chile Verde (awesome with crisp green beans in it!)---5 stars.
Flautas (you don't have to feel TOO guilty getting these)---5 stars.
Lomo de Cerdo---5 stars.
Guacamole---5 stars.

Service is attentive and bilingual, and the owner can often be found behind the counter, cooking your food.

The ingredients are top quality, and the menu is straight-forward and direct.  The prices---another 5 stars.

I think that's around 30 stars so far, and counting.

I'm hooked, and will be back, over, and over, and over, and over again.

!Absolutamente delicioso!

UPDATE:  Went back and had the Mole con Pollo.  Heavens to Mergatroid, it was gooood....and I'm the biggest mole snob in the world.  Go Regalito, get ON with your baaaad self!  12 STARS!
author: Randy F.

description:
This was my second trip to this joint...I never took the time to write a review the last time.  Anyway, this cute little place is just kiddie corner from Luna Park and if you aren't looking you might just fly by it heading down Valencia.  Anyway, it's a pretty small space with more counter seating than tables.  This place was around before NOPALITO opened their doors...similar concept without the heritage.

Anyway, the food is clean, fresh and straight forward.  I wish I left some room for dessert, but after the chicken taquitos, chips & salsa, and the pollo regalito there was no room!  My only minor complaint is that the service is a bit slow.  There were only 2 servers for all the tables, but 3 cooks!  I'll probably be back...
author: Vince B.

description: Pretty underwhelming.  Very small portions and over-priced.  I had the carne asada special and I'm pretty sure we could of enjoyed a better meal across the street at Taqueria.
author: Krissy A.

description:
All but one dish we had was fairly yummy.  

We ordered the guacamole, sopa de tortilla, tinga de pollo ($15) and cochinta pibil ($16, pork)

The guacamole is a must.
The soup was a-ok, but nothing memorable.
The entrees we purchased were a lot of money for very few bites!
The tinga de pollo was great
The cochinta pibil was very bland.

Overall I would not recommend, due to the price for what you get.  Maybe stick to just getting a few appetizers?  Those were a good value.
  
I would have paid 10 for the pollo, and 8 for the pork.  It was VERY small and not very great.  Seems to be the trend for the last two places I have eaten =/  

If I do go back I'll try the mole!
author: Jason H.

description:
A solid four -- possibly a five, if I was still the slightest bit tipsy from the Sangria. 

Friday night, leaving Blondie's with no idea of where to go, only a faint grumbling in our tummies. But, Regalito is what I love about San Francisco, you can randomly walk into a place you've never noticed before and have a wonderful meal.

About six tables and a bar counter, Regalito magically combines clean and modern with warm and homey. Even though I'm not an avocado aficionado, the guacamole actually looked pretty good: fresh with lots of tomato and crisped whole corn tortillas for chips. The namesake rotisserie chicken was juicy and delicious. And the Chile Verde Stew was a stand-out... perfect amount of heat and tender meat. A little Sangria, a lot of good conversation and a perfect lovely meal... a new favorite!
author: Erin M.

description:
Very friendly staff--seriously, who quizzes customers with questions like, "What is the name of Atreyu's flying dragon-dog friend (in Neverending Story)?" (answer: "Falcor," duh)

I only ordered the margarita and pepitas w/ lime and chile. Very spicy!

My roommate ordered the roast chicken w/ lime marinade, and I got to taste some... It looked good, but the chicken was a bit dry and lacking in spice. Perhaps the chicken came from that big case w/ the heat lamps. :(

Decor was very polished--the tables have vinyl/plastic chairs (think: IKEA) but the bar has metal stools. (One reviewer here complained about the cold seats.) Small space--can get cramped when it's busy, but I saw it as "cozy"...

Overall, I wanted to give this place 4 stars, but ultimately had only 3-star food. A decent start, and I hope things improve soon! Don't go here if you're expecting homestyle Mexican food, but do if you want to try something different.
author: Richie K.

description:
This was a major disappointment on several levels. First off, the margaritas aren't made with tequila (they only have a beer/wine license); so you know this didn't bode well.
