The sangria is cheap, but there's a reason for that. It's like kool aid with a few tiny pieces of orange in it. This continued the run of shitty sangria I've had in this town. Get a beer.

The service was strange - the hostess/waitress was socially awkward, which is fine, but then maybe this isn't the best job for you.

Onto the food. I will not heat here again. Why? They have raised their prices from what's listed on menupages - and for no good reason. The food was average or below. The prices were above. I'm no mathematician, but that doesn't add up. My chille relleno was drowning in a really watery sauce - which makes no sense bc you fry something so it will be crispy (ideally) - but then you dump it in a watery sauce so it becomes a mushy mess? And, it still had no flavor. 

Beware - the "quesadillas" are actually empanadas and they rest on a bed of very spicy sauce. It was the only item I enjoyed (all 2 bites worth), but it almost took my man down. He's delicate.

The guac was just ok - lacking flavor punch, and served with the now infamous 3 fried tortillas. Luckily a nice busboy stopped and offered us a couple more so we could polish off our average guac.

Someone in the kitchen must be on a low sodium diet bc everything seemed to lack salt - and they don't even have salt shakers on the tables. I didn't bother asking for one for fear of getting charged.

The thing is, I would have paid the money and put up with the service if the food had been great - I would love to support a new local place trying to make it happen in the Mission. But this wasn't that.
author: Shal J.

description:
I really liked my recent visit there.
The food is all prepared fresh and has a genuine taste that is not found at your local taqueria. 

The enchiladas were oven roatsed, the corn fire broiled with chili powder, and the vanilla flan was great.
It was incredible to see them  make my guacamole straight for an avacado. Now that is fresh!
author: Joe R.

description: Yesterday was my second visit to Regalito and definitely not my last. The biggest standout of this spot is the FOOD! Yes, the atmosphere is nice, service is pretty good, and if you're lucky, like I was, you can snag one of the small tables out front and drink your margs in the sun. What I am so excited to share in this review is how damn good the food is! Each and every dish and drink is made by hand, with love and quality ingredients that shine in every bite. Need some extra heat? They bring you a jar of home made, totally bitchin' hot sauce! I didn't miss my cholula for a second. Fantastic guacamole, fish tacos, y agave wine margaritas made my day. I didn't see the corn with chile on the menu, which was a little sad, it is corn season after all! I hope they have it next week when I go back!
author: Kylie S.

description:
Awesome vibe. Great/authentic food. Good service. 

Reservation made for 8, but didn't get a seat until 8:30 (it's a relatively small place and very busy). Not a big deal as the manager was apologetic, understanding, and down-to-earth. Thought the sangria was average, the guac was fresh, and the empanadas amazing.
author: Troy B.

description: Tasty food! Sangrias are amazing! They have a lovely patio as well. Great for private parties.
author: Kalifornia S.

description: Service was excellent and the fresh guacamole is outstanding.  This is our second visit and last time we had the agave wine which was very good.
author: April M.

description:
I've lived in the Mission for 2 years, and as I'm a Mexican food fiend I can say they have been 2 well lived years. However, one thing I've always felt a bit missing was a Mexican place you could take a first date to and not feel like a cheap bastard. Pancho Villa is great after you've spent some time together, and Puerto Allegre is a great party place, but I had yet to find a more intimate sit down place to go.

Enter Regalito on 18th and Valencia. After walking by the day this place opened the curiosity got the best of me a week or two later. I've been here once more since, and the atmosphere and food are excellent. I had the enchilades verde and the chicken mole, both which I thoroughly enjoyed. I had the bread pudding both times, once was excellent, and the other time it seemed a bit uneven.

The service was great. The first time my girlfriend ordered a white sangria and I got the red. She wasn't a big fan of the white, and I took one for the team and switched. The waiter noticed and switched it for me without my asking. 

The other plus is the affordable prices. Entrees clock in at less than $10, and you get out with a couple of beers and plenty of food for around $35 for two. Excellent place, definite new favorite of mine.
author: simon m.

description:
Bland city, bland bland city.....

Okay me and my friend went there at the suggestion of some of his fellow co-workers. We have often traveled to Buen Sabor across the street and have often noticed this little place poking out from the block. Buen Sabor is more of your standard/authentic mission mexican fare.

He loves guac and so do I, and these coworkers had raved about it at Regalito. So what the hell...

Well the guac-Mole was OK, had plenty of thick cut veges in it, and not too salty. I had the Chili verde, and he had the Molé. Both were so-so, nothing to be excited about, and nothing terrible. Just "there." The rice-beans was the epitome of bland.

Place is nice and trendy, we went on a recent hot day so it was like an oven inside, but it didn't get to us. It get's one extra star because our waiter was this hot semi-muscular hairy guy. The food could have been terrible, but he easily made us forget our troubles.

More restaurants need waiters like him, after all maybe it wasn't the restaurant that was hot, but us? Hmmm.
author: Carlo F.

description:
I did this place backwards.  After first enjoying a wonderful Mexican meal this evening at Regalito, I just checked out the Yelpers who reviewed this place.  The food is wonderful and authentic, and the standards of the kitchen are top-notch. Finally, a restaurant to rival the meals I enjoyed in Cuernavaca. 

But I saw a lot of negative reviews from the burrito-eating public who think they know what Mexican food is.  Or they think mole is supposed to be a hot sauce.  Guess what -- if you think Chevy's is a Mexican restaurant, then maybe you should pass on Regalito.  

I had a fantastic (and very spicy) bowl of pozole to start, followed by a pungent chile verde pork stew.  The tortillas were delicious (not the crappy ones you get in most taco shops.)  Topped it off with a house-made sorbet.  Yes, it cost more than $7 dollars a person, too.
But so does the sushi bar down the street -- get over it.
author: Gary F.

description:
We ended up at Regalito when the line was too long for Puerto Allegre down the street. While the interior is cool and nicely designed, the food and service were ok. You pay for chips and salsa but we ordered guacamole which took a little too long to arrive given we sat across from the service window and nothing has to be made!

One friend ordered the mole chicken and he immediately complained about how dried out the chicken was. Someone else ordered the beef that was to be served with chipotle mashed potatoes but they "ran out" of mashed potatoes and so it was served with rice and no proactive explanation about the substitution until he asked. Everything was ok. Not special and not worth $45 person including 2 drinks (wine or beer).
author: Mariangela S.

description:
I have been here twice and i have left pleasantly content and happy! the food is as they all say not as spicy or condimented which i think is a good thing because it leaves you  feeling extremely heavy  and uncomfortable anyway if it is too condimented  especially if planning to go out drinking and dancing..as most latino restaurants..but it still is very tasty and fresh..i love the flautas..so good! and the guacamole was spectacular and a really good portion of it too! they make their own tortillas so they were really good too! and what was excellent was the desert!! the bred pudding with the caramel ice cream that day anyway was so light and fluffy!..
i would definately recommend it!
author: Maria C.

description: Great authentic Mexican food, go for any of the pork and beef dishes.  Ingredients are fresh and the tortillas are really good.  Skip the churros and go for the bread pudding. Can't say I like their green enchiladas ; they lack flavor but otherwise this place is awesome.
author: Eduardo M.

description:
I had high hopes for this place, but was ultimately disappointed. The "Pollo Libre" dinner-to-go for four people sounded like a great deal for just over $20. Walking away with the bag, I noticed it had pretty good heft, which made me want to get home even sooner.

Well-packaged, I unwrapped boxes for the whole chicken, rice, beans, and salsa, plus flour tortillas and crispy corn (whole) tortillas. The chicken was very tender, but surprisingly bland, as if the marinade didn't bother to soak past the skin. The rest of the sides were bland, too. Honestly, chicken at El Pollo Loco tastes better. Sorry.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
I kind of hate to write this since I have only been here once and I really wish my experience was better. But, eh....


It was totally bland. Entirely overpriced (with a two-for-one coupon yet!).We had a seriously inattentive waiter. The food took forever and we could see the people in the kitchen not really cooking....??! I don't know WHAT was going on....Even the decor was mediocre. 

It's totally possible that it was an off night, but I won't be going back to find out. 

Sorry Regalito.
author: C Z.

description: I went here with my brother and sister-in-law, both of whom have lived in New Mexico. We were drawn in by the simple menu and everything we ate was stellar. It's a little pricey, but if you want perfectly prepared high-quality Mexican food, this is your spot. You do pay for ambiance and attention to detail.
author: Brandy H.

description:
Boyfriend and I ate at Regalito after an exhausting and frustrating walkabout in search of a good place to eat a modestly priced, high-quality lunch-ish meal.

I'm not a fan of the Mexican food you find in San Francisco.  The taqueria culture here is pretty low-rent, where even mediocre joints are propped up as the "best" or "tastiest" or whatever.

So, it was with resignation that we sat down at a table at Regalito and pored over their promising (aren't they all?) menu.

Much to my surprise, the food was not only good, but good enough for me to want to return for at least a second try.  Let me qualify that by saying that I didn't find the food amazing or great by any measure, but it had heart and the quality of ingredients and cooking improved my mood.

Our lovely waitress was friendly and eager to suggest items.  Boyfriend ordered Pollo con Mole Negro.  I've had the pleasure of eating extraordinary, hand-made mole and was impressed at how close to perfection Regalito got it.  I only tasted the sauce, not the chicken, so I can't comment on the whole dish. Boyfriend enjoyed it thoroughly.

I had Cochinita Pibil, which is (to quote their menu) slow roasted, banana leaf wrapped, citrus & achiote marinated pork garnished with onions and cilantro.  The flavor profile was exquisite, which is a fancy way of saying the sauce and flavorings were spot on.  I wish the pork had been just a tad more succulent.

The taquitos were nothing to write home about, but I often react  that way to taquitos because their contents are often dry and uninteresting.  Can someone tell me if taquitos are anything more than crunch buried in sauciness?
author: Andrew L.

description:
So I tend to try new restaurants when I am starving which means the food is generally biased to everything tasting great. (Especially when I am hiking and just had chalky Cliff Bars)

After hiking all around Muir woods on Saturday morning a group of us decided to try out this semi-new restaurant. There was 7 of us and the first waiter told us they only had seats available at the bar. Then the second waiter sat us at a table in the corner. (Granted this place only has like five tables so our party was very large, in fact they used all the unused chairs at all the rest of the tables to seat us). 

Throughout the meal it was clear that the waiters were not communicating which definitely made the service suffer.

We got Guacamole to start which was served with a small amount of flat bread. The Guac was decent but definitely nothing to write home about and the serving of carbs was horrendously small.

The dishes we order spanned the small menu. Several people got breakfast which were basically Mexican scrambles. Probably the breakfast items were the best out of the dishes. I had the cactus salad which was simply cactus and salsa. It was good but unimaginative. Several people in the group tried the rotisserie chicken. The skin was a bit rubbery, it had no distinctive flavors, and not very tender.  Finally the last person in the group had a pork dish which they were sourly disappointed with.  She thought it tough and salty.

All in all I was disappointed. I thought the concept interesting and was excited to try a new variation on an old stand by (Latin Food).
author: Courtney R.

description:
Pros:
Nice decor
Tidy
Clean bathroom
Ritual coffee served in a french press
Crispy taquito shells
Yummy chorizo scrambled eggs

Cons:
Dry chicken
Bland, bland, bland (beans, taquito filling, tortillas, salsa, rice and the poor chicken again)
The driest brownie ever
Forgetful, inefficient service

I came here with a friend, with only one other table finishing their meal. That said, I expected quicker "on top of it" service. A few things... The food is just sooo bland. I wonder if the cooks even taste their food? At first I thought it was just me, but no... almost everything was bland (see above list).

And the chicken. For some reason I thought Regalito's specialty was their roasted chicken. For godsake it was so dry, lacking flavor. I appreciate it was free range, but they should do the bird some respect in making it juicy and delicious, so we may enjoy this bird in all its glory.

Although they were generally polite, the service is slow, forgetful and amateurish. I was annoyed when our server did not do a last check in before putting our bill on the table, prominently standing up, then he came back asking to pay up so he could cash out. That was either rude, or dumb, if he didn't realize what he was doing. They forgot our tortillas with our food, but did finally bring the bland things to us. They forgot other things we asked for till we reminded them. I hate that... It makes me feel like I'm being a pest. I also don't like paying $3.50 for coffee and getting only milk, but no half and half (but that's just me).

If Regalito can step up on the flavor and service, I'll come back here. I really wanted to like this place, but for now I'll go elsewhere.
author: Antoi C.

description: totally mediocre, I was terribly disappointed at the food. Way too expensive for what you get. Bland food, not authentic and small portions. The only reason they get 1 star is because the staff was friendly and attentive.
author: Karla D.

description: Good, fresh classic mexican food and friendly smiling waiters.  decent prices and not a huge wait. overall, cute place for a date or a chill night with friends. i will def be back
author: Michael R.

description:
Regalito is perfect.  I've been there about 3 times now and I love everything about this place.  It's small, but not too small, the service is fast and friendly, and the food is really good. 

When I think of all the different Mexican restaurants in San Francisco, Regalito is probably the best.  The food is fresh, clean, authentic, and affordable.  There are probably people who will say Regalito is for only for gringos and that may be true.  Since I am a gringo, I don't have a problem with that.

There are so many good Mexican restaurants in the Bay Area.  There's old school places like Tommy's on Geary, Puerto Allegre, Los Jarritos,or even Mi Lindo Yucutan.  Taco trucks like El Tonayense or tacquerias like La Tacqueria, El Farolito, and Cancun.  Then there's overpriced restaurants for yuppies like Dona Tomas or Tres Agaves. 

To me, Regalito stands above and beyond all of these.  There are probably some people who aren't willing to pay a little more for Mexican food.  However, when you consider the high quality of the food, the freshness of their ingredients, good deseign, and excellent service I can understand why they have to make up for it.  

I think Regalito is worth it and hope it stays around for a long time.
author: Ezra Y.

description:
First time of many. I'm surprised by the negative comments about the staff -- both my boyfriend and I were taken aback by how gracious the host and staff were. 

There was a large party taking place and because the kitchen was backed up a little bit, they brought out free appetizers to the table next to us (they had been then longer). Then, because they were out of the tamales I had wanted, they gave me a free entree. Really unexpected and not necessary, but appreciated. 

Did I mention the food was scrumptious? Let's be honest -- when I got to a Mexican restaurant, it's not because I'm on a diet. But this place actually seemed healthy. The food was prepared fresh and had wonderful flavor. 

Don't forget to wash it down with sangria...
author: Sara W.

description:
Went for a semi-official meet up with fellow citybloggers mattymatt and Rita; we went early, and the place was fairly empty, so the small size didn't bother me at all. Seemed cozy, really.

We indulged in a little Sangria, which really is pretty good! The other two times I'd been there, I'd tried wine. The list is small but everything I've had has been really quite good.

I think the sides and apps here tend to be the stars of the show -- on a previous visit I'd had the spiced pepitas, which kick ass. Also tried the fried tortillas (aka big ol' chips) and guac -- not too bad! And, I must say, the rice and beans that came with my chicken were somehow divine -- flavorful, perfectly fluffy rice; perfect ratio of rice to beans. It's hard to get something so simple so right, since everybody does it.

I was frankly less impressed with the chicken, which I'd say was only okay. The skin was loose and flabby; I prefer at least part of the chicken skin to show that it's been, well . . . roasted. Some evidence of flame.

Anyway, I really like this place -- even as I'm giving it three stars due to the bird, which is supposed to be the star, isn't more than average. 

Now if it was called "Regalito Sides and Apps," I'd give it a 4.

I really do dig the atmosphere.
author: Jer N.

description: Dear Gawd, that food is muy excellente! My sister and I agreed, "it's like a fiesta in your mouth!" The menu is very small but what they do, oh, do they doodlee-do it well! I had the (vegetarian) chili rellenos, filled with winter squash in a creamy oaxacan cheese sauce, accompanied with fantastic, smokey black beans. My sister had chicken enchiladas in a green chili tomatio sauce. Both dishes were so unique and so TOTES FLAVAFLAVE! For dessert we shared a layered sponge cake with 3 milk frosting that was TO DIE! The service was excellent, with our wonderful waiter being as excited about the food as we were. This little restaurant is one helluva discovery. I kinda hate writing about it because I don't want to EVER have to wait for a table .... but then, what a hog I would be not to share, so .... Merry Christmas everybody. Consider this a pinata from me to you!
author: Kimber S.

description: The food is fantastic and fresh, organic, reasonably priced for the quality, and the proprietors are *so nice* and courteous.  I'm a fan. I've dined there 3 times now over the course of a year, and it's always a positive experience.
author: Kris A.

description:
Came for lunch after the Carnaval Parade and was impressed by the looks of the place and the menu.  Waited 20 minutes for a table, and about 25 minutes more for food, once ordered.  Things at the other tables looked appetizing.

Ordered Green Chicken Enchiladas and Chicken in Oaxacan Mole.  The enchiladas tasted of tomatillos and nothing else - just a rather watery sour sauce.  The Mole was inedible for me - sweet, none of the bitter chocolate character I like and an odd aftertaste.  The beans were tasty and the rice was ok.  The table salsa was simply extremely hot without much additional flavor.  The price was on the very high end for the quantity and quality.

Can't see why they were busy.  I guess I've gotten spoiled eating in the superior Mexican cafes in Redwood City.
author: T T.

description: The pork shoulder was super soft and tasty along with the black beans. My friend had the chicken and it was bland and not that hot and potatoes were "aiight". Homemade tortillas were nice. The Tamarindo agua fresca was "okay"- overall an overpriced decent experience. I would wanna go back just to try some other dishes but it is definitely over priced for what you get.
author: Genaro R.

description:
Note: I've been 4 times in 6 weeks - I have upgraded Regalito to a 5 (for food only - Service is staying at a steady 3.5) - I can't stay away from this place and am in love with the Enchiladas Rojoas. Yum! (oh, and I had two desserts again...damn them!)

Chef Tomas of Regalito has got something good going on in the Mission.  Mole with depth and silky richness, flautas that are crispy and delicate without being too heavy - also with a veggie friendly option of potato and cheese.  The house lime-ade is perky with mint and very refreshing.

I hate to admit it, because I am a delicate flower of a girl, but I had two desserts.  (Shameful) the bread pudding had layers of flavor including fabulous vanilla ice cream, apples, almonds, cheese (yes, cheese) and spices.  And also the Flan.  I am very picky about flan.  This is excellent flan people - Chef Tomas has played with the recipe for the last 6 weeks and its finally perfect.. I however, loved every version I tried. Also chocolate torte was decadent without being over the top.

Hope you go and enjoy as I did.  The staff is friendly and the place is cozy while still being open and airy.  Its a winner! 

(If you are a snob, go elsewhere...this is a friendly place for nice but low key dining.)
author: Alicia W.

description:
First, let's talk about the tequila issue.  Personally, I don't believe any decent sit-down mexican joint can exist without tequila.  Little taquerias where you go to get your burrito and taco fix are exempt from this, of course.  El Castilito and Papalote are great for a quick bite, especially after a ride, and beer is just fine.  

But for a nicer place when you want a big plate of food with beans and rice and everything else, you must have tequila for the margaritas.  The agave wine they serve with their "margaritas" is an affront to all that is right and holy about good mexican.  First, it tastes like crap and second, get ready for the headache that comes before you leave the restaurant from such cheap, poorly made wine.

Now I understand that they don't have a liquor license, which may be beyond their control, but that doesn't make it right.  And what's worse than not having tequila for a margarita, is putting margaritas on your menu when you don't have tequila!  It's like advertising you have beer, but then only serving non-alcoholic brew.  Es muy malo! 

As for the food, not that impressed.  I had the carnitas which came out very dry served with beans and salsa.  Not nearly enough beans were served and they were mediocre.  There were big chunks of pork, but
without enough carbs to go with it, it was not a very satisfying meal - and like I said, quite dry, like a desert in my mouth.

A friend had the chicken mole.  It wasn't bad - the mole was spicy with good flavor.  The guacamole was pretty good and like some of the other reviewers, we had to ask for more of their giant chips.  The Barbera wine was  good and very reasonable at $23 and the girl serving us was generally attentive and accommodating.  The prices seemed reasonable too.

Overall, not a bad place, but you have to ask yourself, with so many excellent mexican places around, what's the point?  They are obviously trying not to be a simple down-home mexican food place with enchiladas and chimichangas.. Their menu is smallish and tries to offer something a little higher-end, but without the tequila or great execution of what they do offer, it just falls flat for me.
author: Eric F.

description:
The service isn't as bad as you might believe from the reviews; however, the serving staff is young and not full of enthusiasm.

The guac is great, corn on the cob is the best I've had.  The prices are good.
author: Jason J.

description:
Like many people who have grown up in California, I have been eating Mexican food my whole life.  I have traveled extensively throughout Mexico, lived in Los Angeles, and have been eating and cooking Mexican food for as long as I can remember.   

When I came across Regalito, I was thrilled to see a beautiful, classy restaurant that embodies my values in serving free-range, organic chicken with local ingredients.  I had high hopes that Regalito would demonstrate the breadth of Mexican cooking beyond what is typically found in the taqueria.  Unfortunately, I was pretty disappointed.  I felt that too many elements were not fresh (commercial tortillas!), lacked flavor, and disappointed in execution.   The kitchen is open to seats at the bar, and if I hadn't seen my meal being made in front of me, I might question my disappointment.   

We started with Chicken Taquitos and Ensalada de Nopalitos (cactus).  The taquitos were pulled our of a warming tray below the stove, and warmed before serving.  Flavorless, not crispy, and you can get better for a third of the price anywhere on the block.  The Ensalada de Nopalitos was basically nopalitos out of a jar, thrown on to the grill for a minute, with salsa on top.  Nothing special about this, nothing you couldn't do in your house, and for $8.50, I expected better (a big jar costs about $2.50 at any grocery store).  

The reason Regalito gets two stars instead of none is their Cochinita Pibil (slow-cooked pork served in a banana leaf).  This was the only thing I tried that one can't find down the street better and cheaper in any taqueria, and it was AWESOME.  Flavorful, cooked to perfection, and made up for the tortillas not being fresh or homemade.  

Dessert was the last straw with the lack of freshness here.  We had the Capirotada (warm bread pudding with vanilla ice cream).  Upon ordering, we found out that they were out of vanilla ice cream, and only had mango or avocado.  We ordered the avocado on the side, which was great, but definitely didn't go with bread pudding with apples and raisins.  It became obvious that the bread pudding came from the fridge, the inside was cold.  Maybe not microwaved for long enough?  I can't believe that I'm writing that about a $7.00 dessert that was already missing its ice cream.  

I want to say something good here, for the sake of their amazing Cochinita Pibil, but for the size of our bill, I was pretty disappointed.  Maybe breakfast would be better?  

I would recommend that this place think carefully about what it is trying to do and figure out how to make itself better than any taqueria down the street.  Homemade tortillas, attention to detail, and making taqueria favorites stand out would be a good start.
author: Emily S.

description:
Went here yesterday. Had the chile relleno, enchiladas rojas, enchiladas verdes with chicken, the corn, and gaucamole. None of it was exceptional. The chicken enchiladas were bland, as was the white rice and pinto beans that were served along side. The guacamole was ok, it was served with taco sized tortillas that are fried, but for a whole bowl of guacamole we got only 3 tortillas and repeatedly had to ask for more tortillas so we could finish the guacamole. The enchiladas rojas were swimming in a plate of sauce, couldn't even find them in there, and I'm not sure I could taste the cheese if there was any. 

Pros: the place is nice and clean and well decorated. 

Cons: over priced for the quality, no taste, tiniest portions
author: parker p.

description:
What a disappointment!

I had been wanting to go to Regalito for months, after noticing the nice "face lift" of the building and, after peeking inside, really liking the interior. I had also heard good things about the place. Okay, no one really raved about amazing gourmet moments, but people seemed to like it, so even though I did not expect a foodie epiphany there, I at least expected some good Mexican fare - maybe with a modern twist.

Unfortunately, lunch last week did not include any of the above:
we shared three smaller dishes from the lunch menu, plus some guacamole & chips - but non of the dishes lived up to any expectations ...

I was not expecting to be blown away by a culinary surprise, but when it comes to Mexican, especially in the Mission, you expect authentic, well seasoned food - that's yummy.

Too bad, but everything we ordered, including the guacamole, was completely underseasoned (=bland). Using my ice tea's lemon and some salt we got the guacamole to a certain taste, but the Ensalada de Nopalitos (grilled cactus salad) and Taquitos de Pollo (fried tacos with chicken) were plain boring - and I cannot even remember dish #3, which is not a good sign ...

Unfortunately, service did not help our experience:
as other yelpers mentioned before, we were seated at the bar without question, although tables were available. When we ran out of chips halfway into the guacamole & asked for some more, we received an additional stack (I counted 5!) - and later noticed a whopping $1 charge on the bill - which I do not mind paying, but wouldn't you expect the waitress to point out that they were not free - like everywhere else ...

Overall, a pricey but not exciting lunch, rather mediocre food lacking the pro service you expect at these prices  ...
author: Francis S.

description:
Disappointed with Brunch. Came back for Dinner only because we have a Groupon (coupon).

Brunch:

The good: Guacamole served with tostadas was alright, and the Sangria was good.  Fruit with cinnamon cream was yumm as a brunch app.  Staff was checking on table regularly and other waitresses helped when needed.

The bad:  Ceviche was horrible, food slightly overpriced.  I had the chilequiles, which were $10 for some scrambled eggs and tortilla chips - no meat.  It was only average, but the tortillas were housemade and pretty good.  Wait time between appetizer and entree was about 20+ minutes .. for eggs ... seriously.

Dinner:

The good:  Housemade tortillas with papas and chorizo as an app, beer served in mugs instead of bottles, dishes not lacking in flavor.

The bad:  Eye contact made by two staff members in open kitchen upon arrival, but nothing spoken.  Waiter asked us to wait a moment while he input a table's order, then took a phone-in order.  Staff behind kitchen finally came out to greet us. We said we have a reservation under xxx name to which she asked "Do you have a reservation?  What name?"  Cheapest entree on the dinner menu is $14 (for enchiladas?).  The half chicken is $15 served with sides, but was small for the cost and was also dry/overcooked in parts.  Compared to half chicken at Firewood Cafe, this is a bad deal.  Portion sizes for entrees were generally small for the prices.  Price for dinner was $60~ for 4 Mexican beers, 1 app, 2 entrees.

Likely to not return to or recommend this restaurant.
author: Gary M.

description: Went there a few months ago with my hot date and was excited to try the highly proclaimed Regalito in the Mission. Got there 45 mins before closing, was a little worried that we were going to get the end-of-the-day  type of service. But service was Great! Very clean. We sat at the bar, started with some sangria, ordered a bunch of goodies.. Everything was delicious!!! I loved it!
author: Charlie A.

description:
I love a place where you can watch the chef's cook up your food and this is one of those places.  As soon as my friend and I walked in we immediately adored it.  The ambiance is great and we were greeted with a wonderful host and decided to take a seat at the bar.  It was only two of us so it was quite easy to face each other and talk when most people find it difficult to do so.  Wow, my torso actually has a purpose and my chair can actually rotate a bit.  What a concept.  (Of course when you have a party of any more than two this can be a bit of a workout for your obliques.)   

Our waiter came and was so wonderful.  He explained all the food, the concept, and assured us everything was wonderful.  We ordered the agave margarita to sip while we waited for our food, the Taquitos (with potato and chicken) and tinga de pollo.  The taquito's were yummy and full of flavor and not greasy at all.  I am a BIG fan of chipotle and the tinga del pollo nailed it.  All were absolutely delicious.  I can't wait to go back and try everything else.

It's priced for what it is and I love how they don't have disgusting Cheesecake Factory portions where as soon as you get your plate you want to vomit.  

Everybody else is right on the small space so minus one star for that...they definitely need a tad more room there.
author: Gemma S.

description: This is what i imagine great Mexican food is about.  Of course you pay more than if you went to a taqueria but it was worth it.  There is a time and place for cheap and cheerful but i wanted flavorful, beautifully presented,  distinct food.   You can taste the different flavors and they were spectacular.  Service was amazing - friendly, attentive and i must say, they were very patient.  There was an annoying, demanding,  high maintenance woman next to me and the server was kind and cheerful.   I would've loved some kind of signature drink - like their own spin on sangria or other wine based drink.  I will be returning for their dinners.
author: Katherine K.

description: This place is pricy, but worth every penny. I had been here a couple of years ago and had told my husband that I really wanted him to try it. We don't live in the city but I work here. So finding an opportunity where we were both in SF was hard. When we saw that there was a Groupon out for them, we found it to be the perfect excuse. We came with our daughter and really took advantage of the fact that we don't come out often by ordering everything we could in hopes to experience as much of the menu as possible. It was truly fantastic and my husband loved it as much as I thought he would. Parking is challenging as it is in most of the city. I was reminding of why we did not have a car when we did live here. The service was great and the ambiance was lively. It was a really nice dining experience overall.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
I tried this place tonight after being told Luna Park had a wait of 45 minutes for a table.  45 minutes! Seriously!?

We drank Modelo's while waiting for our food which arrived fresh, well seasoned and perfectly cooked.  We shared a starter of Potatoes and Chorizo - it was huge and very tasty. A great start!

For my main I chose the salmon special which was an enormous fillet and cooked perfectly, served with spinach and rice.  My dinner date had Macchata which was served with tortillas and also tasted great.  Prices were very reasonable ($60 for two people including 4 drinks).  We sat at the bar which suits us fine, we could chat quietly and watch the chefs at work.. 

The staff were friendly, without being OTT.  I would definitely go again, it's a lighter take on Mexican food which I really liked and a great place for a quiet, chilled dinner.
author: Angela M.

description:
For $17, I got a chicken enchilada with a bone in it. My husband couldn't get our server's attention to request no sour cream on his plate. We watched our rice and beans sit up in the service window for 10 minutes, while we still didn't have our drinks. It was all brought to us very nonchalantly at the same time even though we were sitting right there at the bar observing the whole operation.

Sadly, we live nearby but won't be back. We would have been happier at a taqueria spending a third of the money on better food.
author: Sandra M.

description: Lured by a Groupon coupon for dinner....  Shared the Papas con chorizo, Pollo con mole, and Tacos Pescado.  All items looked well prepared, but nothing really stood out.  The chicken was very moist and tender, but the mole sauce was lacking.  The fish tacos were ok, but I've had better for cheaper.  Papas con chorizo was our appetizer but came after we had to remind the waiter of the order... Even the Negra Modelo seemed flat (how did that happen?)  Without the discount it would have been pricey for what we ate.  I didn't go in with any expectations and left without any impressions.
author: Will W.

description:
I wanted to like this place. I really did. Good service, charming interior. However, this was literally one of the worst meals I've ever had at a restaurant. I dine out multiple times a week and have NEVER complained about food until I came here. It was that bad.

I had the enchiladas. Which were essentially folded tortillas with mole sauce on them. Bad. Really bad. My date had a nightly special, which were essentially beef skewers brushed in some sort of sauce. Not only was it lacking in flavor, but half of the pieces weren't even edible the beef has so much gristle. Despite not having eaten for the last 9 hours, neither of us could even finish half of our food. It comical just how bad it was.
author: Brendon S.

description: Grossly overpriced for relatively skimpy servings of just-average Mexican food! $120 for party of 4 (only one glass of beer & 3 desserts) is FAR too much to pay for low-average food. Server new (had to reminded to bring rice/beans); bill as delivered was incorrect. Wish we had gone elsewhere.
author: Grant T.

description:
After a failed attempt to watch the Red Bull soap box races with the 10,000 other fans in Dolores Park, my friend and I settled for lunch at Regalito. A more upscale, gourmet Mexican place like this definitely stands out among all the taco trucks and mom and pop Mexican joints in the Mission, but I thoroughly enjoyed it. The inside is small and a wee bit crowded, but it feels cozy and is decorated in nice citrus colors. 

We started with some chips and delicious homemade salsa, after which I had the best tortilla soup I've ever tasted. All too often I find that the tortilla strips are soggy, the avocado is tasteless and the flavors of the soup are unintelligible. Not so at Regalito. Their's is absolutely delicious and I highly recommend it. Next came the cactus salad... good, but not really my cup of tea. I liked the queso fresco and fresh avocado, but the cactus itself didn't really do it for me. It was sort of pickled-tasting and had an odd texture. However, I think that is more just my own personal aversion to cactus and not the restaurant's fault. My dining companion had the pulled pork, which she was kind enough to share with me, and it was delicious as well, although a bit on the oily side.

All in all I think this a great little spot, although I think I'd recommend going when they're not too busy, as the seemed a little overwhelmed by the crowds and our service wasn't great.
author: Lindsey S.

description: Want an authentic Mexican food restaurant? Walk one block away from this place to any taqueria on mission instead. We walked in and sat down at 8pm, had to ask for help at around 8:15, and as I'm typing this at 8:50pm on my phone, we are still waiting for our food. When we ask whats going on we get the run around. I will never come to this place ever again. Ever....
author: lala d.

description:
so heres the deal. this place, its a little off the beaten path for most tourists. but listen, if youre getting tired of rain forest cafe, bubba gumps or clam chowder on the wharf this is the place for you. if youre not tired of bubba gumps, rain forest cafe or clam chowder, regalito is definitely the place for you. seriously, put on your big boy britches and drive yourself to the mission. its between mission and valencia, so if you're more comfortable take valencia. but when you hit 18th go left. 

dont scimp on the guac, guac will start to make sense for you after you try it here. 

dont miss the tortillas, they make my fiance cry in the best kind of way. 

ive yet to eat anything bad here. tinga de pollo is my favorite. its like something called flavor took steriods (in the most organically appropriate way of course) and dove into that there chicken and black bean concoction where it lived happily ever after. 

conchinita pibil is a pork, wrapped in some kind of leaf and steamed kind of deal. i ordered it half expecting the experience to stop after presentation. nope. every bite made me regret every mexican meal i had ever eaten up until that point.

also try the chile relleno. its a little different take on regular chille relleno in that they incorporate squash and a wonderful mole esque sauce. 

order the bread pudding or churros for dessert. if you get the churro ask your server to tell the chef you prefer the churros a little under fried, leaving the very center a tad bit doughy. trust me on this one.

plan on spending from 15 to 20 bucks to eat and a soft drink. if you order beer or wine it goes up from there a little, obviously. if you dont try this place, i feel really really bad for you. just saying.
author: Jarred D.

description:
My honey and I snuck into Regalito on a busy Friday night. We didn't realize there was a wait and walked straight in and sat at the bar, they didn't ask us to leave so we dined. 

We started with the Taquitos de Pollo y Queso, tasty! Then we had the Pollo Regalito, again tasty and light. Our side order was corn on the cob with mayo and chile peppers.. sounded weird but we liked it!

I'll definitely try this place again.
author: Monica S.

description: Great food, had the mole and rancheros.  We did have to wait for a while but it was well worth it.
author: Shima N.

description:
terrible service. I am a very generous and forgiving person, but ignore me once, fine you're busy, ignore me twice, okay you're new.....ignore me for 15minutes while walking by me 12 times ( Yes I COUNTED!!!) and you will get a small tip and a bad review.

This place has a lot of potential....that clearly has not yet been actualized. Great wall colors, beautiful art and a really yummy asthetic. But poor space layout with the bar. They had to force everyone that came in who was less than a party of 4 to go sit at the bar. That's bad!!!!

The food, meh.

Guacamole and Deep Fried Tortillas ----- AWESOME!!!

The Enchiladas Rojas - blahk. Are tortillas folded up a gazillion times with crazy spice mole sauce and some cabbage and a pinch of cheese that's not even melted considered an enchilada? "Got Milk" commercials kept running through my head as I dry heaved the tortillas.

Seriously, the terrible service is what put this place into the 'no friend zone'. Our waiter didn't even try, he was too busy being cool and keeping his shirt unbuttoned to his navel (which was probably pierced bringing him to an even greater douche level) all the while treating us like we were this huge imposition.

If you are a vegetarian do not go here unless you want to order guacamole. You will be very dissapointed.
author: K B.

description: Enchiladas Verdes was delicious and better w/a Tamarind!
author: Cathy F.

description:
Yum, yum and yum! I tried this place for the first time last week and I will definitely be back. A fresh mexican taste with a simple ambiance are the two reasons that I will go back to Regalito.

I had the cactus salad starter which was delicious! I'd never had cactus before and it was very nice. I compare it to okra, a little slimy in consistency, but very tasty. I also had one of the pork entrees (can't remember the name), but it was seasoned well and super tender. My favorite part was the warm corn tortillas that melt in your mouth. Throw in a Negra Modelo and you've got a seriously happy belly. I didn't try dessert, so yet another reason to go back. 

The service was prompt and friendly and the place is simple and cute. We sat in the back of the restaurant near the kitchen and we didn't stink of food when we left - always a bonus!
author: Jenny S.

description:
I've grown up eating Mexican food and from the whole spectrum of cheap (taco truck) to expensive ($20 plates), delicious (Mexico City) to disgusting (at home--sorry Mom!)

I had the Regalito Rosticeria, 1/2 roast  of free-range chicken served with green beans, for a steep $14.00.  Since the place is named for rotisserie I expected this little bird to be ripe with flavor, tender and moist, like a slow-cooked hen should be.  Unfortunately, the chicken was dry and surprisingly flavorless.  I at least expected it to have a little seasoning, but it could have been a cooked pigeon.  I tasted no garlic.  I tasted no spices.  

Sadly, I would rather eat El Pollo Loco and it would be half the price.  Granted, the food here seems healthy enough, but we all know, you don't go for Mexican food for your health.  

For the record, the sangria was excellent.

== edit  ===
After reading some of these reviews, I'm beginning to realize the very low expectations the locals have of Mexican food.  So sad.  Check back with me, when I find some real Mexican food worth yelping about.
author: Rion S.

description:
Jose, our server, was top drawer

The food I ordered was great, the lime marinated pork on banana leaf. We had the guac for an appy and it was sensational.

Would definitely come back for more. thought it was totally great!
author: Jim O.

description: Sangria and salsa was good.had the mole Chicken and was a bit disappointed.  Might have to try another main dish. waitstaff was polite. quiet place.. good for romantic evening but i was in a hurry that day =(
author: Tiff W.

description: I've never had a bad meal here and, the staff is so friendly and awesome Oh, how I love everything on the menu. Try the Mole. This place is tiny tiny, so it probably wouldn't be good for huge groups, but two to four people, perfect.
author: Kat M.

description:
Where the white people go for mexican food. The only thing I have really liked here is the Mole stilo Oaxaca. Be warned, it is very spicy. 

I like Colibri in union square a bit better. 

The staff has always been nothing but nice.
author: danny e.

description:
Delicious Mexican Food that isn't the usual "glop"

If you want to taste some great Mexican dishes that are a change of pace from the "usual" Mexican food found in most restaurants, particularly chains, then this is the place to go.

It was Cinco De Mayo weekend and we were craving for some Mexican and I found this little gem online.
It's a tiny place but very modern inside and very clean.  The staff is nice.
The food was delicious, particularly the Chile Verde and the Carne Asada y Hongos
author: M. E. F.

description:
My boyfriend and I have been stuck in a rut for the last few months -- always going to the same old neighborhood places.  So a few weeks ago, we decided to give Regalito a try.  We both really liked it!

We showed up pretty early on a Wednesday or Thursday and were seated at the bar.  They seemed a little short on staff, so we did wait a while to place our order, but the staff that were there were really nice and friendly.

I ordered the posole, guacamole, and an agave wine margarita and thought all were delicious!  Best guacamole I've had outside of mexico, and the margarita was unexpectedly awesome.  I think my boyfriend liked his pork dish a little less, but we liked Regalito enough to come back the following Sunday for brunch.  Tortilla soup = also tasty!

The prices are a little higher than expected, but I found the food to be worth it.  If you're looking for bottomless chips or margaritas the size of your head, stick to Chevy's or the taco truck.  If you're looking for a meal at a nice restaurant that happens to be Mexican, then give Regalito a try.
author: Julia K.

description: Always a fan of watching food being prepped in near sight.  Fresh and good, fresh pressed tortillas, good grilled corn, fresh fried tostadas.
author: Arcelia G.

description: Hands down the best Mexican food in the Mission (and trust me, I don't say that lightly). We went last Tuesday for the special 'pork night' and all 5 of us absolutely loved our meals. The staff was great, we'll be coming back often.
author: Andy M.

description:
I went for a late lunch/brunch Sunday and the place was empty. Ordered the CHILAQUILES VERDES- delicious. Everything was very fresh. 

Minuses: Not too many vegetarian options (enchiladas looked good, but all had meat). And I would have loved some chips when we sat down.

Overall: I would definitely try it again!
author: Rosie M.

description: Walked here after catching a flick at the Roxie.  We were early for our reservation and sat at the bar -- we ended up just staying and it was great.  Started with the taquitos appetizer and then had the chile relleno.  Portions are perfect for sharing.  This is not "over the top" Mexican food, and that's just fine, but it is a nice upgrade from the many local taquerias.  The ingredients were fresh and tasty and the service was attentive but not intrusive.  Great spot!
author: Paul Y.

description:
So I had a first date at Regalito.  I had just returned from Japan that week and a month without authentic SF mission Mexican cuisine had put my culinary palette in an uproar.  Moreover, hiking around Mt. Tam for most of the afternoon gave First Date and I two Hungry Man Meal - sized appetites. 

Still undecided upon Regalito,  I pulled into the bus stop in front of Regalito as First Date went into the restaurant to assess the reservation situation and menu. He exited Regalito with two thumbs up.  Hopping back into the care excitedly, First Date relayed that he tried to make a reservation, but they insisted that currently we didn't need one, so he told them that we were coming back and just needed to find a parking space.   We did parking reconnaissance  for 30 minutes and considered ordering a bevi from Farina in order to make use of their valet parking lot next door to Regalito before finding a park in front of the theater on 17th Street off of South Van Ness where I saw a poetry slam judged by Beth Lisick back in the mid '90s.

With appetites in hand, First Date and I walked into Regalito.   Recognizing First Date, the host  promised us expedient seating. 

"It wasn't this crowded when I came in here .  I would have made reservations," First Date said with a tinge of disappointment.  

Some time later, the host remorsefully informed us that only bar seating, which I am not a fan of, was available.  Hunger and my desire to make a good first impression superseded.  We gingerly took our seats at the bar facing the two man/one tortilla lady kitchen. 

I went to the bathroom and implored First Date to order apps.  Upon my return from Regalito's poorly lit and sparsely decorated excuse for a bathroom, First Date informed me that despite valiant efforts, he had yet to order apps.  After a couple minutes, the host, now our waiter or "haiter," greeted us and began reciting the Regalito schpeel  when he stopped himself midsentence and apologetically informed us that he had to seat an incoming group of patrons and would return shortly.

First Date and I exchanged a silent glance that said, "Are you serious?"

"He's lucky he's cute," First Date said as I nodded in agreement. 

As the bottomless water with lime, made possible by the deft front house help, quenched my hike - parched throat our haiter returned.  He succinctly extrapolated the specials from memory and when I asked for a replay of the last dish he  delved into a culinary monologue describing the lamb shank in a apricot/avocado leaf sauce served with  beans and rice, the earthy taste given to the sauce by the avocado leaf, and the regions from which the other elements of the dish hailed.  At the end I was sure whether to order or clap.  All things considered I order the lamb shank special and First Date ordered our Tortilla Soup, nopalitos salad, and the Regalito lime marinaded chicken with sauteed greens for his entree.

First Date commented that the bar seating was terribly undesirable for conversation, let alone a first date, but we made the most of it and enjoyed ourselves despite the constant traffic of restaurant staff visiting the bar to pick up entrees and apps on their way to hungry patrons.

The warm nopalitos salad with grilled cactus was really tasty and well grilled. It provided a good contrast to the tepid onion,
tomatoes, and garlic and cold queso [super] fresco and avocado.  I usually stick to nondairy cheeses, but the queso [super] fresco had me asking our haiter if they had a quesero in the back.  The tortilla Soup was pleasantly spicy without numbing your taste buds and and flavorful, but despite being made from chicken broth I didn't taste any hint of  chicken. To each their own, I like a little bit of chicken in my chicken broth.

First Date's chicken was well prepared, doubtless to say - they know how to roast chicken, but he found the meat to be dry.

Upon tasting, I agreed and also noted that Regalito had some how made lime marinade synonymous with bland.  

I was excited about my lamb shank, but my elation found no cause.  The lamb shank was an excellent cut of meat with little fat and a average amount of meat on the bone comparable to a small turkey drumstick, but First Date found the meat to be a bit dry.  We both found the apricot/avocado leaf sauce covering the lamb terribly disappointing.  Only the color of the sauce recalled the apricot from our haiter's expounding .  The earthiness of the sauce attributed to the avocado leaf over powered any other flavors the chef attempted to bring out of the dish.  The whole pinto beans and rice lacked flavor and added nothing to the meal.  I tried them several times independently and with different combinations of chicken, lamb, and apricot sauce on tortillas to no avail.  But at least the tortillas were good.  Thanks Tortilla Lady.
author: Eric J.

description:
Used a Green Zebra coupon here - that's what prompted me to try this restaurant. The dishes were well executed - my chicken was moist, flavorful & tender & my wife's pork was tender and flavorful as well - and the the service was attentive and swift.

Also, the bread pudding for desert was quite excellent and big enough to share for two people. 

I waited several days to do this review so I can't remember the finer details of our dining experience but bottom line is that I will eat here again. And with so many good restaurants to choose from in this city the fact that it's good enough to bring me back again constitutes an above average review.
author: Rex W.

description:
Passed by here on a foggy cool evening in early August, and decided to stop in for dinner.  I was feeling like something warm and comforting, and I was SO HAPPY I ordered a bowl of the tortilla soup. I wasn't expecting perfection, but that's what I got. Tiny cubes of queso fresca, avocado chunks, and torn dried ancho chiles floating in a tomato broth with fresh little tortilla strips strewn about and a good dose of spice. The next time I have a cold, I am coming here and ordering 3 bowls of the stuff.

We also had guacamole (pricey, but good, and they give you a huge bowl of it, plus awesome fresh chips) and the chicken mole with rice (the chicken literally FELL OFF THE BONE).  

The staff were friendly. The ambiance was cool. And a couple guys with an accordian and a guitar came in to serenade the crowd. Damn fine evening.
author: Clare M.

description:
Food: Had the Pollo Con Mole Negro, friend had the Lomo de Cerdo (roast pork). Flavors were good (clean and light; nearly bordering bland) and both incredibly moist. Also started with the spiced toasted pumpkin seeds which were alright, if just a little salty. Good to snack on though. Had a carafe of sangria as well, which was fine, but not one of the better ones we've had in the Mission. Ended up being about $50 for the two of us, which might seem like a bit for Mexican food, but probably worth it.

Service: No issues here. Was toward the end of the night, so things were slowing down, but we were served and checked up on without any problems. 

Ambiance: bright, modern decor on the inside. I loved that we were stitting at the counter and watching every move of the cooks.
author: Alex C.

description:
Enchiladas verdes were very good. Mild but not bland. The white onions sliced on top added a lot of flavor to each bite, so make sure not to push those aside. 

The mole was excellent, and the chicken was roasted to perfection. Enough to eat for dinner and take some home for another meal. Negra Modelo was a good choice of beverage to accompany both entrees. All entrees come with rice and beans, which are also mild but not bland, and add a lot of heft to the meal. 

The corn...my god, one could swoon over this corn. A cob, roasted to perfection, and slathered with mayo, cheese, and chili powder. A must for an appetizer. Easily shared by two (and recommended). 

The carmelized mangoes with vanilla ice cream was a decadent end to the meal. Fun to watch them slice the mango, but don't watch them cook it (seeing all the butter they put in will give you a heart attack on the spot). 

I'd recommend that you sit at the bar so you can watch the food going out to tables (helps you drool and decide before you order, and can help you avoid food envy since you know what you're getting) and being prepared. Our waiter made our mangoes for us, and it was neat to see everyone pitch in. Oh, and not that this matters at all, but our waiter was also incredibly attractive. Swoon again. 

Only criticism was that the place was freezing.
author: Sarah L.

description: Breakfast here is soooo good. All organic, fresh ingredients, made in an open kitchen right in front of you. This is the cleanest kitchen I've ever seen. Handmade tortillas, fresh guacamole made to order. Chorizo and eggs is divine. Fresh mimosa's take a minute but that's only because they are juicing the oranges specifically for you. Dinner was not quite as good, mole and chicken was dry. The service is always worthy of 5 stars.
author: Nicole C.

description: I went with a friend on a Saturday afternoon. I have passed Regalito many times and had been wanting to try it out. I hadn't read any reviews, I was just curious. The service was great! We sat outside, which can sometimes be risky in terms of service...since you are not within direct site of the staff. It didn't matter. Our server was nice, knowledgable and attentive. The food matched the service. Both my friend and I love guacamole.  We ordered their homemade guacamole and were not disappointed. The sangria was excellent and I loved the fresh homemade tortillas  I had the pork entree which was very good and I saw other things on the menu that I'm going to try on my next visit.
author: cynthia h.

description:
I'm drooling now just thinking about the dish I had here, Pulled Chicken with chipotle sauce, it reminded me of my Tia's home-cooking. The chipotle sauce was not too spicy, but still had a little kick to it and the cilantro in the sauce was perfect. I love cilantro! The rice was perfect and fluffy, only complaint, I would of liked a bit more rice in my portion. And I usually like smaller portions.
My BF had the Cochinita Pibil, he loved the portion of black beans served with the pork. The pork itself was delicious, although not as tender as the Pibil he used to get at "Mi Lindo Yucatan" in Noe, which unfortunately closed. 
We also had Arroz con Leche (that's rice pudding for you gringos) for dessert. It was warm, had raisins in it, and reminded me of home. All it needed was cinnamon on top. *drools*
The over-all experience was nice. They knew we spoke Spanish, so they spoke Spanish, always nice. The art is interesting. The kitchen is open and behind a cool looking glass counter, where you can also sit. The place is a bit small if you were going with a big group, say 10 peeps, but doable. If they have the budget they should fix up their bathroom, it looks ghetto compared to the rest of the restaurant. And I appreciate them keeping the restaurant clean, but try not to use harsh smelling chemicals while I'm trying to enjoy my Arroz con Leche. Thanks! I really liked that they have the option to make reservations through Yelp, that was pretty cool and easy.
I want to come back here, but I'll have to go when I have some cash to spend. The plates are a bit pricey. 2 sodas, 2 entrees, and 2 deserts for $75 with tip, no alcohol.
author: Juliette F.

description:
Men On Food say: 'This deserves an around-the-world-and-back snap.'
 I have 3 words to add - dee lish us.  LOVED IT!!  - Antoine
author: Ricardo A.

description:
The mole's really delicious and they have good sangria. Everything here is very fresh. The guacamole is super fresh like homemade. The grilled mango w/ Mexican vanilla ice cream was really really really good. The ice cream was eggy and creamy and full of vanilla flavor. This is how ice cream should taste.

It's tiny so be prepared to wait and don't plan going anywhere else afterwards.
author: E. M.

description:
Maybe they were having an off night - but my pork shoulder carnitas was bland and tough. even the beans that it came with were bland.  

I expect some flavor in my food for  a 15  dollar entree. Well should I?
author: Christian S.

description:
Just had a really good meal at this place. The food was pretty awesome. We had the pork wrapped in a banana leaf, one of the chicken dishes, and an empanada special for the appetizer. I had the bread pudding with Mexican ice cream for dessert. We had sangria and margaritas to wash everything down with, and it was all yummy.

The wait staff was really attentive, professional and friendly. This is a really small place, but the decor is nice, it's not too noisy and we got good service. I'd almost go back right now for more of that pork. :-)

It's also only three blocks from the parking garage on 21st, so drive (don't walk, run, skate, ride alpaca or some other mode of transpo) to this nice 'lil Mexican joint on 18th. You'll be glad that ya did.

[update: just went back last weekend, and it was every bit as good as it was the first time.]
author: Steve R.

description: Ate there tonight and had a wonderful dining experience.  The service was super (Elizabeth was all smiles and very attentive) and the food tasted so fresh!  The guac was outstanding, the tortillas divine, the pollo con negro mole was really rich and creamy (perhaps a smidge too much spice - cinammon?), and the carne asada had a nice grill flavor.  The bread pudding was good - not the best I've ever had but I'd order it again.  We definitely plan on coming back as the dishes we saw on other diner's tables looked really good too....
author: Scott G.

description: I really wanted to love this place, but I couldn't help feeling a little bit disappointed.  They were offering an appetizer special the night we went that sounded delicious.  Braised pork cheek with black beans, avocado, and tortillas.  A bowl of black beans arrived, and I kid you not, we had to fish around in there for the pork.  I found 2-3 very small pieces, and my date only got one piece that turned out to be all fat.  For entrees we ordered the mole and chile relleno, which were tasty, but very small portions for the price.
author: the c.

description:
Outrageously bad food!
I started with the ensalada espinicas, which, at $8, consists of about eight spinach leaves with bland and uninspired accompaniments.  The grilled corn on the cob ($6) tasted as though it had been sitting in somebody's refrigerator for the last two weeks - unacceptable for a restaurant in California to be serving something like this in July.  Finally, my entree came - Tamales de Calabacitas - unbelievably bland and dry and smothered in a tasteless goozle of a sauce.  The tamale lady wouldn't be cought dead serving something that tasted like this, and yet Regalito considered this inetible concoction worthy of $16.  My partner's dinner was equally disappointing and overpriced.  
Is anybody in the kitchen even bothering to taste what is being served here?  
My advice: veer far away from this overpriced and pretentious joint serving unjustifiably terrible food.
author: Marta K.

description:
Go for the green beans.  The green beans are fantastic.  Really fantastic.
Go for the decor.  They did a truly impressive redecoration to the outside and the inside.
But the rest of it... it's not that it's bad at all.  It's fresh and the salsa is tasty, but it's just sort of rudderless.  It's not a tacqueria.  It's not a Mexican restuarant in the style of Panchita 3.  Not saying that it needs to be easily definable, but it just needs a little something else....
author: amanda g.

description:
We received friendly, personable service, our food came out promptly, and the error in our bill was dealt with easily and gracefully.   I hesitate to give the 4th star because the food wasn't very consistent in its quality.

We ordered a spread of small plates:  enchiladas rojas, enchiladas verdes, taquitos, guacamole, and fried quesadillas.  The most interesting and flavorful dish of the night was the enchiladas verdes, which were tasty, spicy, and all around excellent.  The fried quesadilla was something more like a pupusa, but with a cheese filling.  It too was excellent, but really, how can you go wrong with fried tortilla stuffed with cheese?

The guacamole was fresh (you could see the chunks of avocado), but it  could have used a bit more chile.   Similarly, the enchiladas rojas were surprisingly bland, though the ingredients seemed to be quality.   I guess I just like more strongly flavored food.  The taquitos were served with an amazing salsa that saved them -- otherwise, they were (surprise, surprise) somewhat bland.

The flan was excellent.  The french-press coffee was well done.  

If the food were more consistently flavorful, I would be happy to return many times.  As it is, I had a perfectly acceptable experience that I might repeat if I happen to be in the area.
author: Jay M.

description:
Super clean restaurant! 
It feels so fresh when I walk in.
I felt a bit weird eating Mexican food in such a pretty & modern restaurant, but it was a great experience.

Both male and female staffs were pretty attractive when I went in for dinner that night.
 
The food wasn't too pricey.
We ordered Chuletas de Puerco and Chile Relleno which were both yuuummy! I was really full but couldn't stop eating!

Nice place to hang out with small group of friends, or for a date.
I am so happy I found this place! I will definitely go back to try their "free range chicken"
author: Mai K.

description:
Went here last night on a friend's recommendation.
Ehhh, is all I have to say. 
The guacamole was good, the salsa fresca fresh and juicy but everything else was just ok. 
There was three of us and we shared two plates. The mole chicken which didn't blow my hair back and the lemon pork tenderloin that was only slightly better than the mole. 
All in all, the food I thought was a bit to pricey for what it was.
author: Shawn P.

description: Cramped space, weird service that didn't serve our dishes in the right order, and average overpriced food.  Skip this place.
author: Ankur P.

description:
I noticed lately that most of my reviews on Yelp are 4 or 5 stars, but this restaurant ain't gettin' close to that.  I am so very grouchy about this restaurant, for many reasons.

First and foremost, it is unacceptably overpriced for what you get:
- $19 for three shrimp enchiladas with very little shrimp in them.  The red sauce was unpleasantly bitter, and the asparagus did not work with the dish at all. 
- Dishes come with a *small* side of rice and pinto beans.  No choice of type of beans.
- Coupled with a $10 glass of wine, this meant a $30something dinner/person for subpar food.   I was so underwhelmed with the food that I would have been grouchy even if the charge was only half as high.
- No complimentary chips and salsa or other appetizers, making the value even poorer.

Next, service was acceptable in some ways but poor in others.  No one acknowledged us when we walked into the restaurant, despite the fact that it was less than half-full.  However, I will concede that it was friendly once we were seated.  Belatedly-commenced friendly service, however, cannot redeem a poor-tasting, overpriced meal.

Finally, the one thing that I was really looking forward to was a margarita ... but they didn't have margaritas or other liquor-based drinks on the menu.  Only after I had ordered a glass of wine did I read the Yelp reviews - and realize that apparently they are clandestinely selling margaritas, if you know to ask for them.  My guess is that they're trying to get around the lack of a full liquor license.  Whatever the case may be, I didn't get the Mexican food + margarita I was looking forward to, and I am tres grouchy.  We thought we'd found a convenient alternative to waiting 30 minutes for a table at Tacolicious, late on a weeknight ... but it turns out that T-lish warrants the wait; this place isn't worth paying for or waiting for, especially in the Mission, with so many amazing alternatives a stone's throw away.  Given the number of excellent other choices, I predict that this restaurant will have a richly-deserved CLOSED indicator on Yelp in the future.
author: B L.

description:
You know, I read all the yelps before going to this restaurant, and it dimmed my former enthusiasm for a new restaurant.  That said, I was impressed with the taste of my enchiladas verdes (upon recommendation from our sometimes-attentive waiter) however like other yelpers, I was a little taken aback by the 'side' status of the rice and beans.  Oh, and the chips - which you have to make into your own chips, by the way... they taste good but come only by request.  The sangria was refreshing, very drinkable.  Cinnamon on the rim.
Everything needed salt!  
All in all, I had a great time with my friends - it was a comfortable place to sit and talk.  I also think that it is hard to come by good, fresh, non-greasy, light mexican food when you want it.  (I know I can abstain from the beans and rice and chips that automatically come to the table in other restaurants, but let's be honest)

I will definitely go back to try some other things - I think once you know how to order here, you're golden.

And don't listen to glu b - that is NOT a urinal.
author: Melissa B.

description:
Loved the Sangria and it appeared everyone else sitting at the bar did too. 

Rubbed Pork was wonderful. Every order of the Guacamole is freshly made and really tasted great.  Rice and beans were lovely.

Really loved this place. Staff was attentive and personable. Will definitively go back many times and program into  my cellie for to-go on the many nights this place is jammed.

Entrees were $9-12 and decent sized portions. I couldn't finish mine and took it to go.
author: eric P.

description:
I couldn't have imagined a better way to enter Regalito Rosticeria, after coming through the door I found myself wedged between the two mariachis belting out some loud tune for at least a couple of minutes while waiting to be seated, but I'd have to say the rest of my experience was like rolling down a smooth slope ending in a visit to their  cheerless restroom. 

Anywho, a quick rundown of the food May T. and I tried out:  
First, the complimentary bowl of tortilla chips that any self respecting Mexican restaurant gives its recently seated customers to stave off their aching hunger were..... Oh wait, they don't give you chips!  Forgive me for thinking every Mexican restaurant must have chips, in my mind it's like the 11th commandment.  So, we started out with the house-made chorizo and potatoes; this was not bad, didn't make my tongue do somersaults or anything, but the potatoes were cooked well and the chorizo, nice and spicy.  Accompanying the chorizo, we had the nopalitos salad, which was a bit bland and uninspired.  Like it was described in the menu, it's nopalitos and salsa, comes out cold and a bit slimy.  For our main, we had the Elote (grilled corn on the cob).  This was definitely the highlight of the meal, well grilled, sweet corn, melted cheese, lime and spices, YUM!  Alongside the elote, we shared a plate of Cochinita Pibil, and though this sounded good in writing, in execution it was a bit lacking; for citrus and achiote paste marinated pork, it was a bit bland, but at least tender, but my tongue wanted more.  Oh yeah, the tortillas were not bad.

I know, you're here for the low down on the restroom.  I felt like this restroom was not up to the standards in I had set after seeing the modern decor of the interior of the restaurant proper.  It felt like they didn't put any thought or feeling into making this important room a comfortable escape for hand washing or bladder relieving, it was cold an uninviting.  At least it was clean and well kept, but i didn't like the cleaning station in the corner with the little-person shower thing.  It makes the place seam a bit lower class than it tries to be.     

All in all, RR is a cute but small place, the service was OK and i like the open kitchen, I think I would have been happy to watch the cooks from a bar seat, if we had been forced to sit at one.  However, for having unexciting food I will stick to the more affordable taquerias next time I hunger in the Mission for some south of the border treats (or the bacon wrapped hot dog cart).
author: Adrian L.

description:
I came here initially because I really liked the name, Regalito.  Silly reason, but that's the truth.

The food was decent/good - but the drinks, not so much.  Also my dining experience was somewhat negatively skewed because we had to share a table with another couple ... who were a tad quiet.
author: Rose W.

description:
I recently moved offices to the Mission and Regalito was on the list to check out for lunch.

I have to say it did not disappoint.  They even have a few outside tabels so you can bring your pup along.

I had the guacamole appetizer and the chicken tostadas.  MMMM.  The meat was so moist and tender and the dish was simple, yet rich.  I thought it was just great.

We were greeted warmly and the man, I assume owner/ manager, was very attentive.  The young man who waited on us was pretty slow, but the warm atmosphere and delicious food made up for it!
author: Becky T.

description: This place was the bomb.com! Oh my gosh, the food was so yummy and hot (temp-wise and also important to me). I ordered the enchiladas verdes and let me just say that they were AWESOME! They weren't that spicy (at least they weren't to me), but they have a nice, spicy habanero salsa that you can add which makes it POP. Guac was niiice, even though it came with tomatoes (not my fave). I convinced my coworkers to eat the nopales and we were literally fighing for the last bite. Our server/hostess was so sweet and friendly. Decor was great; not tacky as some latin decor can be. YOU.MUST. GO.
author: Penny H.

description: Good Meal.  The waiter was very helpful when I requested help ordering a Gluten Free entree., even though he was running about the tiny space.  Everyone was happy with the guacamole, the appetizers, their meals and the only lost start was from my tamales which had lots of  masa and little meat and for the prices being a bit up.
author: Bo D.

description: why 3 and a half stars only ? !just had half a chicken today with potatoes and the chicken is super moist and tast , the skin has lots of flavor and rubbed perfectly , its even hard to tell which is better this one or lemon 's
author: NAEL K.

description:
I have gone here twice for brunch.   Each time ordering the Chilaquiles Verdes...YUUUUMY!  This dish is so well balanced in taste that it will call you back.  Both times I have ordered the guacamole to start, the chilaquiles verdes and split a dessert.  Absolutely every bite is delicious!  The ingredients are fresh.  The presentation beautiful.  And, the staff is very friendly without being obtrusive.  

A great neighborhood place!  If you are a resident of the Mission, you HAVE to try it.  I come from Nob Hill and my ONLY complaint would be the parking.  But that is not the restaurant's issue...it's what to expect in San Francisco.

All in all - WONDERFUL place!  Go try it and you will agree!
author: Annalisa E.

description:
2 stars...1 star for the great service and 1 star for the fresh and tasty guacamole.  

I really wanted to like this place because it's a cute restaurant in a great location.  But I just didn't like the food.  I had the Pollo Con Mole Negro which was 1/2 of a roasted chicken with mole sauce.  I'm glad I asked for the mole sauce to be served on the side because the sauce was very thick and glutenous and I didn't like the taste of it.  So I just ate the chicken with the rice and beans which wasn't too bad if you like paying $16 for rotisserie chicken w/rice and beans.  My partner had the Carne Asada w/Mushrooms.  The mushroom sauce had a sour taste to it that made me gag.  

I wouldn't eat here again and I wouldn't recommend it to a friend.  I would recommend the guacamole.  It was the best part of our meal.

Sorry Regalito..I hate giving bad reviews....
author: Lisa E.

description:
I really enjoyed the atmosphere and the food at Regalito Rosticeria. Two of us started with the chips and salsa. While the salsa could have used more salt and a little more zing, I liked the freshly fried corn tortilla that they used as the chips. It was a new twist on chips and salsa. I had the Enchiladas Rojas ($13.50) and Elote ($6) as a side. My enchilladas were above average and the Elote was FANTASTIC. I'm not sure I've tasted corn like this before and I would return to this restaurant just for the Elote which is Grilled Corn on the Cob, Grated Cotija cheese, mayonnaise, lime and Arbol chile powder.

The downside of this place was the service. My husband and I received our main dishes at least five minutes apart, so, I felt bad eating my food before him. In addition, his entree was supposed to come with beans and rice, but, they never brought any. Since he felt lucky just to get his food, he didn't complain. I got my sides several minutes after my main arrived. I don't understand why they can't bring my main and side at the same time! Its fairly tough to get a waiter's attention for water or anything else.

Anyways, I really did enjoy my food, but, my husband was so turned off by the service that he doesn't really want us to go back.
author: Joan L.

description:
OH YEAH!  I've been here twice, and it keeps getting better. Let's start with the coffee, served in a french press with beans from Nicaragua, or so I was told. I had the Conchinita which is pork slow cooked in a banana leaf.  Hello yummy.

The inside is painted a bright green with seating at the counter and 4-5 tables inside. Both times the restaurant has been almost empty and it was around 1 pm which was great for me since its small , but I want everyone to love Regalito as much as I do. So where are all the peeps?
