The wait staff were very sweet to my 1 year old daughter too. Everything was speedy and hot. This is a fave I will visit again and again.
author: Kristin G.

description: I have mixed reviews about Regalito.  I've been the Regalito three times now.  The first and second times were several years ago and the food was excellent and worth the prices they were charging.  Last month I went there with a friend for brunch and after ordering, we were told the pork dishes needed to finish cooking and wouldn't be ready for a couple of hours.  We changed our order to something that would be fast since we had been waiting for awhile and order tortilla soup.  The soup was so salty we couldn't finish eating it.  The server didn't inquire why we didn't finish the soup.  The service overall was slow and our orders were not delivered at the same time.  The chips and guacamole were not of the same quality I had previously.  The restaurant was not busy so I was surprised at the change. We felt we paid a lot of money for much not.  I was hoping for so much more.
author: Sharon S.

description: I have eaten here twice and both times the dishes I got were completely bland and flavorless.  The enchiladas are a waste of time!  I'm only giving two stars for the sangria and the taquitos which were delicious.
author: Wheelsie W.

description: Been here five times.  Excellent food.  Chicken enchiladas verdes were outstanding.  Roasted chicken also very good as was the guacamole.  I have felt like the service was attentive and trying hard to please.  It would be nice if it had a full bar.  Not the typical mexican place (don't mean it in a bad way) but well finished environment.
author: Glenn S.

description:
My husband and I came here for Lunch on a Saturday. 
The food was good not but not great, I especially liked the guacamole. 
Some other yelpers complained about slow service, but we didn't have any issues, in fact we had 1 hour on the parking meter and had 20 mins to spare!
I do agree with the other yelpers that the food is a bit pricey for what you get... but its definitely worth checking out.
author: Amanda T.

description: We enjoyed both Pollo Con Mole and Regalito. I especially love the Churro & Chocolate palate cleanser. Service great as they kept filling our glasses.
author: Johnson H.

description:
Went here last night for date night and really liked the servers and decor, but food and service were unremarkable.  I think this place can pull it together and move from very average to better than average eatery.  I sensed a real desire to please on the part of everyone, hence the three stars.  Without that sense, probably would've given it one or two stars.

The lowdown:
Starter - potato dish was EXCELLENT and got me excited for the rest of the meal.
Food - had the carne chile colorado (not exact name). Server said it was verya spicy but I love spicy food.  He was right.  It was terribly spicy, so much so that I couldn't figure out the point.  The spice wasn't highlighting some flavor, it was just burning my mouth.
Wine - had a glass of Malbec that was very enjoyable but something of a light pour for $8.  Then my partner got the same wine and it didn't taste anything like the glass I had.  This fact isn't figured into my rating because I honestly don't know if it tasted different because most of my taste buds were dealing with being spiced to death.
Service - super friendly and one of the biggest pluses.  Everyone was very nice.  But, the restaurant was less than half full and there was a ratio of less than 3 tables per server and I saw food sitting a long time at the counter waiting for delivery.  Also, second glass of wine order took a long time.

Final word - will be back because the people were all so nice, atmosphere was great and there were glimpses of inspired cuisine with the starter.
author: Kevin M.

description:
I heard about this place from a friend and I immediately thought of fabulous meals I had in Mexico as opposed to the typical taqueria that you find a plenty here.   It was a Friday night and the place was pretty packed, not overwhelmingly so but every table was filled.  We sat on bar stools facing the kitchen which gave us a nice view of what was going on backstage.  

Unfortunately watching all the excitement was more like a tease because I thought our food was mediocre.  We ordered several items, taquitos with potatoes, pumpkin seeds with lime, my entree was the cochinita pibil and to finish off our meals we shared a bread pudding.  

Although the actual dishes tasted great, the side dishes that came with the meal were terrible like the salsa, tortillas and beans.  All were pretty bland to the point where it was not eatable.  I have to say they really did tame down the flavors for all the dishes but some were still quite good like my cochinta pibil. 

I don't think I'll be back here anytime soon unless they figure how to incorporate a jalapeno or any kind of pepper to their meals.
author: Jay A.

description:
Hip place and clean spot for "new" Mexican. The salsa and chips are amazing....fresh, fresh, fresh! Love their intrepretation of chile releno...it was not deep fried...very creative.  

It was me and 3 buddies, and we had:
Chile releno (I love this)

Pollo regalito (my buddies are not accustomed to organic chicken, so they were super suprised that the chicken was very moist and flavorful without over seasoning)

Carnitas--excellent and not very salty

Desserts:
Lightly caramelized mango served with 
Mexican vanilla ice cream (this was the best, I must admit)

Flan (my favorite--super light, awesome)

Strawberries and cream

If you are looking for "real Mexican" food, this is not the place. For example, the rice and beans here are terrible. But if you are looking for a Northern Calif flare to Mexican cuisine, then you will like it.
author: Al G.

description: I must have seen this place a million times and finally went in after looking at the menu from the outside and found one of my fav mexican places in the city. We had 2 entrees, one was the special which was pork cooked in beer and spices, which I had also tried in Nopalto and it was just as good here (it came with black beans and lots of tortillas). We also ordered the chicken verde enchiladas which were huge and with a delicious spicy sauce. The chicken was very tasty and clean and the pinto beans and rice which came with it were the best I have ever had. Honestly, who would have thought rice and pinto beans can taste so good. The atmosphere was mellow and sophisticated, we sat at the counter and looked at the chef preparing his dishes attentively. Service was also efficient and smiley. Overall, a cozy little spot with excellent food.
author: Chris D.

description: Best Mexican food in SF. Not cheap, but worth every penny. Great michelada, great service.
author: Robert A.

description:
Headed over to Regalito with the "esposa" following my Spanish final at CCSF's lovely Church St campus. We've both been meaning to try Regalito all semester, and thanks to our friends at Groupon we finally made it over there this evening. I really wish that we hadn't waited until the end of the semester to check this place out, their food kicks ass!

Regalito was serving their special Tuesday "Pigalito" menu, along with a couple of specials. We scored a 9:30 reso on Open Table, and the parking gods bestowed upon us a spot right in front on 18th St. We were warmly greeted upon walking in, and there were 3 other occupied tables in an otherwise uncrowded restaurant. Luckily, the coziness of the space gave the place an upbeat vibe, perfect for celebrating the end of 4 months worth of homework and cramming for exams.

I ordered the pork shank off the Pigalito menu, while the lady went with the chicken enchiladas off the specials menu. The pork shank was the best this side of the revered O'Reilly's Holy Grail (seriously the best restaurant ever to walk the face of the earth), fall off the bone tender but not at all overly fatty. It was bathed in a very spicy, complex sauce which struck just the perfect balance between flavor and heat. It was mucho caliente y mucho delicioso (did I mention I got a C in the Spanish class?). Las enchiladas con mi amor were 3 overstuffed flour tortillas bursting at the seams with pollo and topped with a mild green tomatillo sauce and sour cream. Our super-cool waiter brought us a huge bowl of rice and beans to share as well as their special hot salsa. The beans were perfectly cooked and added another layer of depth to both dishes. My puerco definitely did not need the salsa, but wifey said it rounded out her enchiladas (which she did admit would have been a teench underseasoned and bland otherwise).

We passed on dessert, as the dinner portions were just enough where you felt full yet would be overstuffed with sweets. Our total including 2 Pacificos y 2 sangrias came out to $24 + tip after our $40 Groupon was applied. If you're looking for unique, flavorful Mexican fare in a festive atmosphere, Regalito is a must.
author: Michael T.

description: I just came from an outstanding late lunch experience at this place.  This is not your typical tamale-cheese enchilada Mexican restaurant; the menu is very innovative with dishes I had never seen before.  I ordered the cochinita pibil.  The meal was just excellent-a generous portion of tender marinated roast pork, fresh warm tortillas, flavorful beans, and a habanero sauce with some good fire to it. I will definitely be back to sample the other interesting items on the menu.
author: Howard C.

description:
Took our in-laws here over the holiday weekend. It was really good, clean, and the service was fantastic. We ordered the chicken mole and some smaller dishes and they were good portion size and yummy. 
All in all, a great place and price with the in-laws.
author: patrick k.

description: I love this restaurant. This is our go to place for food any night of the week. The sangria is AMAZING as are their chicken enchiladas, guacamole and the staff is so friendly and helpful. This is not a taqueria, so don't try to compare the food or experience to one. People say the portions are small, but I can tell you that I feel like I have to be rolled out the door every time I eat there. I love Regalito's!
author: Julie H.

description:
my bfriend and i ate at regalito last night for the first time....the food was fabulous!! everything was so fresh and so yummy, we stuffed ourselves until we couldn't eat anymore, but then we ordered flan (don't leave without ordering this) for dessert and rolled ourselves out of there. 

eduardo was our server and made our experience even more enjoyable. an all around fabulous experience....

i highly recommend it...and if you do eat a lot - you can always take your left-overs home and eat them the next day for breakfast (i did) :-)
author: Teri A.

description:
As my girlfriend said, the flavors didn't quite pop, but it was pretty good.

Potato taquitos were boring, even smothered in salsa. And my girlfriend's mole negro had a little too much chili so it drowned out the other flavors. I had pork ribs, that were a special, and that was good.

Cute place, though freezing in there in this weather. Medium prices (we spent $40 on 2 mains, 1 appetizer, and 2 agua frescas).

I'd go back to try a few more things.
author: David K.

description:
Bland, americanized Mexican food. Aside from the ambiance, this place is just plain old Vanilla. 

Standard beans and rice. Chicken with little to no flavor(though it was moist). Flavorless enchiladas. The salsa fresca was good though, as were the chips that were served with it. But c'mon? charging for chips? That's bullshit unless you are pretty damn arrogant about your restaurant.

The carnitas did look good, but they were out of them on this evening.

Prices, however are fare. Yes, you can get better Mexican food at a taqueria nearby for much less, but the prices here are for sit down place with a "nice", clean, hipster-mission atmosphere (no Mexicans here except in the kitchen).

All in all, standard Mexican fare with toned down flavors in the heart of the land of good SF taquerias. I wouldn't return by choice.
author: Evan B.

description:
I been to Regalito three times for dinner.  Each and every time the food has been exceptional.  this is not your Americanized plate with rice and beans but a great selection of regional dishes from all over Mexico.
be sure to share with  someone each others plate.  

this place would be five stars but
the interior is a weird set up.  this is especially true for  the counter seating area.  At the counter you have this glass wall in front of you and  looking at dishes-very poorly thought out.
author: Glenn T.

description: Went with friends for hubby's bday on a Saturday night.  Service was slow and unprofessional.  Waiter was in the middle of taking our order and just took off to seat a group when they came in.  Veg appetizers include the potato taquitos, guac and the soup was a cream of cauliflower.  All just okay.  The enchiladas were just okay too.  Can get much better food than this for a better price.  Won't return.
author: Manisha S.

description: I hate writing reviews after Will W because he says it all.  The food was meh...mole sauce needed salt badly..three tiny fish tacos for sixteen or seventeen dollars...nice fancy looking place with fabulously clean bathroom but still....
author: Poppy C.

description: Great service, really nice staff, they kept our water glasses full and the food was AMAZING. Must eat: taquitos, chicken mole-SO delicious, carnitas and churros. Can't wait to go back!
author: Brenda B.

description: Not bad. Overall a nice dining experience - clean, attentive, and good food with subtle flavors.
author: Jonas T.

description:
im mexican and the tortillas there knocked my socks out!!!

its a bit pricey, but being far away from mexico and having this quality mexican cousine, totally worth it.
author: ricardo m.

description:
Ate here after making reservation  the previous day.  When we arrived there was no record of it. The manager made it clear that the burden of proof was on us: who did we talk to, when did we call, etc.  Not an iota of responsibility or regret , no attempt to make it right.  Told him this was not OK and I would probably not be coming back. His response:  "that's fine with me."
There were other major problems as well: 1) Sitting at the counter  (no table for us), we had a clear view of the kitchen . One employee was using her hands extensively in food prep: stuffing peppers, shaping dough for tortillas, etc.  All this and more ..........without wearing gloves.  Maybe not a code violation but definitely unappetizing. 2) Manager informed us  we'd be charged tax on the entire value of the meal, not the Groupon purchase price.  Not sure this is even legal but it has never happened anywhere else -- and we use lots of Groupons.
Food was OK - service slow - but  the best dinner ever would not get me back.
author: Nancy L.

description: Really tasty food and good service. BUT, I thought I was going to a Mexican place :(
author: Jason R.

description:
Nice, modern interior and clean. but the food is so bland! very disappointed...needed more seasoning, more crispness (too soggy) and the service was slow, even though the place was practically empty.

Sadly, won't be returning!
author: heidi y.

description:
What I love most about this place is that it is a bit different -- Mexican restaurant, not taco stand.  We've gone 4-5 times and the service has always been very good and the folks are crazy excited to be at this restaurant.  
All in all good food, nice people.  We'll go again.
author: Catherine B.

description: I've been to Regalito twice now - I was hoping it would have improved in my second visit, but no such luck.  Both times I visited were with a Groupon.  If it weren't for the second Groupon, I definitely would not have gone back.  The food was decent, but very bland.  Of all the dishes I have tasted in my day, this is some of the blandest food I've had in a SF restaurant.  In addition - it's super pricey!  You definitely don't get what you pay for.  I'm glad I didn't come here and pay full price.  I had the half chicken on my first visit and the flank steak on my second visit.  I was able to also taste the green enchiladas, red enchiladas, and a shredded chicken dish.  All were just meh.  Nothing mind-blowing.  The service is attentive, and the drinks are tasty (but again, expensive for what you get).  I did enjoy a glass of their sangria.  While it was a clean, filling meal (dinner on both occasions), I know that I won't be back.  There are too many other wonderful places to eat in SF that offer better food and a better experience.
author: Jenna C.

description: Yum, everything I had here was amazing. Spinach salad, scallop special, house made chips, and bread pudding. The restaurant is small, but designed well. The design concept of the restaurant was inspired by the name "Regalito" meaning "little gift" in Spanish. There is even a "ribbon" of contrasting material/color that wraps around the entire space. The kitchen is divided from the diners by a glass sneeze guard so you can see everything as it is prepared. The owner was in the kitchen with his staff and was very friendly with all the customers. Love it.
author: J J.

description:
I really wanted to like this place.  The ambiance is nice.  I like the long bar seating area where I sat by myself next to the kitchen.  I started with a black bean soup, which was delicious.  Had a bunch of avacado in it as well as some nice cilantro and seasoning.  From there, I was excited about the main dish.
I ordered the Chicken Mole, in which the mole recipe came from Oaxaca, in which I've been.  I was less than happy with it.  The mole was just OK and there was only enough to cover the chicken, so I had to order more.  The chicken was dry and flavorless and even with the extra mole sauce I had problems finishing it.  Also, the chicken was so large that it was hard to manage it on the size plate they serve it with.  Kind of strange for a rotisserie place, but to me, it seemed like they took it off the rotisserie a few hours ago before they served it.  They should take some lessons from the Limon rotisserie (there, the chicken was delicious, even without the sauce).  Service was good though.  Not sure I'd come back after that.
author: Mitch A.

description:
I noticed this charming little place a few weeks ago walking through my neighborhood and thought it looked cute.  When my  friend suggested it I was excited to go and try it.  We scanned the small menu and decided to go for the guacamole when we saw it on someone elses table. It does seem expensive but it was obviously fresh and made to order. Not like some other joints whose guac tastes refridgerated and scooped out of a big tub. This homemade quality  justifies the extra dollar or two for me. Also it was well seasoned. It wasn't spicy, but it wasn't bland either. 

I decided to get a little meaty and ordered the spiced pork leg. It came with rice and whole beans. I tasted the beans first and again thought they were well seasoned with salt if nothing else. The rice didn't have a lot going for it. It was somewhat overcooked and had no other discernable flavor other than salt. I'm not saying that the meal was over salty, just that there was no depth of flavor and salt was the only seasoning. Living in the Mission, I have come to expect some spice and heat from my Mexican food. Unfortunately my whole plate was completely bland and underwhelming. The service however was beautiful and friendly and helpful. I was brought limes and salsa when I asked. I was brought tortillas even though I hadn't asked and they are a separate  a la carte item.  So A+ for service.

Luckily my dining partner ordered the enchiladas verdes which did have heat,  was seasoned well and was very tasty.  I think Regalito has a future in the Mission but they really need to taste their food before they send it out. They won't last long unless they up the flavor and possibly the heat of their offerings.Consistency is key here. They have everything else.
author: Claire K.

description: This is a long overdue review. I moved to SF from the "great" ol' state of Texas, so I'm a sucker for tex-mex, but most of all fabulous mexican food.  I stumbled on this restaurant with some TX friends for my first dining out experience in SF and overall was impressed.  Tasty food.  Nice atmosphere.  Great service.
author: Uchenna A.

description: We went here on the suggestion from a friend and we were delighted with the place.  We were a little wary at first as we were almost the only people in the place (seats maybe 30 people total inside) at 7PM on a Thursday night, but it quickly filled up so by the time we left at 8PM, it was pretty full.  They had 3-4 tables set up to eat and drink outside as well.  The waitstaff was super friendly when we arrived and during the entire meal.  We ordered the cactus salad and 2 chicken dishes that were all very good - everything came with freshly made tortillas, but they have no dishes with seafood or steak.  We had so much food left over that I would recommend  2 people only need an appetizer and an entree to split.  The agave margarita carafe was a little too acidic for us, but that might be because there was so much of it for us to drink.  We paid $78, but our bill could have easily been under $40 without the drinks and extra entree.  Definitely will be back!
author: Luke L.

description:
What a great restaurant!  The wait staff are so NICE & knowledgeable!! And the food is fantastic!! We had the Cochinita Pibil
and Green Enchiladas.  Both were utterly delicious and very generous portions too!  They make their own tortillas and salsas and everything is fresh and full of flavor. I love their Sangria and Agua Frescas--all house-made.  Prices are very reasonable for a sit-down restaurant.  The art work and music are very inviting.  We would definitely recommend!!
author: k k.

description:
mmm...elote.

you'll have to see adrian's full review of the bathroom.
http://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=ZZfJg3PeZdAxTMc2PpkTrg
(he even took photos of the wc with my camera, that freak)

food comments:

elote is the roasted corn on the cob with crema, queso, chili and lime. YOWZA that shit is good! the grilled cactus ensalata was kind of disappointing. it was too acidic and needed something to balance it out....like meat or something savory/sweet. we shared the pulled pork tacos entree and they were adequate. wish the pork had more flavor intensity. black beans were good and flavorful (lard anyone?) 

decor details:

the ambiance was intimate and cozy, but the restaurant itself is SMALL. dude, this is a tiny tiny restaurant with only about 10 tables and a long counter along the open kitchen. even though we didn't have reservations on a friday night, they still managed to seat us right away although we stood for a few minutes at the front door sandwiched between 2 mariachi singers while the hostess was fiddling around in the back. adrian wanted to do a little dance and i wanted to sing, "AYAAYAYAYAYAYAYAAAAY!!!" (we decided against it and just stood there like idiots for fear of stealing the two REAL performers' thunder and tips. cuz you know, we're just that good!)

mmm....elote. (i'm gonna figure out how to make this roasted corn at home and serve it to my amigos)
author: May T.

description: Completely unimpressed with the food and service. We tried 2 of their specialties: the Pollo Regalito which is a QUARTER of a small bird for something like $9 bucks and the Lomo de Cerdo, roast spice-rubbed pork leg ($9.5). The only thing we ate that was actually tasty was the Pepitas con Chile y Limon (toasted pumpkin seeds, chile and lime). Both entrees were boring and the server turned his back when I told him we were ready to order our food and did not come back until he had our drinks in hand about 10 minutes later. I know he heard me so is that being overly-picky? I didn't feel like it was too much to ask to have our order taken in a semi-empty restaurant when all he did was go stand around chatting with co-workers while waiting for our drinks. Would not go back... too many other options in the Mission at better prices.
author: margot b.

description: Met up with one of my best friends for a "catch up" lunch. The Waiter was fantastic - the food was scrumptious (potatoes and churizo, grilled cactus salad, and pork in banana leaves). Want to come back for the chilies and chicken!
author: Ron W.

description: My 1stWF treated me to B'day dinner last week. The Childrinas (crispy fried spinach tacos $7) was a good starter. Based on Yelp reviews, I tried the Papas con Chorizo ($6) - what a disappointment.. greasy soggy potatoes and sausage, avoid it!  The grilled Cactus salad ($7) was served with salsa and cheese and all the flavors and textures did not blend right...they should have added something crunchy like tortilla chips to balance out the soft succulence of the cactus. As for the main course, the Mole sauce ($16) fue muy fabuloso, just the right combination of cacao, fruits and spice, pero...the Chicken was dryer than the Sonoran desert. The homemade Habanero - well balanced and flavorful but could be mas picante.  In short, overpriced Mexican comfort food, but with fresh organic ingredients. I prefer Poc Chuc on 16th and South Van Ness which serves excellent authentic Mayan food.
author: Khaled M.

description: Went here for dinner because I had a 30% off deal from blackboard eats. We got the 'chips' & guac to start which was great, but be careful of that salsa they have the table bc it is spicy!! I got the shredded chicken dish - it was good, but nothing out of this world. We also got sangria, which again was good but not memorable. They don't serve hard alcohol here. The waiter was nice, they do take reservations (nice, especially because the restaurant isn't that big), and they were willing to split the bill on 4 credit cards. Good, casual place to visit if you are looking for somewhere good in the area that's not quite a taco bar, but I wouldn't necessarily go out of my way to come.
author: Caitlin B.

description:
I can't say I was too impressed with regalito.  First of all it was freezing inside, and the cold metal chairs and table did nothing to help this...  We ordered a few beers and checked out the menu.  I was a bit surprised...  I think it is a little pretentious of a mexican place to go al  a carte unless the food is spectacular (which it isn't).  I mean, what sort of place feeds you mexican food without either free chips and salsa, or free rice and beans - what is it, five cents a customer to make a big vat of beans and rice at the beginning of the night?    Anyway, we decided to order (for $3 bucks or something) some chips and salsa.  
   The chips and salsa came and it was very spicy, which was nice, but there was a huge bowl of salsa and THREE round chips.  Three? are you kidding me?  At least they were a few inches in diameter, but still, breaking them into tiny pieces i only got maybe four bites. Not starting off to a good start...
   Then the red enchilatas came out and I was floored.  They were literally three small tortillas folded over into quarters with enchilata sauce on top with NOTHING inside. huh?   For $7-8,  all I get is three tortillas with sauce????    nothing, no cheese or anything?  plus the sauce was chalky. a few bites and i was done.
   After that experience we asked the server if he could put some cheese or something in the green enchilatas.  So we got three little enchilatas with some cold cotija inside... hmm these were ok but still not worth the $7+ bucks.  The green beans were actualy good, but the potatoes were swimming in butter and not all that good.
  All in all, there was no ambiance, it was cold, over-priced ( bill was about $50 bucks for about a cup of veges, a bowl of salsa and about nine tortillas with sauce... is this some sort of sick joke???) and the food was not flavorful and boring.  Do yourself a favor in a neighborhood with tons of amazing mexican restaurants... go somewhere, anywhere else... and if 'fancy' mexican is your game, go to panchitas #2 or velvet cantina.
author: amy b.

description: Awesome.  SO good!  Everything was very fresh and service was great.  If I lived closer this would be a regular spot for me!  The sangria was tasty and not too sweet, guacamole was fresh and fun to eat with the tostada style tortillas, Cochinita Pibil (slow roasted, banana leaf wrapped, citrus and achiote marinated pork; garnished with habanero pickled red onions) was out of this world and the churros?  YUM.  Go there.
author: Megan W.

description: When this place first opened a few years ago, my lovah and I were in love and we started a weekly ritual of meeting up for lunch at El Regalito. They used to have lunch speciala, drink, torta or tacos and dessert (ice cream) all for a decent price, however, things have changed, the quality of the food is not the same, they no longer offer the same specials and they stopped serving tortas!!! That was the deal breaker for me, no tortas, no love.
author: Anabelle B.

description: The bright paint of the exterior just sucks you in.  Regalito offers organic Mexican food with a dining area that has a very modern flair to it.  Being a big fan of Mexicano food, I was a bit disappointed with the food.  It lacked imagination and flavor, which is what draws me to Mission district.  The pollo Regalito (Rotisserie Chicken) was bland.  I enjoyed the taquitos and the tamarindo juice.  The menu is limited with seafood offerings only on Fridays.  Great service, but because the menu and dishes should be reworked, I would have to say pass.
author: Jason A.

description: I don't understand how Regalito gets only 3.5 stars.  The nopales salad was fantastic (and I'm not the hugest nopales fan to begin with) with big slices of fresh avocado and queso blanco.  The cochinita pibil was suuuuper tender and tasty.  No wait for 2 on a weeknight.  If you want non-burrito Mexican food in the Mission, this is the place.
author: April G.

description: I've eaten at Regalito twice in the past few weeks with different groups of friends, and both times everyone was very happy with the experience. I love the bright, clean, but sophisticated design of the place. The food was unfailingly good and the service is warm and efficient.  The sangria is first-rate and a great way to start (and finish) a meal.  Tonight I had conchinita pibil -- succulent chunks of pork wrapped in banana leaves -- a house specialty, and it lived up to its billing: tender and flavorful. My friends had enchiladas verdes and they were also very tasty. Regalito is a terrific addition to the Mission dining scene and a nice departure from the typical Mission taqueria (which are very good, of course, but burritos can get tiring.)
author: Peter K.

description: Regalito is wonderful.  The food is great. Ive ate there twice in the last two weeks. The cochinita pibil is perfection! The ambiance is cool and the service is warm & friendly.
author: Lindsey T.

description: Regalito is a beauty. Thomas Pena (the owner/chef) and staff are warm and welcoming, and the service is charming and understated. The chicken enchiladas are fresh and perfectly spiced - I have to admit that I have trouble choosing anything else on their menu, because I love these so much. Had an incredible spicy beef stew one evening, based on one of the cook's family recipes. It was the best comfort food in the world. We ordered spiced pumpkin seeds, which were yummy to snack on with a beer (and they serve PBR, as well as Mexican beers, etc.) After a hard week of work, when I have a craving for a delicious, unpretentious dinner in the Mission, Regalito is the place I choose.
author: Julie B.

description: Went here with a groupon.The food was probably the blandest mexican food I have ever had.The chicken mole was so lame,as if the chicken was just roasted and sauce poured over it.No depth of flavor at all,or is that is how it's supposed to be done,I doubt it.Same with the enchilada verde,bland chicken with sauce over it.I was expecting much more as it is supposed to be a cut above the regular  mission taquerias.Service was fine,and a nice waitress,but the food was totally forgetable.
author: terence r.

description: went back last night. I really want to like this place, and there are some positives - it's cute, the service is good, the menu sounds good. There's only one issue. The food is just not that good, and it's really pretty lame if you consider how much it costs compared to the 450 places all around.
author: Fred A.

description: Nothing special. Was expecting more given the price and how nice it looks. The food was a bit bland. Better food like this can be found at many other places for less. Service wasn't great either.
author: Ian E.

description:
Have been by Regalito's dozens of times and finally decided to dine here on a Monday night.

Started with freshly made guacamole along with a fantastic Rosado.

We followed up with a half roasted chicken with lime, which while delicious, was just warm at room temperature.  The enchiladas verdes were perfect.

We decided to try dessert as well.  For the carmelized mango...great idea, but the mango was not ripe.  And the bread pudding was not warmed through, making me think it was leftover from the previous evening possiby.

Service was very friendly and attentive.  

So while we were not disappointed with the flavor, the food temps were the only issue tonight.  We plan to go back for a second time to try out the carnitas dishes.
author: David B.

description: Best Mexican in the Mission. Fresh mexican... Even if that sounds like an oxymoron
author: Tony D.

description: Man, such a nice little spot with a cool owner and staff, but there are definitely some issues with the kitchen.  The food took forever and when it finally came my carne asada was actually pretty good, but my friends who had the mole said it sucked...had no flavor.  I think the dude said they'd been around for twelve weeks, but it seemed like they had just opened and didn't have the kinks worked out yet.  I hope they get their shit together because I would like to see this place do well.
author: George C.

description:
first yelp review!

this place opened up a few months back. looked cool. big chickens roasting in the kitchen. nice paint job. I gave it a whirl.

bland bland bland bland gringo style bland. mole was tasteless and "el regalito" chicken nearly put me to sleep. and $20 a head, no drinks! within two blocks you can get a powerhouse burrito w/ beer for half the price.

fairly fresh guacamole, but not enough to cover the rest of the pretty terrible shortcomings. 

here's hoping the next review's more uplifting!
author: matt s.

description:
The layout of this place half ruined it for me. The lack of table seating disappointed me, as it's hard to be social and inclusive with your friends when you are sitting at a counter. They should at least give you tin can telephones upon entry so you can have a conversation with your friends at the end of the counter.

The guacamole was pretty good and not drenched in lime like I've had at other restaurants. The waiter was happy to give us more tostadas (even though he didn't look too happy) when we ran out, which was nice. I ordered the rotisserie chicken in chile, garlic, and lime marinade, and just from the sound of it, it sounds delicious. Unfortunately it was pretty bland with no chile, garlic, or lime marinade to be found. I love me some rotisserie chicken but I could've made this at home, or gone to Chick-N-Coup and saved $20. The rice and beans that came with the dish were very good, though.

Also note: They add full cans of Sprite to the sangria. SPRITE. What the cock is that about? Probably the worst sangria I've ever had in my entire life.

I'm glad I tried this place, but I'm not really in such a rush to go back.
author: Alexis C.

description:
i'm on a really tight budget these days but i really wanted to go out for a bite.  i stopped in to regalito's for a beer ($1.75 PBR) and shared a plate of taquitos and chips & guac.  i loved it!  the taquitos were made w. fresh white chicken meat and had a nice light salsa topping.  the guac was perfect.  the interior was adorable, as was the guy who waited on us.
i am going to be a regular at regalito - it's such a great deal!
Regalito means "little gift" and it is such a little gift - a little gem!
author: Mary C.

description:
We tried to go to Weird Fish, but the wait was too long and Regalito had a table for us immediately. I know there's a lot of chicken going on at this place, but the menu does asterik certain dishes as vegetarian. We had a vegan in the group and asked if he could be accomodated before we were seated. We were told he could, so we made the choice to stay. 

The place is pretty cute inside, and they have a decent variety of dishes in the menu. The pumpkin seeds were excellent, the green beans were nice too. They made our vegan friend a grilled zucchini dish and all seemed great. 

At some point while we were chowing down, our waiter brought over some beans and rice and told us that there was chicken stock in the rice as a warning. Knowing that we were all vegetarian we wondered why he brought it to us. I let him know we wouldn't be needing these sides as none of us could eat it. Then, he stopped our friend from eating her chile relleno as she was about to swallow the fork and everything on it. These words, verbatim, actually came out of his mouth. "What kind of vegetarians are you?" Her response, "The kind that doesn't eat meat." There was some squabbling about why the dish is asteriked as vegetarian on the menu (a question still unanswered) and we learned from our waiter's explanation that there are apparently many kinds of vegetarians and some vegetarians eat chicken. This is strange because I know a lot of vegetarians, but not a single one like that. People may have their own diets and rules, but in a restaurant, it's normally safe to say that anything marked vegetarian would be lacto-ovo. 

The attempt to provide information to veg customers doesn't go unappreciated, but I strongly disagree with the answers we were given about their choice to asterik the menu item. Considering many other vegetarian customers may have ordered this dish in the past,  it's probably safe to assume that loads of people have uknowingly eaten their meals here doused in chicken broth. 

I was too disgusted by this experience to ever have the trust to return.
author: aaron f.

description: cute place, attentive service, but the pork and the chicken were way over-cooked
author: mack m.

description: You cannot get a margarita here, which was something we overlooked when we made the reservation! This restaurant has a decent chicken mole dish and the sangria was nice. The guacamole was fine, but not outstanding. Service was OK. Our waiter reminded us to hurry up because a larger party was coming through later in the evening - this wasn't ideal. Overall this was a decent dining experience.
author: Diana M.

description:
the guacamole was very good.

the taquitos de papas y queso were alright.

the sangria was terrible.  worse than terrible.  i watched the man make it.  he used an entire can of 7-up in each pitcher.  w.t.f.?

in short:  meh.
author: Sarah B.

description: The sangria here is delish, and the food ain't bad either! The tomatoes with queso fresca were really good, as was the guacamole. Our entrees (roast chicken and cheese enchiladas) were pretty tasty too, though nothing to write home about. The service was excellent; our waiter was really laid back but very friendly. The carafe of sangria was just the right amount for two people- it gave me a little buzz but not so much that I felt ill the next day. Overall it was a nice experience. They really could use more space though because it is EXTREMELY small and crowded. If If you don't mind rubbing elbows with strangers than it's okay. I'll definitely go back, but probably during the week when it shouldn't be quite as busy.
author: Lisa F.

description: The owner was really nice, and the space is beautiful. Our server was a sweetie, and we saw many gorgeous plates go by. We thought that if each thing we ordered had one or two very simple touches this place would have been great. Maybe some salt/stock (or bay leaf?) in the beans & rice? Maybe some lemon/lime and cumin in the guac? Onions should be either raw & thinly sliced, or cooked until that raw bite is gone, not warm slimy crunchy. You're are almost there! We're rooting for you!
author: J. R.

description:
Four of us went to Regalito and ate through almost half of the menu. Ordering a carafe of white Sangria, we settled in with two appetizers; Quacamole con Tostadas and Papas con Chorizo. The quacamole is ample with fresh salsa and served with whole fried corn tortillas. I enjoyed it more than I thought I would considering I'm not a huge fan of salsa (I'm getting better at this). But the fried potatoes with the chorizo, queso fresco and crema was a clear winner amongst all of us. I could eat a whole plate of this...

Another carafe of the fabulous sangria came with the four entrées of the evening. One special of the evening, roast lamb with New Mexico chili sauce, Enchiladas Verdes, chile relleno de Calabazas y Maiz, and Cochinita Pibil.  The enchiladas were served with whole pintos and fine, but too cilantro-laden for enjoyment by yours truly. The Chile Relleno was my order and was stuffed with queso Oaxaca, squash, corn and garnished with ranchera sauce and cream. I could tell that it was good, but a bit on the spicy side for me. I also ordered a side of carnitas just because I tend to always want to taste a restaurant's carnitas. It was very good and served with some black beans. The lamb was very tender and quite rich. But for me, the dish of the evening was the Cochinita Pibil; slow-roasted, banana leaf wrapped, citrus and achiote marinated pork with habanero pickled red onions. LOVED that dish...

Two desserts were shared over coffee; the churros with hot chocolate and Capirotada, warm bread pudding with apples, raisins, nuts & jack cheese - topped
with Mexican vanilla ice cream. The bread pudding was HUGE and while I enjoyed the caramel sauce, it was a bit on the gummy side. Everyone loved the churros as well. They were obviously very fresh, but a still a bit gooey on the inside, I thought. The hot chocolate was superb. With tip, $50 a person.
author: Carolyn T.

description:
I first want to give credit where credit is due when it comes to how we stumbled upon this great addition to the Mission.  Thank you to my golf clubs.
It was my pricey set of golf clubs in the back of my jeep that caused us to drive past our targeted restaurant to the parking lot adjacent to Regalito.  It was raining, we saw the signs....end of story (or beginning).
The host welcomed us into the restaurant wearing his backwards hat and speaking perfect English.  I began to worry a bit.  We double checked that they served margaritas, as that was the night's primary objective, and were told they use agave cactus wine instead of tequila.  At this point i was very worried about this place.
After a 10 minute wait, during which time the cooks gave us samples of the special wine, we were seated at one of the few tables.  The food, drinks, and service that followed were pure bliss.  
It turns out that the host is fluent in both languages and their 25% alcohol margaritas are excellent and don't destroy your taste buds before dinner.  The food contained by far the freshest ingredients I've had at a Mexican restaurant, including the swanky ones.   The modest prices reflect the premium ingredients, nothing else.  Even though we all cleaned our plates, which included beef, pork, and chicken enchiladas, we didn't have that 3-lb burrito feeling that is always due to cooking with lard and 1-2 day old ingredients.  Regalito also doesn't need to compensate for taste with enormous portions.  Instead they spend the time to arrange smaller plates with traditional sides.  They are aware of how good their meats are and that you do not need to drown them in beans and salsa for flavor.
So yeah, this place is great and i hope it doesn't get too popular for the walk-in crowd.
author: Gavin D.

description: Service was fine, tostadas were nice, the tamarind juice was tasty, but the entrees were garbage.   I ordered the half chicken and I was completely underwhelmed when it came out.  The skin was all soggy and gross looking and incomplete, to boot.  A huge section of the skin of the chicken breast was missing and the meat had been prodded around in and damaged, I'm assuming to determine if it was fully cooked, but who knows.  They tried to hide this catastrophe behind the other piece of chicken, as if I wasn't going to notice.  I sent it back without touching it and had it taken off the bill.  My girlfriend's tinga de pollo was awful - greyish pieces of chicken in limp sauteed onions.  At $16.00 a serving, you expect a lot more. It didn't stack up to even the cheapest Mission burrito spots. Won't return.
author: Karthi X.

description: I'm going to start off by saying, the service was good!  Totally acceptable despite what the other reviewers have written.  My critique lies in the food.  I think it has potential, but there was little to no taste in any of the dishes we had.  My friend ordered the Rojas enchiladas and there was nothing inside the tortilla.  Everything, which was not much, was thinly layered on top of 4 tortillas.  My other friend ordered the Tinka and it was nothing to write home about.  I had the carnitas and they were fine, but could have used a whole lot more flavor.  In one word, I'd describe the food here as bland.  For the price point, the food should not to be bland.
author: Dara S.

description: I think I have a new favorite place. I'm a big fan of roasted chicken so I was naturally drawn to this place but I got a lot more. Everything is freshly made and you can really taste the difference. My wife is a big fan of mole and she had one of the best she's ever had here. If you're looking for tacos and burritos then stick with your favorite taqueria but if you're looking for real Mexican food then give this place a try. I can't wait to go back and try the enchilada verde. It doesn't get the full 5 stars because the atmosphere is a little sterile.
author: Reza E.

description:
Good but not great. 
The appetizer was excellent. Masa and blue corn tortilla with queso fresco and fresh toppings. Very tasty. 
For conchito pibil (achiote pork marinated in a banana leaf) and a lamb special with the same marinade. The lamb was definitely tastier. 
Tortillas on the side were good but not great. The black beans on the side were forgettable. 
Nopalito was better for this type of high end Mexican food.
author: Jacob K.

description: Finally Mexican food that reminds me of home (San Antonio, TX).  The enchiladas verdes are the best I've found in this city  that's deranged in thinking that burritos are the end all be all of Mexican food (you all are very wrong!).   And for those dogging on this place for it's blandness guess what...authentic Mexican food IS pretty bland.  I just can't wait for them to start serving the micheladas!  My only real suggestion for improvement would be to add some more vegetarian and vegan dishes.
author: Lisa R.

description:
ooooh kay now, we have a place to get some mutherfucking carnitas. seriously fuck everything esle -- eat pork here. the enchiladas are the truth. 

the mango dessert -- holy crap it was awesome on a plate.
author: lydia p.

description: I really liked this place when it first opened, was always pleasant, made me feel like I was in Mexico City... and I think the food is good and the atmosphere is nice... but, now-a-days, it can get a little rough in there... it's a small place with people squeezing in and bumping your table or your chair... and it's a super tight squeeze at the bar. These days, I'll only venture in during the off hours... cuz it's become a bit of a trendy scene... and I don't  like to feel rushed by the wait staff, or, in such a small space, care to deal with the overly-perfumed, designer bag set.
author: M V.

description: Regalito is just that.  A little gift.  I walked in and the smell was perfect.  Something yummy was roasting away.  The service was great.  Everything was fresh and pretty much perfect.  I have a feeling my husband and I will be seen there again.  We had the guacamole with tostadas and habanero shrimp appetizers, followed by the machaca and 1/2 whole roasted chicken, respectively.  The fresh, homemade tortialls were great.  I was only a little surprised that the machaca wasn't what I thought - the beef was cut and prepared a little differently that I expected but it was still very good.  The beans beneath the machaca were amazing.  The roasted chicken was like butter.  I never eat chicken skin but the perfect glaze on this roast made me break my rule.  Oh, and you MUST GET THE FLAN.  The flan is the way flan is supposed to be - simple with it's caramelo.  It was perfect.  Too bad I didn't get a pic of the flan - we inhaled it before I could break out my camera.
author: Isa L.

description: Similar to the other reviews, the tasteful colorful decor and attentive service cannot overcome the underachieving quality of the food.  Okay, to be fair, my wife loved her enchiladas verdes although she was surprised that it did not come with a side of rice / beans for the price.  However, the carnitas, which came highly recommended by the waiter, fell far short of what should have been a great tasty dish.  Instead, it was surprisingly bland.  My friend and I looked at each other almost in amazement that it lacked any taste.  Once I started adding salt, pepper and salsa, it made it only slightly better.  The only good thing that we liked about this dish was the fresh corn tortillas that accompanied it. and required other condiments to give it some zing, e.g. salt, pepper and even the salsa.  When you consider that the dish cost $17, I walked away feeling disappointed.  Because we were with friends, I did not want to complain.  Unfortunately, we're not likely to return.
author: Will L.

description: Nice "small gift" of a mexican restaurant in SF - everything was good (we had guacamole, two pork dishes, the papas y chorizo, beans, ...), but I particularly liked the churros dessert.
author: Jeff H.

description: very very imaginative mexican restaurant specializing in regional cuisine.  No, you won't find burritos here but there is more to mexican cuisine than tacos and burritos.  the mole chicken here is excellent as are most dishes.  the guacamole and tortillas are the best in SF.  you can't go wrong with this place.
author: joe r.

description: Note: I only had dessert here.  I had the churros and hot chocolate, but the hot chocolate tasted bad, and then I noticed the solid white bits floating in it.  So I told them I thought the milk had gone bad and sent it back.  They brought me another that tasted just like the first, but without any floating bits.  I gave up and asked for coffee and ate the churros, which were fine, but not any better than any other churros I've had.  They didn't do anything to make up to me for the bad milk (like even apologize!) which might have made me feel a little better.
author: J T.

description: Such a cute place, and such friendly service, but the food was so bland.  I had the carne asada and my husband had the pollo regalito, and we just weren't impressed...  We were actually most impressed by the guacamole appetizer and the spicy potatoes as a side order.  Even though we liked the guacamole, I could make it just as well at home, and I'll probably do that next time.
author: robyn s.

description: I didn't like this place.  I was immediately turned off when I was seated at the bar like it was a regular table.  The waiter didn't even ask if it was ok.  AND, there was an open table. The bathroom then was kind of gross, and the waiter asked me to move my bag after I put it down on a table next to me, since the bar was too small.  The menu is nice, but kind of limiting.  Overall, they need to beef up the quality of their service.
author: Joanna S.

description:
I've walked by this place a hundred times, always admiring the colors and design of the signage and interior.

One morning a couple weeks ago I took a couple friends out for Sunday brunch here.  Not sure what the schtick is at this restaurant.  Roasted meats?  I don't know.

The breakfast dishes were on the lame side.  I got Chillaquiles which were basically a few corn chips scattered on a plate with some eggs, cheese, beans, and sauce.   Not too much flavor and the portion was on the small side.

My two friends seemed to enjoy their breakfasts - I cannot recall what they ordered.

As I like to drink some sort of cocktail/alcoholic drink with my brunch, I ordered a carafe, then another, of mimosas.  I saw the price - $22  So I only have myself to blame when the bill came - with tip this brunch for three people was about $90.

Uninspiring experience.  I'll stick to places with cheaper mimosas - there is no reason why cheapo champagne and orange juice should be so expensive.
author: David M.

description: Ok, the food is delicious... no doubt.  However the selection is small and the prices are large.  Some boiled chicken, and rice for 17 dollars?  Look if this wasnt in such close proximity to delicious, cheap , mexican food on every corner, they might be able to get  away with it.  But I wasnt fooled... and I left hungry .  If your looking for a bite of some tasty meat, like an appetizer, and are willing to pay, go here.  But for a dinner night out, try somewhere else.  On the upside, the staff was nice and very attentive.  I guess they would have to be to get a tip out of the overcharged customers.
author: Jennifer E.

description: What a great little restaurant. I like everything about it, from the decor to the excellent coffee to the presentation of the food to the awesome breakfast dishes. This is perhaps my favorite place to get breakfast in San Francisco. The owner and the staff are good people and you never have to wait for a table. I highly recommend eating at the bar. It's fun to watch the staff prepare the food.
author: Kourosh K.

description:
My DB (darling boyfriend) & I had a lovely lunch here last Sunday.
Tiny place; clean postmod decor helps it look larger. Service sweet & attentive w/out  hovering.
Guacamole (made( just for us! BY  HAND) was silky and chunky @ the same time (if that's possible) and as close to perfect as it gets. We scraped the bowl with the super crispy flaky warm corn tortillas.
DB had the steak & sauteed mushrooms; served with rice & beans, a steal @ 10.95.  I've had much less flavorful steaks @ twice the price.
I had tostadas with pork carnitas, queso fresco, and salad on top. Carnitas!!! succulent & not greasy in the least. How do they do it?
Fresh limeade, spiked with an adorable sprig of mint, couldn't have been more refreshing. Coffee is Ritual Roasters and served in a french press.  Love the attention to detail.
We really enjoyed it and can't wait to go back.  That will be easy for us, coz we live about two blocks away.
A welcome addition to our neighborhood, and adds to our feeling of being really spoiled on this stretch of 18th street. Tartine, BiRite, Delfina, Plantanos, Luna Park... is that why  I can never never never park in front of my building?
author: Patsy H.

description:
Being Mexican,  I may be a bit more critical, but I ordered the enchillada roja for lunch and I can tell you that I never had an enchillada which was just a tortilla dipped in sause. I must say that the sauce was good, but again, it was just a torilla in sauce with a very light sprinkling of chesse on top for $10.50.The side dish of rice and beans was bland. On a positive note, the guacamole was good, although it could have used a bit of seasoning, and I do like that they use fresh ingredients, which is the reason for the 2 stars.
Bottom line is that I could have gotten better enchilladas at El Toro.
author: Deborah B.

description: Although the restaurant itself looks spectacular, the food is really hit or miss. Firstly, there are ONLY TWO vegetarian entrees on the menu. Hello! This is San Francisco... capital of uber-veggie-vegan-non-meat-eaters! The one we tried (chile relleno) was boring, so were the rice and beans that accompanied it!! I will say though that the veggie "sides" were delish! Grilled corn on the cob and calabazas. The flan was disgusting (not sweet, but very bitter). Even the meat eaters with me had no ooh's or ah's about their food.
author: Sally M.

description: Yum yum-licious!  A block from my home, I finally had an afternoon to wander over and take a late lunch at this tasty new spot.  Jonathan was my friendly and fantastic waiter who brought my Pacifico and tostada de Pollo.  I was shocked at how good a little tostada could be.  There was tons of chicken that was nice and spiced and the rest of the toppings were all super fresh.  I'm really looking forward to brunch on the weekend here, esp. on Sundays since they have the Virgin Mother Mexican candles all over the place.
author: Tracy E.

description: Delicious guacamole, delicious enchiladas, delicious agave wine margaritas, friendly waiter = good first experience. Definitely worth rotating into my regular mexican roster. I will be back.
author: Justin B.

description:
let's have a collective group sigh of relief - not a burrito in sight. a mexican joint willing to give real food and not the usual 'same shit, different wrapper'.

this place is great, from the decor to the food. warm and homey with great sangria [though no very winey]. we started with the guac and chips and moved on to the mole chicken and carne asada. both were perfectly cooked and a real delight to eat. 

i must recommend that you ask for some 'hot sauce'. you'll be offered the house version which i went crazy for. next time i go back i'll be bringing some home - it's really that good.

great atmosphere and friendly staff. a nice respite from the usual mission tacqueria.
author: matt n.

description: This is another groupon I purchased recently and decided to use it this labor day weekend. My dad and I went there for lunch. The service is quite slow b/c there were just too many people and only one waitress who is taking care of everything. I made a reservation for 1pm and did not start eating until 2:20'ish...But the food was worth the waiting. I had the ensalada nopalitos and pollo regalito. The cheese was good and I loved the cactus and beans!! I'm not a big fan of chicken, but the chicken here was really good, tender and not too juicy or dry. And it was not too salty like most of the other chicken I've had in restaurants. I wish they had more selections on the menu and the tortillas were too thick for me; I like them on the thin side. The waitress was very friendly, so I forgot about the long wait.
author: Lily X.

description: I like food, specifcally mexican & using the best ingredients & I like Regalito a lot! This place is very good & the waitstaff is killer, make sure to ask for a reccy on the menue. I have taken my family in a few times & everyone comes away happy.
author: Quinn R.

description: Tiny restaurant, clean, upscale vibe, modern with pretty artwork. Prompt, friendly service. Delicious guacamole, best we ever had. Pork is their specialty and deservedly so. Came upon this place by accident but will go back. Portions not huge, prices OK but not cheap. Agave margaritas are tasty!
author: Maggi B.

description:
I am a big food fan and when I eat out I expect quite a bit.
But I do expect and scale my expectation accordingly.
I do recognize sometimes sooner rather than later detail.
Detail is not always about presenting a revolution in flavour but sometimes it is in substance.  You will not go to Regalito and get a wild black cherry pecan encrusted saffron dusted Loup de Mer....  this is not what Regalito Rosticeria is about.  Regalito.. means 'small gift' in English from the Spanish.   I think Regalito means for me a small gift and attention to detail.  Restaurants today are big in style or so many try and few execute well.  I found Regaltio a simple Mexican style Rosticeria.  This is a highly differentiated restaurant concept that does not exist in San Francisco.  This city could not have another Taqueria unless it was highly differentiated.  I ordered the Mole and it was well prepared Mole Poblano is a brilliant sauce when done well and a severe disappointment if it falls short.  For this Rosticeria it was well executed.  The salsita was fresh and so were the tortillas.  There is an organic approach to the food and it shows well.  The sangria was delicious and it was nice to see they gave the glasses a coating of cinnamon.  I have never seen that before and it worked well.  The fruit slices were evenly cut and it is a better presentation when it is smaller cubes.  The coffee... which I have never seen in any restaurant (and I have eaten out a lot ...London, Paris, New York, Chicago, Florence, Venice, Madrid, Barcelona....) was served in individual French presses.  These small touches go a long way.  The service was thoughtful and not overbearing.  You have to review the restaurant for it's intent and not compare it with restaurants that it should not be compared to.  This City is filled with too many restaurant critics and sometimes they are overly harsh.  The restaurant deserves best in class.  Detail and execution of detail earns them high marks.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description:
i went here the other night after wanting to try it for months. i think the wait was worth it because some of the earlier reviews seem not so great.

the star of the night was a special side, yummy, juicy, grilled corn (see my picture) with mayo, cheese, spices, and a squirt of fresh lime on it. OH so good.  i have been trying to get my hands on some corn like this since first trying it in brooklyn about 5 years ago.  occasionally i see someone walking around mission st. with it but i can never figure out where it came from.

for dinner i had the enchiladas rojoas which was a very nice dish and a good change with the normal, overly cheasy enchiladas you can pretty much get at any other mexican place.  basically they were just tortillas, folded, with salsa all over (but not runny) and a bit of cheese and sour cream on top and some fresh onion. it was the perfect amount of food and i even had a enough room for an ice cream cone afterward.

i must admit i am a little disturbed to read the review that aaron f. left. i  am slightly hopeful that the restaurant learned a lesson and isn't using chicken stock for items marked as veggie. i did eat the beans and rice. i guess i'll live though and i am not deducting a star for that since it's unconfirmed for my meal.

i wish i had tried the pumpkin seeds!  and, hopefully i'll be back for breakfast or brunch sometime.
author: Kristie P.

description: Regalito, while mostly meat-centric offers some pretty good desayuno fare at a reasonable price, very flavorful, good portions and super fast service, with a smile. As far is upscale cheap mexican food goes this place is a sure winner. The restaurant is clean and bright and airy, with a sparklingly clean kitchen on view, you can sit at the bar and watch your food being prepared or site at one of the 8 or so tables, a fair selection of wines are available also.
author: Jared Z.

description: I really, really wanted to love this place, its in my old neighborhood and we found parking right in front. The space looks like most remodels these days, cool track lighting, muted colors, clean lines, it reminded me of a mini version of Limon. The waitress was super nice, but the food....it was only ok. They should give away chips and salsa, but I am not going to balk at paying $3.50.  We had the enchiladas verde and the chicken mole. Both were good but not great and at $12.50 a plate (for lunch) we were hoping for more flavors and more heat. Not spicy heat, but hot food. It was clear they serve their food on cold plates....the place was nearly empty and after reading reviews of this place I give it 6 months tops before they close. Too bad, it could not have been cheap to assemble such a cute place.
author: James S.

description: This place gets 2 stars for 2 reasons. One is that they have a kick-ass guacamole with the perfect amount of lime and jalapenos, the second is that they try to provide organic/sustainable foods whenever possible and that's not easy. The problem arises when you order their signature rotisserie chicken. When I ordered it the waitress, who was a pastoral masterpiece, let me know that the chickens had come off the rotisserie only a half hour ago.  Sorry honey there's no way the juices of that rotating fowl dried up that quickly. It was dry and mostly white meat (e-gads). Better to be honest, they came off an hour ago and I should really try something else, than to leave me disappointed. Mostly Nice.
author: Matthew R.

description:
** BRUNCH REVIEW**

i've finally found the best posole in the city! forget eggs benedict - brunch cannot get any better than a big steaming bowl of spicy pork broth, full of super-tender chunks of meat and plenty of hominy, garnished with handfuls of cilantro, little moons of radishes, a squeeze of lime, and bits of crunchy tortilla chips.
author: Angi C.

description:
we walked in on a tuesday @ 7:30 and the place was hopping. we were able to sit at the bar within twenty minutes.  even though they have a small wait staff, we were greeted right away and service was great.  

sangria was yummy and the food was outstanding.  super fresh and flavorful.  guacamole was just right and tasted like it was made to order.  we ordered vegetarian dishes which were robust in flavor with a beautiful presentation.  they make their corn tortillas in house and they are FANTASTIC.  ended up taking some home.

the restaurant is small and the atmosphere bustling.  very friendly and attentive wait staff.  will definitely go back.
author: larisa p.

description:
Regalitos has a nice atmosphere and and friendly service.  The Sangria is excellent.  The chicken I had was rather dry but the mole sauce was excellent.  The Guac was a bit bland but the taquitos were yummy.  Prices are reasonable.  This is a good place to have in the neighborhood but it could be better.

SFD
author: Peter H.

description:
Because I am the un-lawful wife to the most negative of nancies, I was hoping, wishing and praying our dining experience at Regalito might at least silence his most previlent complaint: "there is no good mexican food in SF."  Instead it brough up a cache of new Eeyore-isms...and this time I had to agree.
I maybe midwestern and white, but my nancy is as latino as they come, and having been willingly "dragged" to some of California's finest, I consider myself quite the connoisseur of enchiladas.  And, though I must compliment the verde sauce at Regalito as well as the Cafe Habana-esque corn-on-the-cob, the rest was hum-drum and dull--giving a bad name to how utterly delicious free-range, fresh foods can actually be.
Worst of all: I sat wearing my coat sleeping-bag style for insallation while my best friend's teeth chattered next to me.  I can forgive the mild palate, but being old is not cool.  
Even I found myself complaining bitterly in memory of the blue corn tortilla lady and Mexico City, where you can eat your weight in those insanely delectable chips and drown yourself in tangy, zesty salsa.  
Still lookin' for some Mexican fan-fare that won't bring the boyfriend to tears.
author: Jamie H.

description: This small little place is cozy on a cold night if you sit away from the door.  I'm not a meat eater, but my friends who are rave about the roasted meet goodness here. The staff is always super friendly. The sangria is good and now that Ramblas has closed up shop I expect I will be coming here more often for a tasty beverage.
author: saru k.

description:
Great guacamole.  Bland, burned food otherwise, but man, you can't beat their guac.

I've dined here a couple of times and both experiences were unimpressive.  I suppose they make a decent rotisserie chicken, but their beans taste like sugary baked beans from a can, the rice is mushy and far more interestingly colored than flavored.  We also tried the red snapper, flavored with (drum roll...), lime.  It tasted like nothing but undercooked fish.  The nopalitos salad was interesting, but cold.  I had the mole on another occasion and it was OK, but the meat and the sauce where utterly unaware of each other.

I don't know what they're trying to do here ("Tex-Mex"?, "Neuvo-Oaxacan"?), but it sure isn't the rich, hot, hearty, fatty, garlicky family-style Mexican food I'm used to.
author: Aaron C.

description: I've been here before and the rotissorie chicken was average, which would earn this place a 2-3 star review notwithstanding the following. However, I went recently and they gave me and my friends the skunk eye while we were waiting for a table because we brought my friend's 10 month old baby along for dinner. They kept telling us it was inappropriate to wait by the door with a baby. Where the hell else are we supposed to wait? Infuriated, we left and went accross the street to El Toro, which was a thousand times more accommodating.
author: Ben B.

description: I really believe this place has some potential...granted its only been open for two weeks? I order the chicken torta which was surprising good but a little on the soggy side. The place is cute but it's screaming to yupsters to flood the joint. Maybe it just needs a little more time to work itself out.
author: Paola W.

description: Decent to very yummy food (get the mole).  Not too big space-wise.  Very accommodating staff.  Nice switch from your run-of-the-mill Mission taquaria.  Great locaton, too.
author: Tiberius A.

description:
Love the room, I just wish there were more tables (I sat at the counter). Very nice waitress

Good
- "Carne Asada y Hongos", grilled steak is proper
- pork special grilled with a paprika-ish spice, looks dry but incredibly tender, only came with refried beans, need rice for better balance

Ok
- "Ensalada de Nopalitos", grilled cactus and salsa, an interesting cold appetizer, oh their tortilla is so good

Skip
- sangria :-(
author: xo x.

description: Bland. Bland. Bland. I never add salt to my food and I kept going for the salt shaker here. No wonder why it was hard to get a refill on water--they must be used to their customers not needing it! I took some home in a box and thought of giving it to a homeless person but on our way home my stomach was grumbling--I couldn't give this food away.
author: Ann D.

description: Wow!  I can't believe I waited this long to try Regalito.  Maybe because there is so much inexpensive and quick Mexican food in the Mission, it never really made sense to go to a higher end place -- but this is no taqueria, and it's not just fancy burritos, either.  I was FLOORED by how delicious everything was, and every dish had a creative twist.  We were a group of 5 people, so we ordered a lot of different things on the menu, and every single person was impressed.  The tortilla soup was delicious - savory, light, flavorful.  The corn was devoured in minutes.  I had the carne asada - it was awesome.  The one entree that was underwhelming was the enchiladas rojas.  The desserts were pretty good -- there's a creative grilled mango dessert, churros with hot chocolate, a pretty standard flan, and a very good bread pudding.  The sangria was great.  On Mon/Tues nights there is a $28 prix fixe in which you can choose any appetizer, entree and dessert.  Unfortunately when we tried to order this, the waiter said it was "too late" because he had already entered in our orders - that was lame and we would have appreciated him being more accommodating - but other than this, we loved the place.  Two thumbs up, I can't wait to go back!!
author: Molly P.

description: Striking colors yet welcoming. The Ikea style kitchen and dining area beckons you in.  Clean and refreshing interior.  Great menu selection including grilled cactus and flan.  The BEST chicken mole with just the right amount of cocoa. Everything was fresh and delicious.  Price is right too!  I heard they have a great weekend brunch as well. I am definitely going back.
author: Grace C.

description:
My three year-old is the world's pickiest eater and he loves Regalito's. He will gobble down a bowl of rice and beans and eat half of my chicken order. All you parents out there know how impressive this is! They now do a half chicken with the fixings to go that is the BEST solution to a family meal when I can't quite get it together.

The mole here is divine.
The guaucamole to die for!
I had serious pregnancy cravings for the torta veggie sandwich and the limeade. 
Yum, yum for the green or red enchilades!
People are talking about the carne asada like it's a neighborhood secret that might get out. 

Finally Mexican food that tastes like Mexico and is not of the burrito variety! 

Do not leave this place without trying a desert. The owner is a pastry chef and you will NOT be disappointed.

We LOVE  LOVE LOVE everything about Regalito's including the decour, colors, art, and open kitchen!
author: Amy G.

description:
somewhere between 2 1/2 and 3 stars.

good, real art - great color scheme.

here's the quick & dirty on the food:

the chicken mole was delici-oh-so, though the meat was a bit dry. mole of excellent complexity.
the carnitas, perfect texture.
& who can do black beans & warm corn tortillas wrong?

but,
over 8 dollars for 3 small tomatoes (cut in 4ths) with a slice of cheese and a cilantro dressing is absurd. it doesn't matter how organic the tomatoes are.

$40+ for a bit of pork, 1/2 a chicken, and a few tomatoes, 
even with divine mole sauce, the take-away is simply over-priced for the belly full.
author: randi v.

description: I enjoyed the chicken soft taco with verde sauce.  In fact, their verde sauce is the thing worth trying in this place. Prices are reasonable.  A different kind of mexican.. I think I'll come back to try something else.
author: J J.

description:
YUMMMMM!!!

We stumbled into this place a couple weeks ago when my hunger (and crankiness) became an obvious issue. Yum is all I have to say.

Good
freshly fried whole tortilla chip thingees and freshy guac (watched them make it from our seats at the bar)
yummy chicken, sauce, veggies
friendly staff having a good time
chilequilies for brunch (yes, we went back the next day to try them)

Bad
snapping at bf for stealing my enchilada :-(
author: anna l.

description:
mole!  bloody mole!  imma cut it off n chop it up n make some guacaMOLE!

went here one nite for dinner n had the guacamole con tostadas--the molst memorable of course.  i had the pollo regalito n mi novio had the carne asada.  HUGE PORTION.  mmmm...nam nam nam ..delicioso!

MOLE! MOLE!  MOLEH MOLEH MOLEH!
author: Lady K.

description: Regalito is SO good.  I love the food, the atmosphere, the service, everything.  My favorite is the enchilada verde but the mole is great too.
author: Cynthia A.

description: I'm really sad to have to downgrade to 2 stars because this place has gone to crap. I've been going to Regalito almost every Sunday for more than 2 years. First, it was excellent. Then, they fired the chef and replaced him with a useless moron. We had to suffer through his crap for about 6 months. Then, he was fired and replaced with a competent chef, and things returned to normal. Then, that one was fired and replaced with a chef who is totally and wholly incompetent. The food became horrible, but what's worse, is that the management of the restaurant has become totally incompetent. One Sunday, there were no beans available because they didn't plan ahead and soak the beans. Then, halfway through the meal, they gave me a bowl of hard uncooked beans. The food itself was disgusting and almost inedible. I waited 6 weeks until returning. This time, the restaurant was closed b/c they changed the hours. I waited 1 hour to return. Upon returning, I was told that the dish I order every Sunday is not available because they didn't bother to pre-cook the ingredients the night before as they always had in the past. This sloppy incompetence is totally unacceptable.
author: Eater S.

description:
Delectable Fresh Mexican Cooking

I took my family and enjoyed an amazing 3 course meal for an unbelievably great price. Our favorites were the Limeade drink (never had a drink so tasty), the pumpkin seeds (super spicy kick), Guacamole with corn chips (best damn guacamole in this city), Chile Relleno de queso (finally a light dish of it's kind), beet salad (simple and perfect), and the bread pudding (giving Tartine Bakery a run for their money). The atmosphere was casual and warm with a stylish flair true to San Francisco. Our waiter was not only attentive but much like one in a fancy restaurant, memorized a hefty food order with multiple changes and served everyone correctly. The music was true to Latin America and played at the perfect volume. One may be skeptical after reading the catty reviews on Yelp but pay the snooty, intellectual, hipsters no mind because you'll have a great meal at a great price. And it you don't like the ambience, at least get Take-Out. As for myself and my family, I can't wait to go back!
author: Lisa D.

description:
My significant other stumbled across Regalito's in the Chronicle & thought the menu sounded tasty.

The establishment was VERY small. Parking can be a hassle. The food does smell good, I think I just ordered the wrong thing. The waiter told us about a special that SOUNDED good, but WASNT! anyhow, the verde enchiladas were good (I tasted my friends) & the salsa & chips that I paid for weren't too appetizing...I must say though, the waiter we had was really nice.

it was okaaay. I may be back - but there's definately no rush.
author: Jasmin P.

description:
Wow!! I had a great experience at Regalito and I'm picky. I was surprised to read some of the negative reviews and I thought they were mean and exaggerated. Oh well, everyone's got their say and it's fair that it's so.
José (our server) is a fantastic person. I think I caught myself saying "am I allowed to pull up a chair and invite you to join us at the table?"
The food is great and ORGANIC!
author: Thiago d.

description: Cute place, prices ok.  I could live off their guacamole.  Chicken mole was poached and covered w/ mole sauce, wish it was cooked in the mole sauce, sauce was a bit sweet for me but overall good.  Their papas con chorizo was very tasty, had to fight the bf for a few bites.  Their sangria was a bit too sweet for my taste.  Would go back to try the other entrees.
author: win c.

description:
I was SO disappointed at this place.  Given the high prices, I was expecting a Mexican fusion type dining experience with complex flavors.  What I got was quality below the regular taqueria joint at 3xs the price!  

Not withstanding the wait that was estimated to be 15 minutes that turned out to be almost 90 minutes, the meal started out okay, but got progressively worse.  We started with taquitos - the chicken ones were fine, but nothing spectacular.  The potato ones were not good, but edible.
