I did really like the slaw that came with the taquitos, but that was pretty much the highlight of the meal!  The guacamole was also pretty good, but could have used a little more lime and salt.  We shared fish tacos and enchiladas rojo.  The fish tacos were $17, so I expected something really spectacular and delicious,  but instead got overcooked, flavorless fish, and rubbery tortillas.  The enchiladas were tortillas with sauce that was way too burnt tasting to be edible.  No cheese, nothing - just tortillas and bad sauce.  The sangria tasted like flavored water and after drinking several glasses and not being the slightest bit buzzed, I'm pretty sure it was flavored water.

I don't know why anyone would go here given that there are a ton of better places within steps of this place.  It might do well in an area where there isn't a point of comparison to far superior Mexican food ... like Iowa.
author: Bay Area F.

description:
Fell short in almost every way.
Design: felt too cramped, tables too small
Food: The menu descriptions and the server make everything SOUND so good.  If only they put the same amount of effort cooking the dishes as they did describing them... Server encouraged certain items because such and such dish is "really good if you can find a place that does it right."  Felt like they were using psychology to con you into thinking that you're wrong for not liking what they serve.  Bland is really the word that comes to mind for their signature chicken, the enchiladas, even the guac.  Hope you have a better experience than I did.
author: Jay D.

description: I gave this place 5 stars for the sheer authenticity of the Mexican cooking, and the friendliness of the staff.  I haven't found anywhere else in San Francisco where you can get an actual, real "enchilada," folded over (not rolled) with sauce, onion slices and crumbled cheese on top.  And the roasted chicken is top-notch, and would be great to take home to the family and/or roommates.  Other highlights:   tasty roasted pumpkin seeds, guacamole that is actually as good as what I make myself, nice side dishes involving actual vegetables.  We loved it.
author: Eric W.

description:
I've been here a few times with friends and wanted to like it for its decor and location. 

The owner (?) - a big, imposing man with a black beard - has always welcomed us warmly, something I truly appreciated. However, it appears he hasn't been around as of late. Every time we go in here, we have a new young waitperson who appears to be just starting out on their first day. Basically, unprepared, scattered and unattentive. Is it so hard to keep good people? Or is this not a good place to work?

The sangria was good, though finding a fly in it kind of ruined the experience for me.

Wish I had more good to say but in SF, you have a lot of dining choices. The bar is set relatively high, and I think I'll be skipping this place from now on.
author: Pat E.

description: We had a Groupon coupon for Regalito Rosticeria and were concerned with some of the poor comments on Yelp re the restaurant, but decided to give it a try on a Sunday evening.  Our experience was that  the service was excellent, both friendly and nicely paced.  I had the pork shoulder with black beans which was delicious.  The restaurant itself is charming, nice decor - we do not live in the neighborhood, but if we did we would definitely make it a "go to" place.  Yes, the guacamole was mild, but it was accompanied by a hot sauce that you can add,  to please all tastes.  We eat at a number of Mexican restaurants in the East Bay and found the prices at this restaurant to be fair and in line with most nice Mexican restaurants in the Bay Area.
author: D. S.

description: Very disappointing. While the food was actual good, the service was atrocious.  Made a reservation for 3 via open table well in advance and then upon arrival was offered the community table or the bar. Both of those options seem more appropriate for walk ins. For 3 people, we opted for the community table. Then, we realized there was one waitress for the entire restaurant. After not being attended to, we asked the bus person if she could take our order and she said no but she would get the waitress--who never came. We had to go to get the waitress at which time the bus person ended up taking the order after all.  At every juncture throughout our meal, we had to get up to get the waitress to ask for everything--water refill (we were never asked if we wanted more to drink so we just opted for water after our first drink) and to clear our plates.  We were not attended to at all. Even after the restaurant thinned out and there were less people for the waitress to manage.  It's as if she thought there was another wait person managing the community table so she didn't need to.  It's too bad the service is so poor because it is actually a nice atmosphere and good food.
author: Wendy T.

description: awesome comida michoacana, great tortilla soup and pozole on the weekends...kinda like a baby nopalito, without the wait. a nopalitito. great wait staff, nice art, quick and pretty cheap, def a nice spot to have some legit upper middle class mexican.
author: Hayden S.

description: as my man Adam say's "this is the worst restaurant I've ever been to, not just the worst mexican, the worst restaurant"... which is usually a good sign that it's a good place.  can't compare it to a taqueria.. totally different thing.  very good food
author: Brent C.

description: ??? How can this place still be in business??? I don't have the energy to describe on how many levels this place is wrong. Please make space for a better restaurant.
author: Jennifer P.

description: I am a bit disapointed.  Loved the decor, but it felt overpriced.  There was only one other set of customers and service was slow.  The food was very simple for the price.
author: Paula S.

description: Terrible.  The cup of tortilla soup ($4.50) was lukewarm and watery.  If I hadn't sprayed lime juice in it, it wouldn't have tasted of anything.  The cochinita pibil ($16) was bland.  The portions were small -- the cochinita was several small pieces of pork and about three dozen black beans.  The small portions and fancy presentation didn't make the meal taste any more interesting.  At the end of the evening we plopped down $ 70 and felt like we had been taken.
author: Paul M.

description: The chips and salsa were tasty, but the chicken was very bland.  We had the lime rotisserie and the mole chicken.  After putting some of the lime chicken and the salsa into a tortilla, it didn't taste like much at all.  I tried topping with some mole, and it didn't really add much.  For $17, the mole chicken was not worth it at all.  It's a decent amount of chicken, but considering the flavor wasn't there, and you get a very ordinary side of rice, I would not go back.  A costco chicken has at least twice as much flavor and costs $5 or something.  The place was also freezing cold when we went.  We did go at around 8pm on a Sunday night, but that's still not an excuse for a dry, flavor-less, $17, half-chicken with some very average mole dumped onto it.  One last thing, I had a coupon for a free entree, and this place was still lame, even at half price.
author: Tom Z.

description:
when some friends were visiting from barcelona, i took them to the mission, which kinda scared the crap out of them. on our way home, we spied a "rosticeria", and immediately visions of the traditional sunday crispy roast chicken and potatoes that the spanish love so much came to mind. we timidly entered the newly opened place...which smelled like the rosticerias of home, sat down, and  had a feast. the chickens that we ordered were perfect and did not disappoint. one of us had the enchildas verdes and loved it. the staff was super friendly and answered all of my friend's curious questions about the more "native" dishes on the menu. i didn't think of it as a tony mexican restaurant...more of a mexican restaurant with a spanish flavor (having spent a lot of time in spain myself).
the only drawback was  the *tiny* space. we got lucky because it was early evening and hardly anyone was there...but even then, we could barely move without bumping into other diners. if you love  a good roast chicken, this may very well be heaven. yeah ok you can probably make the same at home, but there's something about the rosticeria atmosphere that adds to the flavor, i think. and the person that mentions that the pork is so good "even jews can't stay away"...uh not all jews keep kosher, and if your friend did, they sure as hell wouldn't be swayed. pork isn't always "good".
author: roz A.

description: Whoa, I'm surprised at some of the harsher reviews here.  It doesn't seem to have affected business much, though, on a Saturday at noon.  It was packed inside.  The draw for us was two dinky outdoor tables with not such a great view or sidewalk space, but on such a mild day, we just had to eat with Sadie in tow.  It was worth it.  The pozole, dyed my lips richly red with tingly spices.  It had loads of nice fatless chunks of pork and plenty of satisfyingly chewy hominy with radish, cabbage, lime, and oregano garnish and tasty hard-fried corn tortillas to crumble in.  We keep trying pozole every time we see it on a local menu, and RR's version comes the closest to rivaling my brother-in-law's, which is a nice surprise.  Chilaquiles were all right.  Higher priced than the usual Mexican restaurant, but this isn't a taqueria, ok?  Service was courteous and friendly.  Wouldn't order the agua de jamaica (hibiscus flowers) or tamarindo again as not to our taste, but they were flavorful and good to try.  Since it's a rosticeria, will try the meats next time.
author: Esther R.

description: prop for serving fair trade organic coffee from ritual. way to support the 'hood. the guac was pretty good, the salsa average. not enough chips with the guac, so we had to ask for more. the server was a space cadet hippie dude, to the point that the owner apologized to us for that and implored us to give the place another shot some other time. the chicken was okay but sort of dry. my friend who got steak clearly ordered the best out of all of us. the rest of us found the food just average. very very cute decor and i like the concept of the place more than the place itself. i'd go back, but i'm not in a rush.
author: Marla W.

description: Good tortillas. Mole was weird. To be honest, what I like the most about this place is their mural on the side of the building.  That's what drew me there in the first place.  It looks great.
author: Brandyn B.

description: i have to admit, i had passed this place so many times but always avoided it because the sign was too nice and i figured it was just americanized mexican food ...  i finally went in for a reunion dinner with two of my favorite girls, and was very pleasantly surprised at how good it was!  we sat at the bar (the mangos sitting on top were an odd touch) and i had the chile verde, which was a big bowl of warm, filling, green chile flavor.  our waiter was appropriately quirky (we think he was faking an accent for the first half of our meal) and the decor was bright and cheery.  definitely a good place for a pick-me-up meal with friends.
author: ali l.

description: This was amazing Mexican food. The guacamole was really fresh, and it came with homemade, salty tortilla chips.  I ordered the tortilla soup. It was perfectly spiced, and really the best tortilla soup I have ever had with tender chicken and lots of veggies and tortilla strips. I also ordered the papas con chorizo, and it was mind-blowing. The chorizo was crumbled into juicy, spicy deliciousness with queso fresco and slow-roasted potatoes. Everything we ate was perfect. it was so so good.
author: Kristen W.

description: I went with a friend recently, and made a reservation.  This was the middle of the week.  The host was pleasant, but the table was not ready when promised.  No apology was made.  Sat at the table, the lights here are harsh and they had some mariachi guys performing, some good, some not so good.  Drink order took a while.  Finally waitress came and asked if we were ready to order.  She was polite, but the food took FOREVER.  I'm not kidding, it was nearly an hour after we sat down before our food arrived. NO apology was made, no free app, no free drinks, nada.  The cochinita pibil was flavorful but dry, which is heretical.  The portions are small and the tortillas are delicious but they gave us three for two people.  The wait staff is not polished, and the experience completely does not justify the exorbitant prices.  I enjoy most restaurants.  This one was a complete disappointment.  The only up side was that I had a LOT of time to talk to my date.
author: Frank S.

description: imagine. mother's day. 2007. 6 hungry. one daughter under 30 (me). two pushy new york jewish couples missing their children. my mother lonley without her husband. one of the 6 (not me nor my mother) identifies as a millionaire foodie. and they are visiting me and a few art galleries in the mission. yet, again, they are hungry. and grumpy. and demanding. where do i turn in need? REGALITO ROSTICERIA - the wait staff were lovely, the food was perfect, they seasoned everything with and without oil and with and without the ice or the lime in the water glass and everything with a smile and calm - they just knew - a perfect meal for the perfect opportunity to have everything go wrong - i obviously loved my experience and recomend the place highly.
author: Lisa F.

description:
sad to say that it wasn't as yummy as i had expected.  =/

i had the chicken...so maybe i need to try something different.  i was expecting a bit more seasoning to it.  it was a light lunch though so i didn't feel overstuffed.  that's always a plus.

the guys working were prompt and polite.
author: H. G.

description: Great chicken here. The salsa/tortilla was a nice starter too. Will definitely be back sometime soon.
author: Jennifer H.

description: decor is nice and modern - great poster-lined lime green walls, we came for lunch and it was surprisingly empty. the food was pretty yummy, though the beans and rice weren't so great, but the mango juice made up for it. service was great also, attentive and sweet.
author: vina t.

description: i recently had dinner here with a small group of four. it was saturday night, at 7:30, and we were seated within 10 minutes, no reservations. this always makes me suspicious- it seems like a red flag for mediocrity.  we sat down and proceeded to order guacamole as an entree. it was nice, but needed salt. i had a pork dish that i enjoyed thoroughly, and the rest of my party had enchiladas. they seemed underwhelmed. in all, the food here is good, but nothing to rave about.
author: oona m.

description: Going in to this place, I really wanted to like the food.  I went about a month ago and couldn't believe that just a few months earlier, it was the salvadorian place that always gave me the impression that you had to be family to be let in. The renovation was done very tastefully. Three of us in our group ordered the pork dish, but it wasn't ready yet. Ah well, we did get there early.   Unfortunately, the beans tasted very burnt, so burnt they even smelled burnt.  Perhaps it was a simple oversight.  I had the chicken mole and it was dry and nearly flavorless.  I've had lots of moles in my day and this was way on the bottom. The chicken was even a bit dry.  A lovely mole sauce can make the plainest rice taste great, but when the mole is lacking, the rice just tastes bland.  The waitress was very sweet and apologetic about the burnt beans. They boast having all natural ingredients, free-range chicken, organic this and that.  But what good is spending so much in wonderful ingredients if they're not prepared properly? I think I'll wait a few more months and give it another chance after they've had a chance to work out the kinks.
author: Anthony C.

description: Oh so good.  Everything is covered in oh-so-tasty mole.  Really good guac.  Service is great.  I can't say enough good things.  Last time I came in with 7 people and we had to squeeze, but they accommodated us and the service was fast and the food was tasty as the first time I went.
author: Liz M.

description: This is perhaps the BEST chile verde or chicken enchiladas I have EVER had!  I LOVED it.....
author: J F.

description: I had to write a review about how "real" the Mexican food is here.  The comments that this is an Americanized or a California interpretation of Mexican cuisine are completely laughable. The idea for this restaurant was born from the food stalls in Mexico City, as seen in the "weird" set up as one yelper mentioned. I personally think sitting where you can see you food being cooked in front of you, is a good thing (unfortunately the Health Department requires that glass wall).  The red rice and refried beans, burritos, tacos, nachos, etc. are all "border food" and those are the Americanized versions of Mexican food.  Don't get me wrong I loves me a super burrito like the rest of us.  But I have to agree with the yelper who said for those who appreciate the PBS show Mexican:One plate at a time, have an appreciation for this restaurant.  As for the comments that the food tastes bland, I guess there is a reason for over seasoning.  If the meat or produce is not organic or fresh, than seasoning is needed to cover up the true flavor and quality of the food.  However, just try the enchiladas verde and if you think it is bland than maybe you just don't get it.  No worries there are plenty of taquerias to chose from in the mission.
author: Bryan S.

description: I've been to this restaurant twice, once for takeout and once eating in.  I found both of meals enjoyable.  I really like their chicken soup, rice and beans and taquitos.  I will defiantly be coming back.
author: Anne G.

description: First, no margaritas....bummer.  But the food is good.  I like the chips and salsa ( the chips are actually whole crispy tortillas).  Chile verde dishes are worth trying.  The restaurant is bright and cheery and clean; it is small however.  And parking is always a challenge in the Mission.  It is worth at least one visit to make your own decision.
author: K J.

description: Good food, but small portions and relatively expensive.The menu is small but kitchen is consistent. The ambiance is great.  The coffee is great. The best part was the service from William, our waiter.
author: M B.

description: i have walked past regalito so many times, and thought the outside looked cute, but never went in. i finally did. it was easter sunday around 4pm, so we caught the lunch menu (it's till 5). the lunch menu is smaller than the main one, and a little cheaper, by a couple of dollars. i dont think that even the dinner menu prices were at all expensive. we all love enchiladas. the lunch menu had red enchiladas, but when we got inside, we noticed it was vegetarian! which is good for some of you but i wanted meat. the hostess and waiter were really nice and said we could add meat. in fact, all 3 of us ended up having the enchiladas verdes From the dinner menu.  They were really good! our waiter told us they were the best thing there, and that they weren't really spicy, but the flavor was rich and just went "on and on and on." Well he was right, they were really good. some onions and cheese on the top and corn tortillas. There was rice and beans (not refried, the healthy kind) on the side in a bowl. For apps, we had guacamole with tortillas. It was mmm and came with plenty dip. Could have used a few more tortillas. All 3 of us had the mango juice, which was sweet and tasty. I was worried it'd come from a can, but it didn't!  Overall, very friendly staff, yummy, healthy tasting food, and good prices. It was a little small so I bet it can get crowded. But all 3 of us liked it. J expressed that it's his favorite Mexican place in san Francisco so far. I think this place and the one in west portal are tied, although they are different types of Mexican food. I think of this as what we'd be cooking if we lived in mexico... since of course you cant eat that greasy Mexican restaurant food every day normally... so it's probably more authentic than others.
author: Merredith L.

description: after about a week straight of cereal and milk for breakfast, lunch and dinner, i decided to join some friends for a proper meal yesterday (i guess that might skew any review i do towards a star for the better, oh well) . . . we came to this place out in the mission and i was pleasantly impressed.  not some seedy taqueria (which btw, are good in their own respect) but, rather a nice little establishment.  it's pretty small - not good for large parties but, perfect for 2 or 4.  between four of us, we got a couple of the guacamole dishes (by far the best thing we ordered - that could be a meal in itself for me), enchiladas verdes, taquitos, and to top it off churros w/hot chocolate for dessert - it was plenty and rather inexpensive.  they also have fresh squeezed orange juice which i got a puzzled look about - i guess people don't really order oj with a mexican dinner but hey, it was still early, like 5 in the evening.   (this place also does b-fast and brunch hence, the juice on the menu.)  all in all, i would definitely come back. next time for an earlier meal to try something different - and to be able to order my oj w/out shame :)
author: Tanvi A.
